div1.head: Κάβειροι
div1.sense: the Cabeiri, divinities worshipped in Lemnos and Samothrace, reputed to be sons of Hephaestus or Vulcan, from their skill in working metals, Hdt.

div1.head: κάγκανος
div1.sense: fit for burning, dry, Hom., Theocr.

div1.head: καγχαλάω
div1.sense: to laugh aloud, Lat. cachinnari, in Epic forms, 3rd pl. καγχαλόωσι Il.; part. καγχαλόων, -όωσα Hom. (Like καχάζω, formed from the sound.)

div1.head: καδίσκος
div1.sense: an urn or box: there were two, in which the dicasts placed their votes of guilty or not guilty, Ar.

div1.head: Καδμεῖος
div1.sense: Cadmean, Hes., Trag.; poet. Καδμέϊος, Pind., Soph., Ionic form Καδμήιος, η, ον Καδμεῖοι, οἱ, the Cadmeans or ancient inhabitants of Thebes, Hom., etc.; also Καδμείωνες, Il.:— ἡ Καδμεία the citadel of Thebes, Xen.:—proverb., Καδμεία νίκη a dear-bought victory (from the story of the Σπαρτοί, or that of Polynices and Eteocles), Hdt.

div1.head: Καδμηΐς
div1.etym: fem. of Καδμεῖος, Hhymn., Hes.; also in Attic, Thuc.

div1.head: Καδμογενής
div1.sense: Cadmus-born, Trag.

div1.head: Κάδμος
div1.sense: Cadmus, Od., Hes.: son of the Phoenician king Agenor, brother to Europa, founder of Boeotian Thebes. Cadmus brought from Phoenicia the old Greek alphabet of sixteen letters, hence called Καδμήια or Φοινικήια γράμματα (Hdt.); which was afterwards increased by the eight (so called) Ionic, η ω θ φ χ ζ ξ ψ.

div1.head: κάδος
div1.sense: a jar or vessel for water or wine, Lat. cadus, Hdt., etc.
a liquid measure, = ἀμφορεύς, Anth.
an urn or box for collecting the votes, like καδίσκος, Ar.

div1.head: Κάειρα
div1.sense: a Carian woman, Il.
adj. fem. = Καρική, Carian, Hdt.

div1.head: καθαγισμός
div1.sense: funeral rites, Lat parentalia, Luc.

div1.head: καθαγνίζω
div1.sense: to purify, hallow, Luc.:—Pass., μήτηρ πυρὶ καθήγνισται δέμας, i. e. has been burnt on the funeral-pyre, Eur.
to offer as an expiatory sacrifice, Eur.

div1.head: καθαιμακτός
div1.sense: bloodstained, bloody, Eur.

div1.head: καθαιμάσσω
div1.sense: to make bloody, sprinkle or stain with blood, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: κάθαιμος
div1.sense: bloodstained, bloody, Eur.

div1.head: καθαίρεσις
div1.sense: a pulling down, rasing to the ground, Thuc., Xen.: destruction, NTest.

div1.head: καθαιρετέος
div1.sense: to be put down, Thuc.

div1.head: καθαιρέτης
div1.sense: a putter down, overthrower, Thuc.

div1.head: καθαιρετός
div1.sense: to be taken or achieved, Thuc.

div1.head: καθαιρέω
div1.sense: to take down, καθείλομεν ἱστία we lowered sail, Od.; κ. ἄχθος to take a load down, i. e. off oneʼs shoulders, Ar.:—Mid., καταιρεῖσθαι τὰ τόξα to take down oneʼs bow, Hdt.
to put down or close the eyes of the dead, Hom.
of sorcerers, to bring down, Lat. caelo deducere, σελήνην Ar., Plat.
κατά με πέδον γᾶς ἕλοι (in tmesi) may earth swallow me! Eur.
to put down by force, destroy, Od., Trag.: simply to kill, slay, Eur.
in a milder sense, to put down, reduce, Hdt., Dem., etc.: to depose, dethrone, Hdt.; κ. τὸ λῃστικόν to remove it utterly, Thuc.
to rase to the ground, pull down, τὰς πόλεις Thuc.; τῶν τειχῶν a part of the walls, Xen.
to cancel, rescind, τὸ ψήφισμα Thuc.
as Attic law-term, to condemn, Soph.
to reduce in flesh, Plut.
to overpower, seize, κὰδ δέ μιν ὕπνος ᾕρει (in tmesi) Od.; καθ. τινὰ ἐν ἀφροσύνῃ to catch in the act of folly, Soph.: c. gen. partis, κ. τῶν ὤτων to seize by the ears, Theocr.
to fetch down as a reward or prize, καθαιρεῖν ἀγῶνα or ἀγώνισμα Plut.: metaph. to achieve, Pind.; so in Mid., φόνῳ καθαιρεῖσθʼ, οὐ λόγῳ, τὰ πράγματα Eur.; in Pass., Hdt.
more rarely like the simple αἱρέω, to take and carry off, seize, Hdt.

div1.head: καθάλλομαι
div1.sense: Dep., to leap down, Xen.: metaph. of a storm, to rush down, Il.

div1.head: καθαίρω
div1.sense: of the person or thing purified, to make pure or clean, cleanse, clean, purge, καθήραντες χρόα ὕδατι Od.:— to purge, clear a land of monsters and robbers, Soph.

in religious sense, to cleanse, purify, [δέπας ἐκάθηρε θεείωι purified it by fumigating with sulphur, Il.; καθ. τινὰ φόνου to purify him from blood, Hdt.; Δῆλον κ. Hdt.:—Mid. to purify oneself, get purified, Hdt.; οἱ φιλοσοφίαι καθηράμενοι Plat.:—so Pass., κεκαθαρμένος Hdt.
to prune a tree, i. e. clear it of superfluous wood, NTest.
metaph., = μαστιγόω, like our vulgar phrase "to rub down, " Theocr.
of the thing removed by purification, to purge away, wash off or away, λύματα Il.; ῥύπα Od.; φόνον Aesch.
c. dupl. acc., αἷμα κάθηρον Σαρπηδόνα cleanse Sarpedon of blood, wash the blood off him, Il.:—Pass., φόνον καθαρθείς Hdt.

div1.head: καθάπαν
div1.sense: on the whole; divisim καθʼ ἅπαν.

div1.head: καθάπαξ
div1.sense: once for all, Od., Dem.:—then, like ἁπλῶς, once for all, absolutely, Dem.

div1.head: καθά
div1.sense: for καθʼ ἅ, according as, just as, Xen.:— so καθάπερ, Ionic κατάπερ, Hdt., Ar., etc.:—strengthd., καθάπερ εἰ, Ionic κατάπερ εἰ, like as if, exactly as, Hdt., Plat.; καθάπερ ἄν Dem.; καθάπερ ἂν εἰ Plat., etc.

div1.head: καθαγίζω
div1.sense: to devote, dedicate, offer to a god, τί τινι Hdt., Ar., etc.:—of a burnt offering, Hdt.:— to make offerings to the manes, Lat. parentare, Luc.
generally, to burn, καταγιζομένου τοῦ καρποῦ Hdt.:— to burn a dead body, and even to bury, Plut.:—so, ὅσων σπαράγματʼ ἢ κύνες καθήγισαν whose mangled bodies dogs have buried, i. e. devoured, Soph.

div1.head: καθαπτός
div1.sense: bound with, equipt with a thing, c. dat., Ar.

div1.head: καθάπτω
div1.sense: to fasten, fix or put upon, τί τινι Soph.; so, κ. τι ἀμφί τινι Eur.; ἐπί τι Xen.:—Pass., βρόχῳ καθημμένος (perf. part.) fastened with a halter, i. e. hung, Soph.
to dress, clothe, in Mid., σκευῇ σῶμʼ ἐμὸν καθάψομαι Eur.
intr. in sense of Mid. (II), to lay hold of, τινός NTest.

Mid., καθάπτεσθαί τινα ἐπέεσσι, in good or bad sense, as, σὺ τόν γʼ ἐπέεσσι καθάπτεσθαι μαλακοῖσι or μειλιχίοις do thou accost or address him with gentle words, Hom.; or, ἀντιβίοις ἐπέεσσι καθαπτόμενος assailing or attacking . . , Od.: also without qualifying words, to accost or assail, γέροντα καθαπτόμενος προσέειπεν Od.
c. gen. to assail, attack, upbraid, Hdt., Attic;—also, like Lat. antestari, θεῶν καταπτόμενος appealing to them, Hdt.
to lay hold of, τυραννίδος Solon.; βρέφεος Theocr.

div1.head: καθάρειος
div1.sense: of persons, cleanly, neat, nice, tidy, Lat. mundus, Arist.:—adv. -είως or -ίως, Xen., etc.

div1.head: καθαρευτέος
div1.sense: one must keep oneself clean, Luc.

div1.head: καθαρεύω
div1.sense: to be clean or pure, Plat.: —c. gen. to be clean or free from guilt, Plut.; also, κ. ἀπʼ αὐτοῦ (sc. τοῦ σώματος) Plat.; also, καθ. γνώμῃ to be pure or clear in mind, Ar.

div1.head: καθαρίζω
div1.sense: to make clean, to cleanse, NTest.:—Pass. to be or become clean from disease, NTest.; and of the disease, to be purged away, NTest.

div1.head: καθαρειότης
div1.sense: cleanliness, purity, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: κάθαρμα
div1.sense: that which is thrown away in cleansing; in pl. the offscourings, refuse of a sacrifice, Aesch.
metaph. a castaway, outcast, Ar., Dem., etc.
in pl. = κάθαρσις, purification, Eur.
purified ground, ἐντὸς καθάρματος within the hallowed space, Ar.

div1.head: καθαρμόζω
div1.sense: to join or fit to, τί τινι Eur.

div1.head: καθαρμός
div1.sense: a cleansing, purification from guilt, Soph.:—hence, a means of purification, purifying sacrifice, atonement, expiation, καθαρμὸν τῆς χώρης ποιεῖσθαί τινα to make him an atonement for his country, Hdt.; μύσος ἐλαύνειν καθαρμοῖς by purifying rites, Aesch.; θοῦ νῦν καθαρμὸν δαιμόνων avert their wrath by purification, Soph.; καθαρμὸν θύειν to offer a purifying sacrifice, Eur.
applied to rites of initiation, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: καθαρός
div1.sense: clear of dirt, clean, spotless, unsoiled, Od., Hdt., Eur.

clear, open, free, ἐν καθαρῷ (sc. τόπῳ) in a clear, open space, Il.; ἐν καθαρῷ βῆναι to leave the way clear, Soph.; διὰ καθαροῦ ῥέειν, of a river whose course is clear and open, Hdt.; τὸ ἐμποδὼν ἐγεγόνεε καθαρόν the hindrance was cleared away, Hdt.:—c. gen., γλῶσσα καθαρὴ τῶν σημηΐων clear of the marks, Hdt.

in moral sense, clear from shame or pollution, pure, καθαρῷ θανάτῳ Od.: esp. clear of guilt or defilement, clean, pure, Theogn., Aesch.; καθαρὸς χεῖρας Hdt.:—so, of persons purified after pollution, ἱκέτης προσῆλθες κ. Aesch.; of things, βωμοί, θύματα, δόμοι, μέλαθρα Aesch., Eur.:—c. gen. clear of or from a charge, κ. ἐγκλημάτων, ἀδικίας, κακῶν, etc., Horaceʼs sceleris purus, Plat., Xen.
opp. to θολερός, clear of admixture, clear, pure, of water, Hdt., Eur.; so, κ. φάος, φέγγος Pind.; κ. ἄρτος χρυσός Hdt.; ἀργύριον Theocr.
of birth, opp. to ξένος, pure, , genuine, Pind., Eur.; τῶν Ἀθηναίων ὅπερ ἐστράτευε καθαρὸν ἐξῆλθε, i. e. who were citizens of pure blood, Thuc.:— καθαρόν a real, genuine saying, Thuc.
without blemish, τὸ καθαρὸν τοῦ στρατοῦ the sound portion of the army, Hdt.
clear, exact, ἂν καθαραὶ ὦσιν αἱ ψῆφοι if the accounts are clear, exactly balanced, Dem.
adv. καθαρῶς, Hes.; καθαρῶς γεγονέναι to be of pure blood, Hdt.
with clean hands, honestly, Theogn., Plat.
clearly, plainly, λέγειν Ar.; γνῶναι, εἰδέναι Ar., Plat.

div1.head: καθαρότης
div1.sense: cleanness, purity, in moral sense, Plat.

div1.head: καθαρπάζω
div1.sense: to snatch down, Eur.

div1.head: καθάρσιος
div1.sense: cleansing from guilt or defilement, purifying, Hdt., Soph.:—of sacrifice, αἷμα Aesch.; πῦρ, φλόξ Eur.
c. gen., καθ. φόνου cleansing or purifying from blood, Aesch.; but, κ. οἴκων purifying them, Eur.
as Subst., καθάρσιον (sc. ἱερόν) , a purifying sacrifice, Aeschin.:— hence, purification, Hdt.

div1.head: κάθαρσις
div1.sense: a cleansing from guilt or defilement, purification, Lat. lustratio, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: καθαρτής
div1.sense: a cleanser from guilt or defilement, purifier, Soph., Ar., etc.

div1.head: καθαρτικός
div1.sense: for cleansing or purifying, Plat.

div1.head: καθέδρα
div1.sense: a seat, κ. τοῦ λαγῶ a hareʼs seat or form, Xen.
the posture of sitting, ἐν τῇ καθέδρᾳ while they were sitting idle, Thuc.

div1.head: καθείμαρται
div1.sense: perf. pass., used impers. it is ordained to oneʼs ruin, Plut., Luc.

div1.head: καθείργνυμι
div1.sense: to shut in, enclose, confine, imprison, Od., Hdt., Attic

div1.head: καθέζομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:— to sit down, take oneʼs seat, Hom., Trag.
to sit as suppliants, Eur., Thuc.
to sit down in a country, encamp, Thuc.

div1.head: καθεῖς
div1.sense: for καθʼ εἷς one by one, εἷς καθεῖς, for εἷς καθʼ ἕνα, NTest.

div1.head: καθεκτέος
div1.sense: one must keep back, Plut.

div1.head: καθεκτός
div1.sense: to be held back or checked, Dem.: to be retained, Plut.

div1.head: καθελίσσω
div1.sense: to wrap with bandages, enfold, swathe, Hdt.:—Pass., τὰς κνήμας ῥάκεσι κατειλίχατο (Ionic 3rd pl. plup.), they have their legs swathed in rags, Hdt.

div1.head: καθέλκω
div1.sense: of ships, to draw them to the sea, launch them, Lat. deducere, Hdt., Attic
to draw down or depress the scale, Ar.

div1.head: καθέν
div1.sense: for καθʼ ἕν, one by one.

div1.head: καθέννυμι
div1.sense: to clothe, v. καταέννυμι.

div1.head: κάθεξις
div1.sense: a holding, retention, Thuc.

div1.head: καθέρπω
div1.sense: to creep down, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: καθεστηκότως
div1.sense: steadily, calmly, Arist.

div1.head: καθεστῶτα
div1.etym: syncop. for καθεστηκότα, perf. part. pl. neut. of καθίστημι.

div1.head: κάθετος
div1.sense: let down, of a fishing-line, Anth.

div1.head: καθευδητέος
div1.sense: one must sleep, Plat.

div1.head: καθεύδω
div1.sense: to lie down to sleep, sleep, Hom., etc.:— ἐκ τοῦ καθεύδοντος (part. neut.) from a sleeping state, Plat.
metaph. to lie asleep, lie idle, Aesch., etc.:—also of things, to sleep, lie still, be at rest, ἐλπίδες καθεύδουσιν Eur.

div1.head: καθευρίσκω
div1.sense: to discover, Luc.:—Pass., καθευρέθη κοσμοῦσα she was found in the act of adorning, Soph.

div1.head: καθεψιάομαι
div1.sense: Dep., to mock at, Lat. illudere, c. gen., Od.

div1.head: καθέψω
div1.sense: to boil down, Ar.
metaph. to soften, temper, Xen.

div1.head: καθηγεμών
div1.sense: a leader, a guide, Hdt.

div1.head: καθηγέομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:— to go before, act as guide, lead the way, absol., Hdt., Thuc.; οἱ κατηγεόμενοι the guides, Hdt.:—c. dat. to guide a person, Hdt.
c. acc. rei, to go before and teach a thing, to explain, expound, Hdt.
c. gen., καθ. τοῦ λόγου to begin the discourse, Plat.
to be the first to do, to establish, institute, Hdt.; οὐ κατηγήσομαι τὸν νόμον τόνδε τιθείς I will not begin establishing this law, Hdt.

div1.head: καθηδυπαθέω
div1.sense: to squander in luxury, Xen., Plut.

div1.head: καθήκω
div1.sense: to have come or gone down, esp. to fight, Aesch.
to come down to, come or reach to, Hdt.
to have come to any one, καθῆκεν ἐς ἡμᾶς ὁ λόγος the turn of speaking came to us, Aeschin.
of Time, ὁ χρόνος καθήκει the time is come, Xen.; ὅταν ἐκ τῶν νόμων καθήκῃ when [the time] appointed by the law comes, Dem.
to be meet, fit, proper, τοῦ καθήκοντος χρόνου Soph.; αἱ καθ. ἡμέραι the regular, proper days, Dem.

impers., καθήκει μοι it belongs to me, beseems me, c. inf., οἷς καθήκει ἀθροίζεσθαι whose duty it is to assemble, Xen.:—in part., τὸ καθῆκον, τὰ καθήκοντα, Ionic τὰ κατήκοντα, that which is meet, fit or proper, oneʼs due or duty, Hdt., Xen.; also the present state of things, circumstances, Hdt.

div1.head: καθηλιάζω
div1.sense: to bring the sun down upon, to illuminate, Anth.

div1.head: καθηλόω
div1.sense: to nail on or to, Plut.

div1.head: κάθημαι
div1.sense: to be seated, Hom., etc.
to be seated in court, Ar.; οἱ καθήμενοι the judges, the court, Thuc., etc.
to sit still, sit quiet, Lat. desidere, Hom., Hdt.: in bad sense, to sit or lie idle, Il., etc.
of a besieging army, to sit down or lie before a place, Eur., Thuc.
to lead a sedentary life, Hdt., Aesch., etc.
of people, to be settled, Hdt.

div1.head: καθημέριος
div1.sense: day by day, daily (καθʼ ἡμέραν) , Eur.:—later also καθημερινός, ή, όν, Plut.
on this day, Soph.

div1.head: καθιδρύω
div1.sense: to make to sit down, Od., Eur.:—Pass. to sit down, settle, Ar.; κ. ἐς Ἀργώ to take oneʼs seat in Argos, Theocr.
to consecrate, dedicate: so in aor1 mid. -ιδρυσάμην and perf. pass. -ίδρῡμαι, Eur.

div1.head: καθιερεύω
div1.sense: to sacrifice, offer, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: καθιερόω
div1.sense: to dedicate, devote, hallow, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: καθιέρωσις
div1.sense: a dedication, Aeschin., Plut.

div1.head: καθιζάνω
div1.sense: to sit down, θῶκόνδε καθίζανον they went to the council and took their seats, Od.; μάντις ἐς θρόνους κ. Aesch.

div1.head: καθίζω
div1.sense: Causal, to make to sit down, seat, Il., Hdt.; καθίσαι τινὰ εἰς θρόνον Xen.
to set or place, Hom.; καθίσαι στρατόν to encamp it, Eur., Thuc.
to set or place for any purpose, post, Od.; καθίσαι φυλάκους, φύλακας to set guards, Hdt., Xen.
to set up, ἀνδριάντα κάθεσσαν Pind.
to make an assembly take their seats, Od.; κ. τὸ δικαστήριον to hold the court, Ar.
to put into a certain condition, κλαίοντά τινα κ. to set him a-weeping, Plat.; also, κλαίειν τινὰ κ. to make him weep, Xen.
intr., like καθέζομαι, to sit down, be seated, take oneʼs seat, sit, Hom., etc.:—c. acc., καθ. τρίποδα, βωμόν, (as we say "to sit a horse"), Eur.
to sit at meals, Lat. discumbere, Xen.
to sit as judge, Hdt., Dem.
to sit down in a country, encamp, Thuc.
to settle, sink in, Plat.
the Mid. is also used in intr. sense, Il., Theocr., etc.; καθίζεσθαι to take their seats (in the theatre), Dem.

div1.head: καθίημι
div1.sense: to send down, let fall, Lat. demittere, Hom., etc.; ἱστία ἐς νῆας κάθεμεν (1st pl. aor2) we let down, lowered the sails, Od.; κ. ἄγκυραν Hdt.; κ. καταπειρητηρίην to let down a sounding-line, Hdt.; καθιέναι to sound, Plat.; καθῆκε τὰ σκέλη let down his legs, of one who had been lying down, Plat.; κ. δόρυ to let down oneʼs pike, bring it to the rest, Xen.; κ. τὰς κώπας to let down the oars, so as to stop the shipʼs way, Thuc.:—rarely of striking, διʼ ὀμφαλοῦ καθῆκεν ἔγχος Eur.; γόνυ καθεῖσαν sank on their knee, Eur.:— Pass. to come down, of a cowʼs udder, Hdt.; καθεῖτο τὰ τείχη the walls were carried down to the water, Thuc.
to send down into the arena, enter for racing, ἅρματα, ζεύγη Thuc.; τοῦτον τὸν λόγον καθεῖκε has entered this plea, Dem.
to set at, Lat. immittere, Luc.:—Pass. to be put in motion, ἡ στρατηλασίη κατίετο ἐς τὴν Ἑλλάδα Hdt.
seemingly intr. (sub. ἑαυτόν) , to swoop down like a wind, Ar.; of rivers, to run down, Plat.; κ. εἰς γόνυ to sink on the knee, Plut.

div1.head: καθικετεύω
div1.sense: to beg earnestly, Eur.
to offer earnest prayers, Hdt.

div1.head: καθικνέομαι
div1.sense: Dep., to come down to: metaph. to reach, touch, με καθίκετο πένθος Od.; καθίκεο θυμόν hast touched my heart, Il.; κάρα μου καθίκετο came down upon my head, Soph.

div1.head: καθιμάω
div1.sense: to let down by a rope, Ar.

div1.head: καθιππάζομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:
to ride down, overrun with horse, Hdt.
to ride down, trample under foot, Aesch.

div1.head: καθίστημι
div1.sense: in Causal sense; of Act., pres., imperf., fut.; of Mid., the aor1, and sometimes pres.:— to set down, place, Il.; νῆα κατάστησον stop it, bring it to land, Od.; κ. δίφρον to station it, before starting for the race, Soph.:—Mid., λαῖφος κατεστήσαντο steadied the sails, Hhymn.
to bring down to a place, Od., etc.:— to restore, ἐς φῶς σὸν κατ. βίον Eur.:—Pass., οὐκ ἂν χάρις καθίσταιτο would not be returned, Thuc.
to bring before a magistrate or king, Hdt.
of soldiers, to set in order, to set as guards, Xen.
to ordain, appoint, Hdt., etc.:—in aor1 mid. to appoint for oneself, establish, institute, Hdt., Aesch.

esp. of political constitutions, to settle, establish, νόμους Eur., etc.; κατ. πολιτείαν, Lat. constituere rempublicam, Plat., etc.:— so in Mid., φρούρημα γῆς καθίσταμαι Aesch.; καθίστατο τὰ περὶ τὴν Μιτυλήνην Thuc.

to bring into a certain state, κατ. δῆμον ἐς μοναρχίαν Eur.; κ. τινὰ ἐς ἀπόνοιαν, ἐς φόβον, ἐς ἀπορίαν Thuc.; so, κ. τοὺς φίλους ἐν ἀκινδύνῳ Xen.:—also, κ. ἑαυτὸν ἐς κρίσιν to present himself for trial, Thuc.
to make or render so and so, κ. τινα ψευδῆ Soph.; ἄπιστον Thuc.:—rarely c. inf., καθ. τινὰ φεύγειν to make him fly, Thuc.:—Mid., τὴν ναυμαχίαν πεζομαχίαν καθίστασθαι Thuc.
τὴν ζόην καταστήσασθαι ἀπʼ ἔργων ἀνοσιωτάτων to get oneʼs living by most unhallowed deeds, Hdt.
to make, continue, Aesch.; so in Mid., Aesch.
intr. in aor2, perf., and plup. of Act. (also in fut. καθεστήξω) , and in all tenses of Mid. (except aor. 1), and all of Pass.:— to be set, set oneself down, settle, arrive, ἐς τόπον Hdt., Soph.
to come before another, stand in his presence, Hdt.; καταστὰς ἐπὶ τὸ πλῆθος ἔλεγε Thuc.
to be set as guard, Hdt., etc.: to be appointed, Eur., etc.
to stand quiet, be calm, of water, Ar.; so, πνεῦμα καθεστηκός Ar.; ὁ θόρυβος κατέστη abated, Hdt.; so, of persons, καταστάς composedly, Aesch.; ἡ καθεστηκυῖα ἡλικία middle age, Thuc.

in perf. to come into a certain state, to become, and in aor2 and plup. to be, Hdt., etc.; καταστάντων εὖ τῶν πρηγμάτων being in a good state, Hdt.; τίνι τρόπῳ καθέστατε; in what case are ye? Soph.; ἀρξάμενος εὐθὺς καθισταμένου (sc. τοῦ πολέμου) from its first commencement, Thuc.

to be established or instituted, to prevail, exist, Hdt., etc.: in perf. part., existing, established, prevailing, τὸν νῦν κατεστεῶτα κόσμον Hdt.; οἱ καθεστῶτες νόμοι Soph.; τὰ καθεστῶτα the present state of life, Soph.; so, τὰ κατεστεῶτα, existing laws, customs, Hdt.
Pass. to stand against, oppose, Τιτήνεσσι κατέσταθεν Hes.

div1.head: κάθοδος
div1.sense: a going down, descent, Luc.: a way down, Luc.
a coming back, return, Eur., Thuc.; of an exile, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: καθόλου
div1.sense: as adv. on the whole, in general, for καθʼ ὅλου, Arist., etc.; οὐ καθόλου, not at all, Dem.

div1.head: καθομιλέω
div1.sense: to conciliate by daily intercourse, to win the favour of, Arist.

div1.head: καθομολογέω
div1.sense: to confess or allow, esp. to oneʼs detriment, Plat.
to promise, vow, Luc.
to betroth, Plut.

div1.head: καθοπλίζω
div1.sense: to equip or arm fully, τῇ πανοπλίᾳ Aeschin.:—Pass. to be so armed, Xen.
τὸ μὴ καλὸν καθοπλίσασα having taken arms against dishonour, Soph.

div1.head: καθό
div1.sense: adverb for καθʼ ὅ, καθά, in so far as, according as, Lys., etc.
so that, Plat.

div1.head: καθοδηγέω
div1.sense: to guide, Plut.

div1.head: καθόπλισις
div1.sense: a mode of arming, armour, Xen.

div1.head: καθοράω
div1.sense: to look down, Il., Hdt.; so in Mid., Il.
c. acc. to look down upon, ὁπόσους ἠέλιος καθορᾷ Theogn., etc.
to have within view, to perceive, Hdt., Ar., etc.
to look to, observe, Pind., Ar.
to explore, τὰ ἄλλα Hdt.

div1.head: καθορμίζω
div1.sense: to bring a ship into harbour, bring to anchor, Plut.:—Pass., with aor1 mid., to come into harbour, put in, Thuc.
metaph., ἐς τάσδε σαυτὸν πημονὰς καθώρμισας hast brought thyself to such miseries, Aesch.

div1.head: καθοσιόω
div1.sense: Mid. to dedicate, θεῷ Eur.:—Pass., καθωσιώθη Ar.
κ. πόλιν καθαρμοῖς to purify, Plut.

div1.head: καθόσον
div1.sense: for καθʼ ὅσον in so far as, inasmuch as, Thuc.

div1.head: καθότι
div1.sense: for καθʼ ὅ τι, in what manner, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: καθυβρίζω
div1.sense: to treat despitefully, to insult or affront wantonly, τινά Soph., etc.; also τινός Soph.:—Pass., absol., to wax wanton, Soph.

div1.head: κάθυδρος
div1.sense: full of water, κάθυδρος κρατήρ, poet. for water itself, Soph.

div1.head: καθυπερακοντίζω
div1.sense: to overshoot completely, Ar.

div1.head: καθύπερθε
div1.sense: from above, down from above, Hom., etc.:—c. gen., κ. μελαθρόφιν Od.

on the top or upper side, above, Od.; καθ. ἐπιρρέει floats atop, Il.:— to denote geographical position, Φρυγίη καθύπερθε Il.; c. gen., καθύπερθε Χίου above, i. e. north of, Chios, Od.; τὰ κ. the upper country, i. e. further inland, τὰ κ. τῆς λίμνης Hdt.; καθύπερθε γενέσθαι τινός, properly, of a wrestler who falls atop of his opponent; hence, to have the upper hand of, Hdt.
of Time, before, c. gen., Hdt.

div1.head: καθυπέρτατος
div1.sense: highest, ἐν τῇ κατυπερτάτῃ τῆς γῆς Hdt.

div1.head: καθυπνόω
div1.sense: to be fast asleep, fall asleep, Hdt., Xen.:—Pass., perf. part. κατυπνωμένος asleep, Hdt.

div1.head: καθυποκρίνομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:
to subdue by histrionic arts, Dem.
c. inf. to pretend to be some one else, Luc.

div1.head: καθυστερέω
div1.sense: to come far behind, Plut.: absol. to be behind-hand, Menand.

div1.head: καθυφίημι
div1.sense: to give up treacherously, Dem.; καθ. τὸν ἀγῶνα to conduct it treacherously, compromise it, Dem.; so also in Mid., with perf. pass., Dem.
Mid., καθυφίεσθαί τινι to give way to any one, Xen.

div1.head: καθυπέρτερος
div1.sense: above: metaph. having the upper hand, superior, κ. γίγνεσθαι Hdt., Thuc., etc.: c. gen., πόλις κ. τῶν ἀντιπάλων Xen.:—neut. καθυπέρτερον as adv., = καθύπερθε, Theocr.

div1.head: καθώς
div1.sense: = καθά, Hdt., NTest.
how, NTest.

div1.head: καιάδας
div1.sense: a pit at Sparta, into which criminals were thrown, like the Athen. βάραθρον, Thuc., Plut.

div1.head: καὶ γάρ
div1.sense: for truly, to confirm a proposition, Lat. etenim, Hom., etc.:—also καὶ γὰρ δή for of a surety, Il.; καὶ γάρ ῥα Il.; καὶ γὰρ οὖν, καὶ γάρ τοι, Lat. etenim profecto, Plat., etc.

div1.head: καὶ δέ
div1.sense: but also, Hom.

div1.head: καὶ δή
div1.sense: nay further, Hdt.

div1.head: καὶ εἰ
div1.sense: even if, although, Hom.

div1.head: καἴκα
div1.sense: crasis for καὶ αἴκα.

div1.head: καικίας
div1.sense: the north-east wind, Ar.

div1.head: καινίζω
div1.sense: to make new: hence, καί τι καινίζει στέγη and the house has something strange about it, Soph.; καίνισον ζυγόν try on thy new yoke, handsel it, Aesch.; κ. εὐχάς to offer new, strange prayers, Eur.

div1.head: καινοπαθής
div1.sense: newly suffered: unheard of, Soph.

div1.head: καινοπηγής
div1.sense: newly put together, newmade, Aesch.

div1.head: καινοπήμων
div1.sense: new to misery, Aesch.

div1.head: καινοποιέω
div1.sense: to make new, to bring about new things, to make changes, innovate, Luc.:—Pass., τί καινοποιηθὲν λέγεις; what new-fangled, strange words art thou using? Soph.

div1.head: καινοποιητής
div1.sense: an inventor of new pleasures, Xen.

div1.head: καινός
div1.sense: new, fresh, Lat. recens, novus, καινὰ καὶ παλαιὰ ἔργα Hdt.; καινοὺς λόγους φέρειν to bring news, Aesch.; λέγεταί τι καινόν; Dem.; ἐκ καινῆς (sc. ἀρχῆς) anew, afresh, Lat. de novo, Thuc.:—esp. of dramas produced for the first time, Aeschin., Dem.

newly-invented, new-fangled, novel, Eur., etc.; κ. θεοί strange gods, Plat.; καινά innovations, Xen.; οὐδὲν καινότερον εἰσέφερε τῶν ἄλλων he introduced as little of anything new as others, Xen.; τὸ καινὸν τοῦ πολέμου the unforeseen turn which war often takes, Thuc.
κ. ἄνθρωπος novus homo, Plut.

div1.head: καινόταφος
div1.sense: of a new tomb, Anth.

div1.head: καινότης
div1.sense: newness, freshness, Plut.
novelty, Thuc., etc.

div1.head: καινοτομέω
div1.sense: to cut fresh into, in mining, to open a new vein, Xen.
metaph. to begin something new, institute anew, Ar.: absol. to make innovations in the state, Lat. res novare, Arist.; also, κ. περὶ τὰ θεῖα Plat.

div1.head: καινοτομία
div1.sense: innovation, Plut.
novelty, Plut.

div1.head: καινοτόμος
div1.sense: innovating, Arist.

div1.head: καινουργέω
div1.sense: to begin something new, τί καινουργεῖς; what new plan art thou meditating? Eur.; κ. λόγον to speak new, strange words, Eur.: to make innovations, Xen.; and

div1.head: καινουργία
div1.sense: innovation, Isocr.

div1.head: καινουργός
div1.sense: producing changes: τὸ κ. a novelty, Luc.

div1.head: καινόω
div1.sense: to make new, innovate:— Pass., of political changes, Thuc.; καινοῦσθαι τὰς διανοίας to have their minds revolutionised, Thuc.
= καινίζω, to use for the first time, to handsel, Hdt.

div1.head: καί νύ κε
div1.sense: and now perhaps, Hom.

div1.head: καίνυμαι
div1.etym: the pluperfect commonly functions as imperf.
div1.sense: to surpass, excel, ἐκαίνυτο φῦλʼ ἀνθρώπων νῆα κυβερνῆσαι he surpassed mankind in steering, Od.; ἐγχείηι δʼ ἐκέκαστο Πανέλληνας he excelled all the Hellenes in throwing the spear, Od.; ὁμηλικίην ἐκέκαστο γνῶναι surpassed them all in knowledge, Od.: esp. in part., δόλοισι κεκασμένε excellent in wiles, Od.: τέχνηισι κεκασμένος Hes.; φρουραῖς κέκασται is well furnished with, Eur.

div1.head: καὶ νῦν
div1.sense: and now, even now, Hom.

div1.head: καίνω
div1.sense: to kill, slay, Trag., Xen.

div1.head: καί
div1.sense: Conjunction, used in two principal senses, either copulative, to join words and sentences, and, Lat. et; or making a single word or clause emphatic, also, even, Lat. etiam.

copulative, and, merely joining words or sentences, Lat. et, while τε answers to que, Hom., etc.: to combine more closely, τε . . , καὶ . . are used, ἄρκτοι τε καὶ λέοντες both bears and lions, etc.; often to add epithets after πολύς, πολλὰ καὶ ἐσθλά Il.; πολλὰ καὶ μεγάλα Dem., etc.:— θεοὶ καὶ Ζεύς all the gods, and above all Zeus, Aesch.; ἄλλοι τε καί . . , ἄλλως τε καί . . , v. ἄλλος, ἄλλως:—ὀλίγου τινὸς ἄξια καὶ οὐδενός worth little or nothing, Plat.
in questions, to introduce an objection, καὶ πῶς . . ; but how . . ? nay how can it be? Eur., etc.:—also = καίτοι, and yet, Ar.

after words implying sameness or likeness, καί must be rendered by as, like Lat. atque or ac after aeque, perinde, simul, γνώμῃσι ὁμοίῃσι καὶ σύ the same opinion as you, Hdt.; ἴσον or ἴσα καί. . , Soph., etc.: in Attic, καί . . , καί . . answer to the Lat. cum, tum, not only, but also, Plat., etc.

influencing single words or clauses, also, even, Lat. etiam, ἔπειτά με καὶ λίποι αἰών then let life also forsake me, i. e. life as well as all other goods, Il.; καὶ αὐτοί they also, they likewise, Xen.; εἴπερ τις καὶ ἄλλος Plat., etc.

div1.head: καίπερ
div1.sense: although, albeit, mostly with a part., καίπερ πολλὰ παθών Od.; often divided, καὶ οὐκ ἀγαθόν περ ἐόντα Il.; καὶ κρατερός περ ἐών Il.; in Trag., with ὅμως added, καίπερ οὐ στέργων ὅμως Trag., etc.

div1.head: καί ῥα
div1.sense: Epic, to make a transition, and so, Il.

div1.head: καίριος
div1.sense: of Place, in or at the right place, hence of parts of the body, ἐν καιρίῳ, κατὰ καίριον in a vital part, Il.; also, of wounds, πέπληγμαι καιρίαν πληγήν, καιρίας πληγῆς τυχεῖν Aesch.; πληγή is sometimes omitted, Hdt.:— adv. -ίως, mortally, Aesch.
of Time, in season, seasonable, timely, opportune, Hdt., Trag., etc.; τὰ καίρια timely circumstances, opportunities, Thuc.
lasting but for a season, Anth.
adv. -ρίως, in season, seasonably, Aesch.: comp. -ωτέρως Xen.:—so also, πρὸς τὸ καίριον Soph.

div1.head: καιροσέων
div1.sense: a fem. gen. pl. in Od. 7. 107, καιροσέων ὀθονέων ἀπολείβεται ἔλαιον from the close-woven linen trickles off the oil;—i. e. the linen is so well-woven, that oil does not ooze through. It seems to be for καιροεσσέων, Epic gen. pl. of an adj. καιρόεις, from καῖρος.

div1.head: καῖρος
div1.sense: the row of thrums in the loom, to which the threads of the warp are attached, Lat. licia.

div1.head: καιρός
div1.sense: due measure, proportion, fitness, Hes., etc.; καιροῦ πέρα beyond measure, unduly, Aesch., etc.; μείζων τοῦ καιροῦ, Lat. justo major, Xen.
of Place, a vital part of the body, like τὸ καίριον, Eur.

of Time, the right point of time, the proper time or season of action, the exact or critical time, Lat. opportunitas, καιρὸς βραχὺ μέτρον ἔχει "time and tide wait for no man," Pind.; καιρὸν παριέναι to let the time go by, Thuc.; καιροῦ τυχεῖν Eur.; καιρὸν λαμβάνειν Thuc.; ἔχειν καιρόν to be in season, Thuc.:— καιρός ἐστι, c. inf., it is time to do, Hdt., etc.

adverbial usages, εἰς or ἐς καιρόν in season, at the right time, opportune, Hdt., etc.; so, ἐπὶ καιροῦ Dem.;— κατὰ καιρόν Hdt.; πρὸς καιρόν Soph., etc.; and, without Preps., καιρῷ or καιρόν in season, Attic;—all these being opp. to ἀπὸ καιροῦ, Plat.; παρὰ καιρόν Eur.; πρὸ καιροῦ prematurely, Aesch.
pl., ἐν τοῖς μεγίστοις κ. at the most critical times, Xen., etc.

advantage, profit, fruit, τινος of or from a thing, Pind.; τί καιρὸς καταλείβειν; what avails it to . . ? Eur.; οὗ κ. εἴη where it was convenient or advantageous, Thuc.; μετὰ μεγίστων καιρῶν with the greatest odds, the most critical results, Thuc.

div1.head: καιροφυλακέω
div1.sense: to watch for the right time, Dem.:—also, to attend on, Luc.

div1.head: καίτοι
div1.sense: καί τοι , and indeed, and further, Hom., Eur.
and yet, to mark an objection, καίτοι τί φημι; Aesch.; καίτοι τί φωνῶ; Soph.:—also, strengthd. καίτοι γε Ar.

div1.head: καίω
div1.sense: to light, kindle, πυρὰ πολλά Il.; πῦρ κῆαι Od.; Mid., πῦρ κήαντο they lighted them a fire, Hom.:—Pass. to be lighted, to burn, Il., Hdt., etc.
to set on fire, burn up, burn, Hom.
to burn, scorch, of the sun, Hdt.:—also of extreme cold (as Virg. penetrabile frigus adurit), Xen.
Pass., of fever-heat, to be burnt or parched up, Thuc.: metaph. of passion, Pind., etc.
to burn and destroy (in war), τέμνειν καὶ κ., κ. καὶ πορθεῖν to waste with fire and sword, Xen.
of surgeons, to cauterise, τέμνειν καὶ κάειν to use knife and cautery, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: κακάγγελος
div1.sense: bringing ill tidings, Aesch.

div1.head: κακάγγελτος
div1.sense: caused by ill tidings, Soph.

div1.head: κακαγόρος
div1.etym: Doric for κακηγόρους, acc. pl. of κακήγορος.

div1.head: κακανδρία
div1.sense: unmanliness, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: κακέσχατος
div1.sense: extremely bad, Menand.

div1.head: κακηγορέω
div1.sense: to speak ill of, abuse, slander, Plat.

div1.head: κακηγορία
div1.sense: evil-speaking, abuse, slander, Pind., Plat.:— κακηγορίας δίκη an action for defamation, Dem.; also κακηγορίου, δίκη, ap. Dem.

div1.head: κακήγορος
div1.sense: evil-speaking, abusive, slanderous, Pind., Plat.

div1.head: κακηλόγος
div1.sense: evil-speaking, Menand.

div1.head: κάκη
div1.sense: wickedness, vice, Eur., Ar., etc.
baseness of spirit, cowardice, sloth, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: κακία
div1.sense: badness in quality, opp. to ἀρετή (excellence), Theogn., Soph.:—pl. κακίαι defects, Luc.
cowardice, sloth, Thuc., Plat.
moral badness, wickedness, vice, Plat., Xen.
ill-repute, Thuc.
evil suffered, NTest.

div1.head: κακίζω
div1.sense: to abuse, reproach, accuse, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
to make cowardly, Eur.:— Pass. to play the coward, Il., Eur.; κακίζεσθαι τύχῃ to be worsted by fortune alone, Thuc.

div1.head: κακιστέος
div1.sense: one must bring reproach on, τινά Eur.

div1.head: κακκάω
div1.sense: cacare, Ar.

div1.head: κάκκη
div1.sense: ordure, dung, Ar.

div1.head: κακόβιος
div1.sense: living ill or poorly, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: κακοβουλεύομαι
div1.sense: to be ill-advised, Eur.

div1.head: κακόβουλος
div1.sense: ill-advised, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: κακόγαμβρος
div1.sense: κακό-γαμβρος γόος, distress for her wretched brother-in-law, Eur.

div1.head: κακογαμίου
div1.sense: κακο-γαμίου, δίκη, ἡ, an action for forming an unlawful marriage, Plut.

div1.head: κακογείτων
div1.sense: a bad neighbour or a neighbour to his misery, Soph.

div1.head: κακόγλωσσος
div1.sense: ill-tongued, βοὴ κ. a cry of misery, Eur.

div1.head: κακοδαιμονάω
div1.sense: to be tormented by an evil genius, be like one possessed, Ar., Xen., etc.

div1.head: κακοδαιμονέω
div1.sense: to be unfortunate, Xen.

div1.head: κακοδαιμονία
div1.sense: unhappiness, misfortune, Hdt., Xen., etc.
possession by a demon, raving madness, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: κακοδαίμων
div1.sense: possessed by an evil genius, ill-fated, ill-starred, miserable, Eur., Ar.:—adv. -μόνως, Luc.
as Subst. an evil genius, Ar.

div1.head: κακοδοξέω
div1.sense: to be in bad repute, Xen.

div1.head: κακοδοξία
div1.sense: bad repute, infamy, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: κακόδοξος
div1.sense: in ill repute: i. e.,
without fame, unknown, Theogn.
infamous, discreditable, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: κακοείμων
div1.sense: ill-clad, Od.

div1.head: κακοζηλία
div1.sense: unhappy imitation, affectation, Luc.

div1.head: κακοήθεια
div1.sense: badness of disposition, malignity, Plat., etc.
bad manners or habits, Xen.

div1.head: κακοήθευμα
div1.sense: a malicious deed, Plut.

div1.head: κακοήθης
div1.sense: ill-disposed, malicious, Ar., Dem.
as Subst., τὸ κακόηθες wickedness, an ill habit or itch for doing a thing, Plat.
of diseases, malignant:—adv. -θως, ap. Dem.

div1.head: κακοθημοσύνη
div1.sense: disorderliness, Hes.

div1.head: κακόθροος
div1.sense: evil-speaking, slanderous, Soph.

div1.head: κακοθυμία
div1.sense: malevolence, Plut.

div1.head: Κακοΐλιος
div1.sense: evil or unhappy Ilium, Od.

div1.head: κακοκέρδεια
div1.sense: base love of gain, Theogn.

div1.head: κακόκνημος
div1.sense: weak-legged, thin-legged, Theocr.

div1.head: κακοκρισία
div1.sense: a bad judgment, Anth.

div1.head: κακολογέω
div1.sense: to speak ill of, to revile, abuse, Lys., NTest.

div1.head: κακολογία
div1.sense: evil-speaking, reviling, Hdt., Xen., etc.

div1.head: κακολόγος
div1.sense: evil-speaking, Pind., Attic

div1.head: κακόμαντις
div1.sense: prophet of ill or evil, Aesch.

div1.head: κακομαχέω
div1.sense: to behave ill in fight, Luc.

div1.head: κακομέλετος
div1.sense: busied with evil, Aesch.

div1.head: κακομηδής
div1.sense: contriving ill, deceitful, Hhymn.

div1.head: κακομηχανία
div1.sense: a practising of base arts, Luc.

div1.head: κακομήχανος
div1.sense: mischief plotting, mischievous, baneful, Hom.

div1.head: κακομίμητος
div1.sense: imitating ill; adv. -τως, Arist.

div1.head: κακόμοιρος
div1.sense: ill-fated, Anth.

div1.head: κακόνοια
div1.sense: ill-will, malignity, malice, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: κακονομία
div1.sense: a bad system of laws and government, a bad constitution, Xen.

div1.head: κακόνομος
div1.sense: with bad laws, ill-governed, Hdt.

div1.head: κακόνοος
div1.sense: ill-disposed, disaffected, Ar., Thuc., etc.:— bearing malice against, τινι Xen.:—Sup. κακονούστατος Dem.

div1.head: κακόνυμφος
div1.sense: ill-married, of unhappy wedlock, Eur.
as Subst. an ill or unhappy bridegroom, Eur.

div1.head: κακόξενος
div1.sense: unfortunate in guests, in irreg. Epic comp. κακοξεινώτερος, Od.
unfriendly to strangers, inhospitable, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: κακοξύνετος
div1.sense: wise for evil, Thuc.

div1.head: κακοπάθεια
div1.sense: ill plight, distress, Thuc.

div1.head: κακοπαθέω
div1.sense: to suffer ill, to be in ill plight, be in distress, Thuc., Xen., etc.

div1.head: κακοπαθής
div1.sense: suffering ill, in ill plight; adv. -θῶς, miserably, Arist.

div1.head: κακοπάρθενος
div1.sense: unbecoming a maid, Anth.

div1.head: κακόπατρις
div1.sense: having a mean father, low-born, Theogn.

div1.head: κακοπινής
div1.sense: exceeding filthy, loathsome, Sup. κακοπινέστατος Soph.

div1.head: κακοποιέω
div1.sense: to do ill, play the knave, Ar.: to manage oneʼs affairs ill, Xen.
trans. to do mischief to, maltreat, Xen.

div1.head: κακοποιΐα
div1.sense: evil-doing, injury, Isocr.

div1.head: κακοποιός
div1.sense: ill-doing, mischievous, Pind.

div1.head: κακοπονητικός
div1.sense: unfit for toil, Arist.

div1.head: κακόποτμος
div1.sense: ill-fated, ill-starred, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: κακόπους
div1.sense: with bad feet, Xen.

div1.head: κακοπραγέω
div1.sense: to fare ill, fail in an enterprise, to be in ill plight, Thuc.

div1.head: κακοπραγία
div1.sense: misadventure, failure, Thuc.

div1.head: κακορραφία
div1.sense: contrivance of ill, mischievousness, Hom.

div1.head: κακορρήμων
div1.sense: telling of ill, ill omened, Aesch.

div1.head: κακορροθέω
div1.sense: to speak evil of, abuse, revile, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: κακόρρυπος
div1.sense: very filthy, Babr.

div1.head: κακόσιτος
div1.sense: eating badly, i. e. having no appetite, fastidious, Plat.

div1.head: κακοσκελής
div1.sense: with bad legs, Xen.

div1.head: κακοσκήνης
div1.sense: of a bad, mean body, Anth.

div1.head: κάκοσμος
div1.sense: ill-smelling, Ar.

div1.head: κακός
div1.sense: bad, Lat. malus:
of persons,
opp. to καλός, mean, ugly, Il.
opp. to ἀγαθός, ἐσθλός, ill-born, mean, ignoble, Hom., Soph.
craven, cowardly, base, Hom., Hdt., Attic

bad of his kind, i. e. worthless, sorry, poor, κ. ἀλήτης a sorry beggar, Od.; κ. ἰατρός Aesch.; κ. ναύτης Eur.; πάντα κακός bad in all things, Od.; κακὸς γνώμην Soph.;— c. inf., κακὸς μανθάνειν bad at learning, Soph.
in moral sense, bad, evil, wicked, Od., Attic
of death, disease, etc., bad, evil, baneful, Hom., Attic; of omens, bad, unlucky, Attic; of words, evil, abusive, Soph.; κ. ποιμήν, i. e. the storm, Aesch.

κακόν, and κακά, τά, as Subst. evil, ill, Od., Hdt., etc.; δυοῖν ἀποκρίνας κακοῖν having chosen the least of two evils, Soph.:— κακόν τι ἔρδειν or ῥέζειν τινά to do evil or ill to any one, Il.; κακὸν (or κακὰ ποιεῖν τινά Attic; κακὰ κακῶν τὰ κάκιστα, Soph.
κακά, τά, also evil words, reproaches, Hdt., Trag.
degrees of Comparison:
regul. comp. κακώτερος Od., Theocr.; but never in Attic:—irreg. κακίων, ον, with ῐ], Hom., [with ῑ], Attic
Sup. κάκιστος, Hom., etc.:—but χείρων, χείριστος, and ἥσσων, ἥκιστος, are also used as comp. and Sup.

adv. κακῶς, Lat. male, ill, Il., etc.:— κακῶς ποιεῖν τινα to treat one ill; κακῶς ποιεῖν τινά τι to do one any evil, Attic; κακῶς πράσσειν to fare ill, Aesch.; κακῶς πάσχειν Aesch.; κακῶς γίγνεταί τινι Hdt.; κακῶς ἐκπέφευγα, Lat. vix demum effugi, Dem.:—comp. κάκιον, Hdt., Attic: Sup. κάκιστα, Ar., etc.

in Compos., when added to words already signifying something bad, it increases this property, as in κακο-πινής· but added to words signifying something good, it implies too little of this property, as in κακό-δοξος. Once or twice it stands merely as an adj. agreeing with the Subst. with which it is compounded, as Κακοΐλιος for κακὴ Ἴλιος, κακόνυμφος for κακὸς νυμφίος.

div1.head: κακόσπλαγχνος
div1.sense: faint-hearted, Aesch.

div1.head: κακοσπορία
div1.sense: a bad sowing or crop, Anth.

div1.head: κακοστόμαχος
div1.sense: with bad stomach, fastidious, Anth.

div1.head: κακοστομέω
div1.sense: to speak evil of, abuse, τινά Soph.

div1.head: κακόστομος
div1.sense: evil-speaking, Eur.

div1.head: κακόστρωτος
div1.sense: ill-spread, i. e. rugged, Aesch.

div1.head: κακοσύνθετος
div1.sense: ill put together, Luc.

div1.head: κακόσχολος
div1.sense: using oneʼs leisure ill, indolent, lazy, Anth.
act., κ. πνοαί winds that wear men out in idleness, Aesch.

div1.head: κακοτεχνέω
div1.sense: to use base arts, act basely or meanly, deal fraudulently, Hdt., Dem.

div1.head: κακοτεχνία
div1.sense: bad art:
often in pl., forgeries, falsifications, Plat., Dem.
bad, base art, Luc.

div1.head: κακότεχνος
div1.sense: using bad arts or evil practices, artful, wily, δόλος Il.:—irreg. comp. -τεχνέστερος, as from κακοτεχνής, Luc.

div1.head: κακότης
div1.sense: badness:
of character, baseness, weakness, cowardice, Hom., Thuc.
badness, wickedness, Il., Hdt., Attic; κακότητι λειφθῆναι to have been absent by malice prepense, Hdt.
of condition, evil condition, distress, misery, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: κακοτροπία
div1.sense: badness of habits, mischievousness, maliciousness, wickedness, Thuc.

div1.head: κακοτυχέω
div1.sense: to be unfortunate, Thuc.

div1.head: κακοτυχής
div1.sense: unfortunate, Eur.

div1.head: κακουργέω
div1.sense: to do evil, work wickedness, deal basely, Eur., etc.; of a horse, to be vicious, Xen.
c. acc. pers. to do evil or mischief to one, to maltreat, Eur., Plat.:— to ravage a country, Thuc.: — to corrupt, falsify, τοὺς νόμους Dem.

div1.head: κακούργημα
div1.sense: an ill deed, fraud, Plat.

div1.head: κακουργία
div1.sense: the character and conduct of a κακοῦργος, ill-doing, wickedness, villany, malice, Od., Thuc., etc.; of a horse, viciousness, Xen.
in pl. malpractices, Xen.

div1.head: κακουργικός
div1.sense: malicious, Arist.

div1.head: κακοῦργος
div1.sense: doing ill, mischievous, knavish, villanous, γαστὴρ κακοεργός importunate, Od.; κακοῦργοι κλῶπες Hdt.; ἀνήρ Soph.; κακουργότατος λόγος Dem.
as Subst. a malefactor, criminal, Thuc., etc.: esp. a thief, robber, Dem.
doing harm, hurtful, c. gen., κ. εἶναί τινος to hurt any one, Xen.

div1.head: κακουχία
div1.sense: ill-treatment, ill-conduct, Plat.; χθονὸς κ. devastation of it, Aesch.

div1.head: κακόφατις
div1.sense: ill-sounding, ill-omened, Aesch.

div1.head: κακοφραδής
div1.sense: bad in counsel, Il.

div1.head: κακοφραδία
div1.sense: badness of counsel, folly, Hhymn.

div1.head: κακοφρονέω
div1.sense: to bear ill-will, Aesch.

div1.head: κακόφρων
div1.sense: ill-minded, malicious, malignant, Aesch., Eur.
imprudent, thoughtless, heedless, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: κακοφυής
div1.sense: of bad natural qualities, Plat.

div1.head: κακόχαρτος
div1.sense: rejoicing in menʼs ills, Hes.

div1.head: κακοχρήσμων
div1.sense: difficult to live with, Theocr.

div1.head: κακόψογος
div1.sense: malignantly blaming, Theogn.

div1.head: κακόω
div1.sense: of persons, to treat ill, maltreat, afflict, distress, Hom., Aesch., etc.:—Pass. to suffer ill, be in ill plight, be distressed, Hom., etc.; κεκακωμένος ἁλμῇ befouled with brine, Od.
of things, to spoil, ruin, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: κακύνω
div1.sense: to damage:—Pass., in moral sense, to become bad, behave badly, act basely, Eur.: of soldiers, to be mutinous, Xen.
Pass. also, to be reproached, Eur.

div1.head: κάκωσις
div1.sense: ill-treatment, τοῦ ἡγεμόνος Xen.: a distressing, harassing, τῶν πληρωμάτων of the crews, Thuc.
in Attic law, κακώσεως δίκη an action for ill-usage or neglect of parents, Dem., etc.
damage, misfortune, Thuc.

div1.head: κάλαθος
div1.sense: a vase-shaped basket, Lat. calathus, Ar.
a cooling-vessel, cooler, Virgil

div1.head: καλάϊνος
div1.sense: like the κάλαϊς, of changeful hue, of the cock, Anth.

div1.head: κάλαϊς
div1.sense: a precious stone of a greenish blue (v. κᾰλάϊνος), the turquoise or chrysolite, Plin.

div1.head: καλαμαία
div1.sense: a kind of grasshopper, Theocr.

div1.head: καλαμευτής
div1.sense: a reaper, mower, Theocr.
an angler, Anth.

div1.head: καλάμη
div1.sense: the stalk or straw of corn: metaph., αἶψα φυλόπιδος πέλεται κόρος, ἧς τε πλείστην μὲν καλάμην χθονὶ χαλκὸς ἔχευεν, ἄμητος δʼ ὀλίγιστος men are soon satiated with battle, where the sword throws much straw on the ground, and there is little harvest, i. e. much slaughter and little profit, Il.; κ. πυρῶν wheat-straw, Hdt.

the stalk without the ear, stubble; metaph. of an old man, καλάμην γέ σʼ ὀΐομαι εἰσορόωντα γιγνώσκειν thou mayst still, I ween, perceive the stubble (i. e. the residue) of former strength, Od.; ἀπὸ τῆς καλάμης τεκμαίρεσθαι to judge from the remains, Luc.

div1.head: καλαμητομία
div1.sense: a reaping, Anth.

div1.head: καλαμηφάγος
div1.sense: devouring stalks, i.e. cutting them, Anth.

div1.head: καλαμηφόρος
div1.sense: carrying reeds, Xen.

div1.head: καλάμινος
div1.sense: made of reed, Hdt.
made of cane, Hdt.

div1.head: καλαμίσκος
div1.sense: a bit of reed, used as a phial, Ar.

div1.head: καλαμίς
div1.sense: a reed fishing-rod, Anth.

div1.head: καλαμόεις
div1.sense: of reed, Eur.

div1.head: κάλαμος
div1.sense: a reed, larger than the δόναξ, Lat. arundo, being used for thatching houses or even for making the walls, Hdt.; for making mats or crates, Hdt., Thuc.
anything made of reed or cane:
a reed-pipe, flute, Pind., Eur.
a fishing-rod, Theocr.
an arrow, Hor.
collectively, of plants, which are neither bush (ὕλη) , nor tree (δένδρον) , Xen.
a mat of reeds, Plat.
= καλάμη, the stalk of wheat, Xen.

div1.head: καλαμοστεφής
div1.sense: covered with reed, Batr.

div1.head: καλαμόφθογγος
div1.sense: played on a reed, of tunes, Ar.

div1.head: καλαμώδης
div1.sense: like reed, full of reeds, Anth.

div1.head: καλάπους
div1.sense: a shoemakerʼs last, Plat.

div1.head: καλάσιρις
div1.sense: a long garment, with fringe at bottom, Hdt.
the Καλασίριες were a branch of the military caste in Egypt, Hdt.

div1.head: καλαῦροψ
div1.sense: a shepherdʼs staff, which was thrown so as to drive back the cattle to the herd, Il., Anth.

div1.head: καλέω
div1.sense: to call, summon, Hom., etc.: Mid. to call to oneself, Hom.
to call to a repast, to invite, Od.; κ. ἐπὶ δεῖπνον Hdt., Xen.; κληθέντες πρός τινα invited to his house, Dem.
to call on, invoke, τοὺς θεούς Hdt., Attic; so in Mid., Aesch., etc.:—but ἀράς, ἅς σοι καλοῦμαι curses, which I call down on thee, Soph.:—in Pass., of the god, to be invoked, Aesch.
as law-term, of the judge, to cite or summon before the court, Ar., Dem.; πρὶν τὴν ἐμὴν δίκην καλεῖσθαι before it is called on, Ar.
of the plaintiff, in Mid., καλεῖσθαί τινα to sue at law, Lat. vocare in jus, Ar., etc.

to call by name, to call, name, Il., Trag.:— ὄνομα καλεῖν τινά to call him a name (i. e. by name), Od.; so, without ὄνομα, τί νιν καλοῦσα τύχοιμʼ ἄν; Aesch.:—Pass., τύμβωι δʼ ὄνομα σῶι κεκλήσεται a name shall be given to thy tomb, Eur.

in perf. pass. κέκλημαι, to have received a name, to bear it, often = εἰμί, to be, οὕνεκα σὴ παράκοιτις κέκλημαι because I am thy wife, Il.; πόσις κεκλημένος εἴη were to be my spouse, Od.;—rarely in pres., ἐμὸς γαμβρὸς καλέεσθαι Il.
poet. Ἀλεισίου ἔνθα κολώνη κέκληται where is the hill called the hill of Aleisios, Il.
foll. by a dependent clause, καλεῖ με, πλαστὸς ὡς εἴην πατρί, i. e. καλεῖ με πλαστόν, calls me a supposititious son, Soph.

div1.head: καλήμερος
div1.sense: with fortunate days, Anth.

div1.head: καλήτωρ
div1.sense: a crier, Lat. calator, Il.

div1.head: καλιά
div1.sense: a wooden dwelling, hut, barn, Hes.: a birdʼs nest, Theocr.

div1.head: καλιάς
div1.sense: a hut, Anth.: a chapel, Plut.

div1.head: καλινδέομαι
div1.sense: Dep., to lie rolling about or wallowing, Lat. volutari, Hdt., Thuc.:— hence, to be constantly engaged in a thing, Lat. versari in aliqua re, Xen., etc.

div1.head: κάλλαιον
div1.sense: a cockʼs comb: pl. κάλλαια, τά, the wattles, Lat. palea, Ar.

div1.head: καλλιβλέφαρος
div1.sense: with beautiful eyelids, beautiful-eyed, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιβόας
div1.sense: beautiful-sounding, Soph., Ar.

div1.head: καλλίβοτρυς
div1.sense: beautiful-clustering, Soph.

div1.head: καλλίβωλος
div1.sense: with fine, rich soil, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιγάληνος
div1.sense: beautiful in calm, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίγαμος
div1.sense: happy in marriage, Anth.

div1.head: καλλιγένεια
div1.sense: bearer of a fair offspring, name of Demeter at the Thesmophoria, Ar.

div1.head: καλλιγέφυρος
div1.sense: with beautiful bridges, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιγύναιξ
div1.sense: with beautiful women, only in the obl. cases, Ἑλλάδα καλλιγύναικα Ἀχαιΐδα κ., Σπάρτην κ. Hom.

div1.head: καλλιδίνης
div1.sense: beautifully flowing, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίδιφρος
div1.sense: with beautiful chariot, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιδόναξ
div1.sense: with beautiful reeds, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιεπέομαι
div1.sense: Mid. to say in fine phrases, Thuc.: to use fine language, Arist.:—Pass., λόγοι κεκαλλιεπημένοι ῥήμασί τε καὶ ὀνόμασι decked out with verbs and nouns, Plat.

div1.head: καλλιερέω
div1.sense: to have favourable signs in a sacrifice, to obtain good omens for an undertaking, Lat. litare, perlitare, Xen.; so in Mid., Hdt., etc.
c. acc. to sacrifice with good omens, Theocr.:—so in Mid., Ar.

of the offering, to give good omens, be favourable, καλλιρῆσαι οὐκ ἐδύνατο τὰ ἱρά the sacrifices would not give good omens, Hdt.; ὥς σφι ἐκαλλιρέετο τὰ ἱρά Hdt.; also c. inf., οὐκ ἐκαλλίρεε διαβαίνειν μιν the sacrifices were not favourable for his crossing, Hdt.:—in Mid., ὡς οὐδὲ ταῦτα ἐκαλλιερεῖτο Xen.

div1.head: καλλιζυγής
div1.sense: beautifully yoked, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίζωνος
div1.sense: with beautiful girdles, Hom.

div1.head: καλλίθριξ
div1.sense: with beautiful manes, of horses, Hom.; of sheep, with fine wool, Od.

div1.head: καλλιθυτέω
div1.sense: to offer in auspicious sacrifice, κάπρον Anth.

div1.head: καλλίκαρπος
div1.sense: with beautiful fruit, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: καλλίκερως
div1.sense: with beautiful horns, Anth.

div1.head: Καλλικολώνη
div1.sense: fair-hill, a place near Troy, Il.

div1.head: καλλίκομος
div1.sense: beautiful-haired, of women, Hom., Hes., Ar.

div1.head: καλλικρήδεμνος
div1.sense: with beautiful headband, Od.

div1.head: καλλιλογέω
div1.sense: Mid. to use specious phrases, Luc.

div1.head: καλλίμορφος
div1.sense: beautifully shaped or formed, Eur.

div1.head: κάλλιμος
div1.sense: beautiful, Od.

div1.head: καλλίναος
div1.sense: beautiful-flowing, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίνικος
div1.sense: with glorious victory, κῦδος κ. the glory of noble victory, Pind.: c. gen., τῶν ἐχθρῶν κ. triumphant over oneʼs enemies, Eur.
adorning or ennobling victory, ὕμνος, ᾠδή, μοῦσα Pind., Eur.:— τὸ καλλίνικον the glory of victory, Pind.; so, καλλίνικος (sub. ὕμνος) Pind.

div1.head: κάλλιον
div1.sense: neut. of καλλίων, used as adv., v. καλός C.

div1.head: Καλλιόπη
div1.sense: Calliope, the beautiful-voiced, chief of the nine Muses, the Epic Muse, Hes., Hhymn.: also Καλλιόπεια, Anth.

div1.head: καλλίπαις
div1.sense: with beautiful children, blessed with fair children, Aesch., Eur.
a beautiful child, Eur.; v. καλλι- 2.

div1.head: καλλιπάρηος
div1.sense: beautiful-cheeked, Hom.

div1.head: καλλιπάρθενος
div1.sense: with beautiful nymphs, Eur.; δέρη κ. necks of beauteous maidens, Eur.

div1.head: καλλι-
div1.sense: the first part in compds., where the notion of beautiful is added to the simple notion: καλο- is later and less common.
sometimes like a mere adj. with its Subst., as καλλίπαις καλὴ παῖς.

div1.head: καλλιπέδιλος
div1.sense: with beautiful sandals, Hhymn.

div1.head: καλλίπεπλος
div1.sense: with beautiful robe, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: καλλιπέτηλος
div1.sense: with beautiful leaves, Anth.

div1.head: καλλίπηχυς
div1.sense: gen. εως, with beautiful elbow, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιπλόκαμος
div1.sense: with beautiful locks, Hom., Eur.

div1.head: καλλίπλουτος
div1.sense: adorned with riches, Pind.

div1.head: καλλίπολις
div1.sense: fair-city, Plat.

div1.head: καλλιπόταμος
div1.sense: of beautiful rivers, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίπρῳρος
div1.sense: with beautiful prow, Eur.:— metaph. with beautiful face, beautiful, Aesch.

div1.head: καλλίπυλος
div1.sense: with beautiful gates, Anth.

div1.head: καλλίπυργος
div1.sense: with beautiful towers, Eur.; κ. σοφία high-towering, Ar.

div1.head: καλλίπωλος
div1.sense: with beautiful steeds, Pind.

div1.head: καλλιρέεθρος
div1.sense: beautiful-flowing, Od., Eur.

div1.head: καλλιρρημοσύνη
div1.sense: elegance of language, Luc.
braggart language, Luc.

div1.head: καλλίρροος
div1.sense: beautiful flowing, Hom., Aesch.:—metaph. of the flute, Pind.— Fem. Καλλιρόη, one of the Oceanids, Hhymn., Hes.:— but Καλλιρρόη, also, a spring at Athens, later Ἐννεάκρουνος (but now again Καλλιρρόη) , Thuc.

div1.head: καλλιστάδιος
div1.sense: with a fine race-course, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιστεῖον
div1.sense: the prize of beauty, Eur.
in pl. = ἀριστεῖα, the meed of valour, Soph.

div1.head: καλλίστευμα
div1.sense: exceeding beauty, Eur.
the first-fruits of beauty or the most beautiful, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιστεύω
div1.sense: to be the most beautiful, Hdt., Eur.; c. gen., καλλιστεύσει πασέων τῶν γυναικῶν Hdt.:—also in Mid., δῶρʼ ἃ καλλιστεύεται Eur.

div1.head: καλλιστέφανος
div1.sense: beautiful-crowned, Hhymn., Eur.

div1.head: κάλλιστος
div1.etym: Sup. of καλός: v. καλός B.

div1.head: Καλλιστώ
div1.sense: most-beautiful, daughter of Lycaon, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίσφυρος
div1.sense: beautiful-ankled, Hom.

div1.head: καλλίτεκνος
div1.sense: with fair children, Plut., Luc.

div1.head: καλλιτεχνία
div1.sense: beauty of workmanship, Plut.

div1.head: καλλίτοξος
div1.sense: with beautiful bow, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιφεγγής
div1.sense: beautiful-shining, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίφθογγος
div1.sense: beautiful-sounding, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίφλοξ
div1.sense: auspiciously burning, Eur.

div1.head: καλλιφωνία
div1.sense: beauty of sound, Luc.

div1.head: καλλίφωνος
div1.sense: with a fine voice, Plat.

div1.head: καλλίχορος
div1.etym: I, Epic for καλλίχωρος, II from χόρος
div1.sense: with beautiful places, as εὐρύχορος for εὐρύχωρος, epith. of large cities, Od., Pind.
of or for beautiful dances, Eur., Ar.:— ὁ κ. a spring near Eleusis, the fount of goodly dances, Hhymn., Eur.
beautiful in the dance, of Apollo, Eur.

div1.head: καλλίων
div1.etym: comp. of καλός: v. καλός B.

div1.head: καλλονή
div1.sense: beauty, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: κάλλος
div1.sense: beauty, Hom., etc.:— ἐς κάλλος with an eye to beauty, so as to set off her beauty, Eur.; but, εἰς κ. ζῆν for pleasure, Xen.
of persons, a beauty, Xen., Luc.
in pl. also rich garments and stuffs, Aesch., Plat.; κάλλεα κηροῦ beautiful works of wax, i. e. honeycombs, Anth.

div1.head: κάλλυντρον
div1.sense: an implement for cleaning, broom, Plut.

div1.head: καλλύνω
div1.sense: to beautify: metaph. to gloss over, Soph.
Mid. to pride oneself in a thing, Plat.

div1.head: καλλωπίζω
div1.sense: properly, to make the face beautiful; hence, to beautify, embellish, Plat.:—Pass., κεκαλλωπισμέναι τὸ χρῶμα, i. e. painted, Xen.
Mid. to adorn oneself, make oneself fine or smart, Plat.: metaph. to pride oneself in or on a thing, τινι or ἐπί τινι Plat.:—absol. to make a display, shew off, of a horse, Xen.
to be coy, play the prude, τινι or πρός τινα towards another, Plat.; c. inf., κ. παραιτεῖσθαι to affect to deprecate, Plut.

div1.head: καλλώπισμα
div1.sense: ornament, embellishment, Plat.

div1.head: καλλωπισμός
div1.sense: an adorning oneself, making a display, Plat., Xen.
ornamentation, εἰς κ. for ornament, Xen.; καλλωπισμοὶ περὶ τὸ σῶμα Plat.

div1.head: καλοδιδάσκαλος
div1.sense: a teacher of virtue, NTest.

div1.head: καλοκἀγαθία
div1.sense: the character and conduct of a καλὸς κἀγαθός, nobleness, goodness, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: καλοκἀγαθικός
div1.sense: beseeming a καλὸς κἀγαθός, honourable:—adv. -κῶς, Plut.
inclined to καλοκἀγαθία, Plut.

div1.head: καλοκἀγαθός
div1.etym: in good writers written divisim καλὸς κἀγαθός,
div1.sense: beautiful and good, noble and good, used in earlier times of the nobles or gentlemen, Lat. optimates, Hdt., Attic; later, καλὸς κἀγαθός was a perfect man, a man as he should be, also applied to qualities and actions, Plat., Xen.; to an army, Xen., etc.

div1.head: κᾶλον
div1.sense: wood, but only used in pl. κᾶλα, logs for burning (prob. from καίω) , Hhymn.: seasoned wood, for joinerʼs work, καμπύλα κ. Hes.

div1.head: καλοπέδιλα
div1.sense: wooden shoes, used to keep a cow still while milking, Theocr.

div1.head: καλοποιέω
div1.sense: to do good, NTest.

div1.head: καλός
div1.sense: beautiful, beauteous, fair, Lat. pulcher, of outward form, Hom., etc.; καλὸς δέμας beautiful of form, Od.; so, εἶδος κάλλιστος Xen.; καλὸς τὸ σῶμα Xen.; c. inf., κ. εἰσοράασθαι Hom.
τὸ καλόν, like κάλλος, beauty, Eur., etc.: τὰ καλά the decencies, proprieties, elegancies of life, Hdt., etc.

in reference to use, beautiful, fair, good, κ. λιμήν Od.; καλὸς εἴς τι Xen.; πρός τι Plat.; c. inf., κάλλιστος τρέχειν Xen.;—esp. in the foll. phrases, ἐν καλῷ τόπῳ in a good place, Thuc.; ἐν καλῷ τοῦ κόλπου, τῆς πόλεως Xen.; ἐν κ. (sub. χρόνῳ) , in good time, in season, Eur.:—so, καλόν ἐστι, c. inf., Soph.
of sacrifices, good, auspicious, Aesch., etc.
in moral sense, beautiful, noble, καλόν ἐστι c. inf., Hom., etc.; καλὰ ἔργματα noble deeds, Pind., etc.
τὸ καλόν moral beauty, virtue, opp. to τὸ αἰσχρόν (Ciceroʼs honestum and turpe), Xen., Plat.
in Attic not seldom ironically, like Lat. praeclarus, admirable, specious, fair, κ. γὰρ οὑμὸς βίοτος, ὥστε θαυμάσαι Soph.; μετʼ ὀνομάτων καλῶν Thuc.
Degrees of comp.: comp. καλλίων (short ι) ον, Sup. κάλλιστος, η, ον, Hom., etc.
adv.:— καλόν as adv., καλὸν ἀείδειν, etc., Hom.; so καλά Il.; τὸ καλόν Theocr.
regul. adv. καλῶς, mostly in moral sense, well, rightly, Od.; καλῶς ζῆν, τεθνηκέναι, etc., Soph., etc.; οὐ καλῶς ταρβεῖς Soph.; often in phrase καλῶς καὶ εὖ, καλῶς τε καὶ εὖ Plat.
of good fortune, well, happily, κ. πράσσειν εὖ πρ. to fare well, Aesch., etc.; κ. ἔχειν to be well, Aesch.; κ. ἔχει, c. inf., ʼtis well to . . , Xen.
καλῶς πάνυ, right well, κ. ἔξοιδα Soph.; so in comp., κάλλιον εἰδέναι Plat.; and in Sup. κάλλιστα, Soph., etc.
κ. ποιῶν, as adv., rightly, deservedly, Lat. merito, κ. ποιῶν ἀπόλλυται Ar.

in answers, to approve the words of the former speaker, well said! Lat. euge, Eur., Dem.:—but, also, to decline an offer courteously or ironically, thank you! Lat. benigne, Ar.; and in Sup., κάλλιστʼ, ἐπαινῶ Ar.
ironically, finely, Lat. belle, Soph., Eur.
Quantity: ᾱ in Epic Poets: α in Attic: in later Poets α or ᾱ, as the verse requires.

div1.head: κάλπις
div1.sense: a vessel for drawing water, a pitcher or ewer, Od., Attic:— an urn for drawing lots or collecting votes, Anth., Luc.: — a cinerary urn, Anth.

div1.head: κάλτιος
div1.sense: Sicil. form of Lat. calceus, a shoe, Plut.

div1.head: καλύβη
div1.sense: a hut, cabin, cell, Lat. tugurium, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
a cover, screen, Anth.

div1.head: καλυκοστέφανος
div1.sense: crowned with flower-buds, Anth.

div1.head: καλυκῶπις
div1.sense: like a budding flower in face, i. e. blushing, roseate, Hhymn.

div1.head: κάλυμμα
div1.sense: a head-covering used by women, a hood or veil, Il.; worn by brides, Aesch.; a covering put over the face of the dead, Soph.
a grave, Anth.

div1.head: κάλυξ
div1.sense: a covering, used only of flowers and fruit:
the shell or pod of plants, Hdt.; κάλυκος ἐν λοχεύμασι, i. e. when the fruit is setting, Aesch.
the calyx of a flower, a bud, a rose-bud, Hhymn., Theocr.
in Il. 18. 401, κάλυκες seem to be earrings like flower-cups.

div1.head: καλύπτειρα
div1.sense: a veil, Anth.

div1.head: καλυπτός
div1.sense: put round so as to cover, enfolding, enveloping, Soph.

div1.head: καλύπτρα
div1.sense: a womanʼs veil, Hom., Aesch.:—metaph., δνοφερὰ κ. the dark veil of night, Aesch.
of land given to queens as veil-money (cf. ζώνη I. 2), Plat.
the cover or lid of a quiver, Hdt.

div1.head: καλύπτω
div1.sense: to cover with a thing, παρδαλέηι μετάφρενον κάλυψεν Il.; νυκτὶ καλύψας Il.: simply, to cover, μέλαν δέ ἑ κῦμα κάλυψεν Il.; πέτρον χεὶρ ἐκάλυψεν his hand covered, grasped a stone, Il.; of death, τέλος θανάτοιο κάλυψεν ὀφθαλμούς Il., etc.; of grief, τὸν δʼ ἄχεος νεφέλη ἐκάλυψε Il.; κ. χθονὶ γυῖα, i. e. to be buried, Pind.; also, χθονί, τάφωι κ. to bury another, Aesch.:—Mid. to cover or veil oneself, Hom.:—Pass., ἀσπίδι κεκαλυμμένος ὤμους Il.; ἐν χλαίνηι κεκαλ. Il., etc.
like κρύπτω, to cover or conceal; κ. καρδίαι τι Soph.; Pass., κεκαλυμμένοι ἵππωι concealed in the horse, Od.
to cover with dishonour, throw a cloud over, σὺ μὴ κάλυπτε Ἀθήνας Soph.
to put over as a covering, Lat. circumdare, οἱ πέπλοιο πτύγμʼ ἐκάλυψεν Il.; οἱ ἄσιν καθύπερθε καλύψω I will put mud over him, Il.; ἀμφὶ Μενοιτιάδηι σάκος εὐρὺ καλύψας Il.

div1.head: καλχαίνω
div1.sense: properly, to make purple: metaph. to make dark and troublous like a stormy sea, to ponder deeply, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: Κάλχας
div1.sense: Calchas the Greek seer at Troy, properly the searcher.

div1.head: καλῴδιον
div1.sense: a small cord, Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: κάλως
div1.sense: a reefing rope, reef, Od., where the κάλοι are distinguished from πόδες (sheets) and ὑπέραι (braces); κάλως ἐξῑέναι to let out the reefs, i. e. to set all sail, Eur.; metaph., ἐχθροὶ γὰρ ἐξίασι πάντα δὴ κάλων are letting out every reef, i. e. using every effort, Eur.; φόνιον ἐξίει κάλων give a loose to slaughter, Eur.; so, πάντα ἐξιέναι κάλων Ar.
generally, a rope, line, κάλων κατιέναι to let down a sounding-line, Hdt.
a cable, Hdt.; πρυμνήτης κ. a stern cable, Eur.; ἀπὸ κάλω παραπλεῖν to be towed along shore, Thuc.

div1.head: καλωστρόφος
div1.sense: a rope-maker, Plut.

div1.head: καμάκινος
div1.sense: made of reed or cane, Xen.

div1.head: κάμαξ
div1.sense: a vine-pole, vine-prop, Il., Hes.
the shaft of a spear, Aesch., Eur.
the tiller of the rudder, Luc.

div1.head: καμάρα
div1.sense: Lat. camera, anything with an arched cover, a covered carriage, Hdt.

div1.head: καμασῆνες
div1.sense: a kind of fish, Anth.

div1.head: καματηρός
div1.sense: toilsome, troublesome, wearisome, Hhymn.:— tiring, exhausting, Luc.
pass. bowed down with toil, broken down, worn out, Hdt.

div1.head: κάματος
div1.sense: toil, trouble, labour, Od., Soph., Eur.
the effects of toil, distress, weariness, Hom.; ὕπνῳ καὶ καμάτῳ ἀρημένος (so Hor., ludo fatigatumque somno), Od.
that which is earned by toil, ἡμέτερος κάματος our hard-won earnings, Od.; ἀλλότριος κάματος the earnings of other menʼs toil, Hes.
the result of labour, a work, a thing wrought by the lathe, Anth.

div1.head: καματώδης
div1.sense: toilsome, wearisome, Hes., Pind.

div1.head: κάμηλος
div1.sense: a camel, Hdt., etc.; κ. ἀμνός a camel-lamb, i. e. young camel, Ar.
ἡ κ. (like ἡ ἵππος) the camels in an army, as one might say the camelry, camel-brigade, Hdt.

div1.head: καμινευτήρ
div1.sense: αὐλὸς κ. the pipe of a smithʼs bellows, Anth.

div1.head: καμινεύω
div1.sense: to heat in a furnace, Arist.

div1.head: κάμινος
div1.sense: an oven, furnace, kiln, for baking, smelting metals, for burning bricks, Hdt.

div1.head: καμινώ
div1.sense: a furnace-woman, Od.

div1.head: καμμονίη
div1.sense: the reward of endurance, Il.

div1.head: κάμμορος
div1.sense: subject to destiny, i. e. ill-fated, Od.

div1.head: κάμνω
div1.sense: trans. to work of smithʼs work, σκῆπτρον, τὸ μὲν Ἥφαιστος κάμε which he wrought, Il.; κ. νῆας Od.
Mid. to win by toil, τὰς (sc. γυναῖκας) αὐτοὶ καμόμεσθα Il.
to work or till by labour, Od.

intr. to work, labour, Thuc.:—then, to be weary, ἀνδρὶ δὲ κεκμηῶτι μένος οἶνος ἀέξει Il.; οὐδέ τι γυῖα κάμνει nor is he weary in limb, Il.; περὶ δʼ ἔγχεϊ χεῖρα καμεῖται he will have his hand weary in grasping the spear, Il.:—c. part., κάμνει πολεμίζων, ἐλαύνων is weary of fighting, rowing, Il.; οὐκ ἔκαμον τανύων I found no trouble in stringing the bow, i. e. did it without trouble, Od.; οὔτοι καμοῦμαι λέγουσα I shall never be tired of saying, Aesch., etc.
to be sick or ill, suffer under illness, οἱ κάμνοντες the sick, Hdt., etc.; so, κάμνειν νόσον Eur.; κ. τοὺς ὀφθαλμούς Hdt.
generally, to suffer, be distressed or afflicted, στρατοῦ καμόντος Aesch.; οὐ καμεῖ will not have to complain, Soph.; οὐκ ἴσον καμὼν ἐμοὶ λύπης not having borne an equal share of grief with me, Soph.
οἱ καμόντες (aor. part.) those who have done their work, Lat. defuncti, i. e. the dead, Hom.; so, κεκμηκότες Eur., Thuc.

div1.head: καμπή
div1.sense: a bending, winding, of a river, Hdt.
the turning in a race-course, turning-post, Ar.: metaph., μῦθον ἐς καμπὴν ἄγειν to bring a speech to its middle or turning point, Eur.; καμπὰς ποιεῖσθαι Plat.

div1.head: κάμπιμος
div1.sense: bent, turning, Eur.

div1.head: καμπτήρ
div1.sense: a bend, an angle, Xen.
the turning-point in the δίαυλος, the goal, Arist.: metaph., κ. πύματος lifeʼs last turn or course, Anth.

div1.head: κάμπτω
div1.sense: to bend, curve, ὄφρα ἰτὺν κάμψηι that he may bend it into a chariot-rail, Il.; γόνυ κ. to bend the knee so as to sit down and rest, Il.; οὐ κάμπτων γόνυ, i. e. never resting, Aesch.; so, κ. κῶλα Soph.; then, κάμπτειν alone, to sit down, rest, Soph.;—also, γόνυ κ. to bend the knee in worship, NTest.

to turn or guide a horse or chariot round the turning-post (καμπή II); hence, of the horse or chariot, κάμψαι διαύλου θάτερον κῶλον πάλιν to double the post (καμπτήρ) and return along the second half of the δίαυλος, Aesch.; κάμπτοντος ἵππου as the horse was turning, Soph.:—metaph., κ. βίον to make the last turn in the course of life, Soph.; κ. βίου τέλος Eur.
so also of seamen, to double a headland, ἄκρην κ. Hdt.; also, κ. περὶ ἄκραν Ar.; κ. κόλπον to wind round the bay, Hdt.
absol., πάλιν κ. to turn back, Eur.; ἐγγὺς τῶν ἐμῶν κάμπτεις φρενῶν thou comest near my meaning, Eur.
metaph., like Lat. flectere, κάμπτειν τινά to bend or bow one down, Pind.:—Pass. to be bowed down, Aesch., Thuc.; κάμπτομαι I submit, Plat.

div1.head: καμπύλος
div1.sense: bent, crooked, curved, of a bow, Il.; of wheels, Il.; of chariots, Il.

div1.head: καμψίπους
div1.sense: bending the foot, i. e. swift-running, Aesch.

div1.head: κανάβινος
div1.sense: of or for a block-figure, σῶμα κ. a body so lean as to be a mere skeleton, Anth.

div1.head: κάναβος
div1.sense: a wooden block round which artists moulded wax or clay, a block-figure.

div1.head: κάναθρον
div1.sense: a cane or wicker carriage, Xen.

div1.head: κάναστρον
div1.sense: a dish, Epic, Hom.

div1.head: καναχέω
div1.sense: to ring, clash, clang, of metal, Od.

div1.head: καναχηδά
div1.sense: with a sharp loud noise, of water, Hes.

div1.head: καναχή
div1.sense: a sharp sound: the ring or clang of metal, Il., Soph.; kanax6h dʼ 25hn 3hmi4onoi7in loud rang their tramp, Od.; ὀδόντων καναχή a gnashing of teeth, Il.; καναχὰ αὐλῶν the sound of flutes, Pind. (For Verb κανάσσω v. ἐγ-κανάσσω.)

div1.head: καναχής
div1.sense: of water, plashing, Aesch.

div1.head: καναχίζω
div1.sense: to ring, Hom.

div1.head: κάνδυς
div1.sense: a Median cloak with sleeves, Xen.

div1.head: κάνεον
div1.sense: a basket of reed or cane, a bread-basket, Lat. canistrum, Hom., Hdt., Attic; also made of metal, Hom.: —it was used for the sacred barley at sacrifices, ἔχεν οὐλὰς ἐν κανέῳ Od.

div1.head: κάνης
div1.sense: a mat of reeds such as the Athen. women took with them when they went out, Lex Solonis ap. Plut.

div1.head: κανηφορέω
div1.sense: to carry the sacred basket in procession, Ar.

div1.head: κανηφορία
div1.sense: the office of κανηφόρος, Plat.

div1.head: κανηφόρος
div1.sense: carrying a basket:— Κανηφόροι, αἱ, Basket-bearers, at Athens, maidens who carried on their heads baskets containing the sacred things used at the feasts of Demeter, Bacchus and Athena, Ar.

div1.head: κάνθαρος
div1.sense: Lat. cantharus, a beetle worshipped in Egypt, Aesch., etc.
a Naxian boat, Ar.
a mark or knot like a beetle, on the tongue of the Egyptian god Apis, Hdt.

div1.head: κανθήλια
div1.sense: Lat. clitellae, a pack-saddle, or the panniers at the sides of a pack-saddle, Ar.

div1.head: κανθήλιος
div1.sense: a large sort of ass for carrying burdens, a pack-ass, Xen., Plat., etc.

div1.head: κάνθων
div1.sense: a pack-ass, Ar., Anth.

div1.head: καννάβινος
div1.sense: hempen, of hemp, like it, Anth.

div1.head: κάνναβις
div1.sense: hemp, Hdt., etc.;—it was burnt, so as to medicate vapour-baths, Hdt.

div1.head: κάννα
div1.sense: a reed, Lat. canna: in pl. a reed-fence, railing, Ar.

div1.head: καννόμον
div1.sense: for κὰν (i. e. κατὰ) νόμον.

div1.head: κανονίζω
div1.sense: to measure by rule, Longin.: to regulate, square, Arist., Anth.

div1.head: κανονίς
div1.sense: a ruler, Anth.

div1.head: κἄν
div1.sense: crasis for καὶ ἄν or καὶ ἐάν

for καὶ ἄν, Hes., Attic; κακὸν δὲ κἂν ἐν ἡμέρᾳ γνοίης μιᾷ Soph.:—later, κἄν came to be used, even when the Verb in apodosi was of a tense that could not be joined with ἄν, as, κἂν εἰ πολλαὶ αἱ ἀρεταί εἰσιν, for ὦσι, Plat.
for καὶ ἄν or καὶ ἐάν, and if, even if, although, Soph., Ar., etc.

div1.head: Κάνωβος
div1.sense: Canopus, a town in lower Egypt, Hdt., etc.; famed for its temple of Serapis, who was called Κανωβίτης, Anth.:—the Westernmost mouth of the Nile was called the Κανωβικὸν στόμα, Hdt.

div1.head: κανών
div1.sense: any straight rod or bar:
in Hom. the κανόνες of a shield seem to have been two rods running across the hollow of the shield, through which the arm was passed.
a rod used in weaving, the shuttle or quill, by which the threads of the woof (πηνίον) were passed between those of the warp (μίτος) , Il.
a rule used by masons or carpenters, Eur., Xen., etc.
a ruler, Anth.
metaph., ἀκτὶς ἡλίου, κανὼν σαφής, Miltonʼs "long-levelled rule of light, " Eur.
the beam or tongue of the balance, Anth.
in pl. the keys or stops of the flute, Anth.
metaph., like Lat. regula, norma, a rule, standard of excellence, Eur.;—in Chronology, κανόνες χρονικοί were chief epochs or eras, Plut.

div1.head: κάπετος
div1.sense: a ditch, trench, Il.:— a hole, grave, Il., Soph.

div1.head: καπηλεία
div1.sense: retail trade, tavern-keeping, Plat.

div1.head: καπηλεῖον
div1.sense: the shop of a κάπηλος, esp. a tavern, Lat. caupona, Ar.

div1.head: καπηλεύω
div1.sense: to be a retail-dealer, Hdt.; διʼ ἀψύχου βορᾶς σίτοις καπήλευʼ drive a trade, chaffer with your vegetable food, Eur.

c. acc. to sell by retail, Hdt.:—metaph., καπηλεύειν μάχην to make a trade of war, Lat. cauponari bellum, Aesch.; καπηλεύουσα τὸν βίον playing tricks with life, corrupting it, Anth.; κ. τὸν λόγον τοῦ θεοῦ NTest.

div1.head: καπηλικός
div1.sense: of or for a retail dealer: —ἡ καπηλική (sc. τέχνη) = καπηλεία, Plat.
like a petty trader, knavish, Anth.:—adv., καπηλικῶς ἔχειν to be vamped up for sale, Ar.

div1.head: καπηλίς
div1.sense: Lat. copa, Ar.

div1.head: κάπηλος
div1.sense: a retail-dealer, huckster, hawker, peddlar, higgler, Lat. institor, Hdt., Attic; opp. to the merchant (ἔμπορος) , Xen., etc.; applied to Darius because of his finance-regulations, Hdt.:— κ. ἀσπίδων, ὅπλων a dealer in . . , Ar.
a tavern-keeper, publican, Lat. caupo, Ar., etc.
metaph., κ. πονηρίας a dealer in petty roguery, Dem.

div1.head: κάπη
div1.sense: a crib for the food of cattle, manger, Hom.

div1.head: καπίθη
div1.sense: a measure containing two χοίνικες, Xen.

div1.head: καπνίζω
div1.sense: to make smoke, i. e. to make a fire, Il.
to smoke, blacken with smoke, Dem.
intr. to be black with smoke, Ar.

div1.head: κάπνισμα
div1.sense: incense, Anth.

div1.head: καπνοδόκη
div1.sense: properly, a smoke-receiver, i. e. a hole in the roof for the smoke to pass through, Hdt.

div1.head: καπνόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be turned into smoke, burnt to ashes, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: καπνός
div1.sense: smoke, Hom., etc.; proverb., καπνοῦ σκιά shadow of smoke, of things worth nothing, Soph.; περὶ καπνοῦ στενολεσχεῖν to quibble about smoke, Ar.; γραμμάτων καπνοί learned trifles, Eur.

div1.head: Καππαδόκαι
div1.sense: the Cappadocians, notorious as knaves and cowards, Hdt.

div1.head: καππαδοκίζω
div1.sense: to favour the Cappadocians,Hdt.:—Pass. to play the Cappadocian, Anth.

div1.head: κάππα
div1.sense: Κ, κ, κάππα, τό, indecl., tenth letter in Gr. alphabet: as numeral κ 20, but κ, 20, 000:— κ is the tenuis guttural mute, related to the medial γ and the aspir. χ. Changes of κ in the Gr. dialects:
Ionic κ replaces χ, as κιθών δέκομαι κύθρη for χιτών δέχομαι χύτρα:—it represents π, as κου κοτε κως, etc., for που ποτε πως, etc.; so, ἴσκε ἔσπεν, ἵππος Lat. equus.
Doric κ is interchanged with τ, as ὅκα ἄλλοκα τῆνος for ὅτε ἄλλοτε κεῖνος.

div1.head: κάππαρις
div1.sense: the caper-plant, or its fruit, the caper, Lat. capparis, Arist.

div1.head: καπποφόρος
div1.sense: marked with a κάππα, Luc.

div1.head: καππυρίζω
div1.sense: to catch, take fire, aor1 part. καππυρίσασα Theocr.

div1.head: καπράω
div1.sense: metaph. to be lewd or lecherous, Ar.

div1.head: κάπριος
div1.sense: a wild boar, Il.; also, σῦς κάπριος Il.
as adj. κάπριος, ον, like a wild boar, Hdt.

div1.head: κάπρος
div1.sense: the boar, wild boar, Lat. aper, Il., etc.; also, σῦς κάπρος Il.

div1.head: καπροφόνος
div1.sense: killing wild boars, Anth.

div1.head: κάπτω
div1.sense: to gulp down, Ar., etc.: cf. κεκαφηώς.

div1.head: καπυρός
div1.sense: dried by the air, dry, Theocr.
act. drying, parching, Theocr.
metaph. of sound, καπυρὸν γελᾶν to laugh loud, Anth.; κ. στόμα a loud, clear-sounding voice, Theocr., Mosch.; κ. συρίζειν to play clearly on the syrinx, Luc.

div1.head: καραβοπρόσωπος
div1.sense: with the face of a κάραβος, Luc.

div1.head: κάραβος
div1.sense: the stag-beetle, Arist.

div1.head: καραδοκέω
div1.sense: to watch with outstretched head, i. e. to watch eagerly or anxiously, Hdt., Eur., Xen.: —also, κ. εἴς τινα to look eagerly at one, Ar.

div1.head: καράκαλλον
div1.sense: a hood, Lat. caracalla, Anth.

div1.head: καρανιστήρ
div1.sense: beheading, capital, Aesch.

div1.head: κάρανος
div1.sense: a chief, Xen.

div1.head: καρανόω
div1.sense: to achieve, Aesch.

div1.head: κάρα
div1.sense: the head, Il., etc.
the head or top of anything, as of a mountain, Hes.; the edge or brim of a cup, Soph.
in Attic Poets, it is used like κεφαλή, periphr. for a person, Οἰδίπου κάρα, i. e. Οἰδίπους, Soph.; ὦ κασίγνητον κ., for ὦ κασίγνητε, Soph., etc.

div1.head: καρατομέω
div1.sense: to cut off the head, behead, Eur.

div1.head: καράτομος
div1.sense: beheaded, Eur.; κ. ἐρημία νεανίδων, i. e. their slaughter, Eur.
cut off from the head, κ. χλιδαί oneʼs shorn locks, Soph.

div1.head: κάρβανος
div1.sense: outlandish, foreign, Aesch.

div1.head: καρβάτιναι
div1.sense: shoes of undressed leather, brogues, Xen.

div1.head: κάρδαμον
div1.sense: a kind of cress, Lat. nasturtium, or its seed, which was eaten like mustard by the Persians, Xen.; in pl. cresses, Ar.;—metaph., βλέπειν κάρδαμα, i. e. look sharp and stinging, Ar.

div1.head: καρδία
div1.sense: the heart, ἐν στέρνοισι κραδίη πατάσσει Il.; κραδίη ἔξω στήθεος ἐκθρώσκει, of one panic-stricken, Il.; οἰδάνεται κραδίη χόλῳ Il., etc.; ἐκ τῆς καρδίας φιλεῖν Ar.; τἀπὸ καρδίας λέγειν, Lat. ex animo, to speak freely, Eur.
the stomach, Thuc.

div1.head: καρδιογνώστης
div1.sense: knower of hearts, NTest.

div1.head: καρδιόδηκτος
div1.sense: gnawing the heart, Aesch.

div1.head: καρδιουλκέω
div1.sense: to draw the heart out of the victim, Luc.

div1.head: κάρδοπος
div1.sense: a kneading-trough, Ar.

div1.head: καρηκομόωντες
div1.sense: with hair on the head, long-haired, of the Achaians, who let all their hair grow (whereas the Abantes, who wore theirs long only at the back of the head, were called ὄπιθεν κομόωντες) , Il.

div1.head: κάρηνον
div1.sense: the head, mostly in pl., ἀνδρῶν κάρηνα, periphr. for ἄνδρες, Il.; νεκύων κ., for νέκυες, Od.; βοῶν κ., as we say, so many head of cattle, Il.
metaph. of mountain- peaks, Οὐλύμποιο κ. Il.; and of towns, a citadel, Il.

div1.head: Καρικός
div1.sense: Carian, Soph.; Κ. αὐλήματα dirges, Ar.

div1.head: Καρίνη
div1.sense: a Carian woman, Phan. ap. Plut.

div1.head: καρίς
div1.sense: a shrimp or prawn, Ar.

div1.head: καρκαίρω
div1.sense: to quake under the feet of men and horses, Lat. tremere, Il. (Formed from the sound.)

div1.head: καρκίνος
div1.sense: a crab, Lat. cancer, Batr., Ar., Plat.:—proverb., οὔποτε ποιήσεις τὸν καρκίνον ὀρθὰ βαδίζειν Ar.
a pair of tongs, Anth.: καρκίνα compasses, Anth.

div1.head: καρκινόχειρες
div1.sense: with crabʼs claws for hands, Luc.

div1.head: Κάρνεια
div1.sense: a festival held in honour of Apollo Κάρνειος by the Spartans, during nine days of the Attic month Metageitnion, called by them Καρνεῖος μήν, Eur., Thuc.

div1.head: Κάρπαθος
div1.sense: Carpathus, an island between Crete and Rhodes, Hom.

div1.head: καρπαία
div1.sense: a mimic dance of the Thessalians, Xen.

div1.head: καρπάλιμος
div1.sense: swift, Lat. rapidus, Il.: adv. -μως, swiftly, rapidly, Il.
in Pind., γένυες κ. eager jaws.

div1.head: Κάρ
div1.sense: a Carian, Il., etc.; fem. Κάειρα, Il.:—the Carians hired themselves out as mercenaries, and were used to spare the lives of the citizen-soldiers; hence, ἐν τῷ Καρὶ κινδυνεύειν to make the risk, not with oneʼs own person, but with a Carian, Lat. experimentum facere in corpore vili, Eur.

div1.head: κάρ
div1.sense: hair cut off, a lock of hair, (cf. κείρω, ἀκαρής) , τίω δέ μιν ἐν καρὸς αἰσῃ I value him but at a hairʼs worth, flocci eum facio, Il.
also = κάρα, κάρη, head, ἐπὶ κάρ head- long, Il.

div1.head: καρπίζω
div1.sense: to make fruitful, fertilise, Eur.

div1.head: κάρπιμος
div1.sense: fruit-bearing, fruitful, Aesch., Eur., etc.:— κάρπιμα, τά, fruit-trees or corn-fields, Ar.; κάρπιμα ἀγαθά property that yields a produce, opp. to ἄκαρπα, Arist.:—metaph., τῶν ξένων τοὺς κ. rich foreigners from whom money can be wrung, Ar.

div1.head: καρπογένεθλος
div1.sense: fruit-producing, Anth.

div1.head: καρπός
div1.sense: fruit, καρπὸς ἀρούρης, i. e. corn, Il.; so, κ. Δήμητρος Hdt., etc.; of trees, Od., etc.
generally, produce, returns, profits, Hdt., etc.; οἱ καρποὶ ἐκ τῶν ἀγελῶν the produce of the herds, Xen.

of actions, fruit, result, profit, εἰ καρπὸς ἔσται θεσφάτοισι if his oracles shall bear fruit, i. e. be fulfilled, Aesch.; γλώσσης ματαίας κ., i. e. curses, Aesch.; κ. ἐπέων οὐ κατέφθινε, i. e. poesy, Pind.; κ. φρενῶν wisdom, Pind.

div1.head: καρπός2
div1.sense: the wrist, Hom., etc.

div1.head: καρποτόκος
div1.sense: bearing fruit, Anth.

div1.head: καρποφάγος
div1.sense: living on fruit, Arist.

div1.head: καρποφθόρος
div1.sense: spoiling fruit, Anth.

div1.head: καρποφορέω
div1.sense: to bear fruit, Xen.

div1.head: καρποφόρος
div1.sense: fruit-bearing, fruitful, of trees, Hdt., Xen.; of lands, Pind., Eur.; of Demeter, Ar.

div1.head: καρποφύλαξ
div1.sense: watcher of fruit, Anth.

div1.head: καρπόω
div1.sense: to bear fruit or bear as fruit, Aesch.
Mid. to get fruit for oneself, i. e.,
to reap crops from land, Hdt., Aesch.: metaph. to exhaust or drain, τὴν Ἑλλάδα Ar.
to enjoy the interest of money, Dem.; so in perf. pass., τὸ ἐργαστήριον κεκαρπωμένος enjoying the profits of the shop, Dem.:—absol. to make profit, Ar.
to reap the fruits of, enjoy the free use of, Thuc., etc.: —then,
simply, to enjoy, Soph., Eur., etc.:— sometimes in bad sense, καρποῦσθαι τὴν ἁμαρτίαν Aesch.; πένθη Eur.

div1.head: κάρπωσις
div1.sense: use or profit, Xen.

div1.head: κάρτα
div1.sense: very, very much, extremely, Lat. valde, admodum.
beyond measure, in good earnest, κ. ἐγχώριος a thorough native, Aesch.; κ. ὢν ἐπώνυμος true to thy name, Aesch.; κ. δʼ εἰμὶ τοῦ πατρός all on my fatherʼs side, Aesch.
καὶ κάρτα, used to increase the force of a previous statement, really and truly, most certainly, Hdt., Soph.; so, τὸ κάρτα, with iron. sense, in good sooth, with a vengeance, Hdt.

div1.head: καρτερέω
div1.sense: to be steadfast, patient, staunch, Soph., etc.; with a prep., κ. πρός τι to hold up against a thing, Xen., etc.:—with a part. to persevere in doing, Eur.: absol., τὰ δείνʼ ἐκαρτέρουν was strangely obdurate or obstinate, Soph.
c. acc. rei, to bear patiently, Eur., Xen.:—Pass., κεκαρτέρηται τἀμά my time for patience is over, Eur.

div1.head: καρτέρημα
div1.sense: an act of patience, Plat.

div1.head: καρτέρησις
div1.sense: a bearing patiently, patience, Plat.
c. gen. patient endurance of a thing, Plat.

div1.head: καρτερία
div1.sense: patient endurance, patience, opp. to μαλακία, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: καρτερικός
div1.sense: capable of endurance, patient, Xen., Arist.

div1.head: καρτερόθυμος
div1.sense: stout-hearted, Hom., Hes.: generally, strong, mighty, ἄνεμοι Hes.

div1.head: καρτερός
