div1.sense: to be a herald, officiate as herald, Il.; λαὸν κηρύσσοντες ἀγειρόντων let them convene the people by voice of herald, Il.; κήρυσσε, κῆρυξ Aesch., etc.:—impers., κηρύσσει (sc. ὁ κῆρυξ) he gives notice, proclamation is made, Xen.
c. acc. pers. to summon by voice of herald, Hom., Ar.
to proclaim as conqueror, Xen., etc.: to extol, Eur.
to call upon, invoke, Aesch., Eur.
c. acc. rei, to proclaim, announce, τί τινι Trag.:— to proclaim or advertise for sale, Hdt.; κ. ἀποικίαν to proclaim a colony, i. e. to invite people to join as colonists, Thuc.
to proclaim or command publicly, Lat. indicere, Aesch., Soph., etc.; τὰ κηρυχθέντα the public orders, Soph.

div1.head: κήτειος
div1.sense: of sea monsters, Mosch.

div1.head: κῆτος
div1.sense: any sea-monster or huge fish, Hom., Hdt.
an abyss, hollow, cf. κητώεις.

div1.head: κητοφόνος
div1.sense: killing sea-monsters, Anth.

div1.head: κητώεις
div1.sense: as epith. of Lacedaemon, full of hollows or ravines, Hom.; cf. μεγακήτης.

div1.head: κηφήν
div1.sense: a drone, Lat. fucus: metaph. a drone, a lazy fellow, Hes., Ar.

div1.head: κηφηνώδης
div1.sense: like a drone, Plat.

div1.head: Κηφισός
div1.sense: the Cephisus, a river of Phocis, Il.:—fem. λίμνη Κηφισίς Il.
the more famous river of Athens, Soph., etc.

div1.head: κηώδης
div1.sense: smelling as of incense, fragrant, Il.

div1.head: κιβδηλεύω
div1.sense: to adulterate coin, Ar., etc.
metaph. to palm off, Eur.

div1.head: κιβδηλία
div1.sense: adulteration, trickery, dishonesty, Ar.

div1.head: κίβδηλος
div1.sense: adulterated, spurious, base, of coin, Theogn., Eur.
metaph. base, false, spurious, fraudulent, of men, Theogn., Eur.; of oracles, deceitful, Hdt.; ἐν κιβδήλῳ Eur.

div1.head: κίβισις
div1.sense: a pouch, wallet, Hes.

div1.head: κιβωτός
div1.sense: a wooden box, chest, coffer, Ar.

div1.head: κιγκλίζω
div1.sense: to wag the tail:—metaph. to change constantly, Theogn.

div1.head: κιγκλίς
div1.sense: the latticed gates in the law-courts or council-chamber, through which the members passed, Ar.; metaph., means waitings at the bar, the lawʼs delays, Plut.; in sg., ἐντὸς τῆς κιγκλίδος διατρίβειν to live in court, Luc.

div1.head: κίγκλος
div1.sense: prob. a kind of wagtail, Theogn.

div1.head: κίδναμαι
div1.etym: pass., only in pres. and imperf.
div1.sense: to be spread abroad or over, of the dawning day, Il.; ὕπνος ἐπʼ ὄσσοις κ. Eur.

div1.head: κιθάρα
div1.sense: the Lat. cithara (whence guitar), a kind of lyre or lute, Hhymn., Hdt., Attic: —it was of triangular shape, with seven strings, Eur. Cf. κιθαρίζω

div1.head: κιθαρίζω
div1.sense: to play the cithara, φόρμιγγι κιθάριζε Il., Hes.; λύρῃ ἐρατὸν κιθαρίζων Hhymn. (so that there can have been no great difference between the κιθάρα, λύρα, and φόρμιγξ) ; κιθαρίζειν οὐκ ἐπίσταται, of an uneducated person, Ar.

div1.head: κιθάρισις
div1.sense: a playing on the cithara, Plat.

div1.head: κιθάρισμα
div1.sense: that which is played on the cithara, a piece of music for it, Plat.

div1.head: κίθαρις
div1.sense: = κιθάρα, Hom., etc.
= κιθαριστύς, Hom.

div1.head: κιθαριστής
div1.sense: a player on the cithara, Hes., Attic

div1.head: κιθαριστικός
div1.sense: skilled in harp-playing, Plat.: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) = κιθαριστύς, Plat.

div1.head: κιθαριστύς
div1.sense: the art of playing the cithara, Il.

div1.head: κιθαρῳδέω
div1.sense: to sing to the cithara, Plat.

div1.head: κιθαρῳδία
div1.sense: a singing to the cithara, Plat.

div1.head: κιθαρῳδικός
div1.sense: of or for harp-playing, Ar.
ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) = κιθαρῳδία, Plat.

div1.head: κιθαρῳδός
div1.sense: one who plays and sings to the cithara, a harper, Hdt., Plat., etc.

div1.head: κίκιννος
div1.sense: a ringlet, Lat. cincinnus, Ar., Theocr.

div1.head: κίκι
div1.sense: the castor berry, Hdt.

div1.head: κικκαβαῦ
div1.sense: onomatop., a cry in imitation of the screechowlʼs note, toowhit, toowhoo, Ar.

div1.head: κικλήσκω
div1.sense: to call, summon, Hom.
to call on, invoke, implore, Il., Aesch., etc.
to accost, address, Il.
to name, call by name, Il., Aesch., Eur.: —Pass., νῆσός τις Συρίη κικλήσκεται there is an island called Syros, Od.; cf. κλῄζω II.

div1.head: Κίκυννα
div1.sense: Cicynna, an Attic deme: Κικυννεύς, ὁ, a Cicynnian, Attic; pl. Κικυννῆς, Ar.; Κικυννόθεν, from Cicynna, Ar.

div1.head: κῖκυς
div1.sense: strength, vigour, Od., Hhymn.

div1.head: κίκω
div1.etym: a verb only found in Doric aor1 ἔκιξα
div1.sense: = ἤνεγκα Anth.:—in Ar. we have ἀπ-έκιξαν, sent away, shook off.

div1.head: Κίλιξ
div1.sense: a Cilician, Il.: fem. Κίλισσα, Aesch.: —adj. Κιλίκιος, η, ον Cilician, Aesch.; ἡ Κιλικία, (sc. γῆ) , Cilicia, Hdt.

div1.head: κιλλίβας
div1.sense: in pl. κιλλίβαντες, a three-legged stand for supporting any thing, κιλλίβαντες ἀσπίδος a shield- stand, Ar.

div1.head: κίμβιξ
div1.sense: a niggard, Arist.

div1.head: Κιμμερικός
div1.sense: Cimmerian, K. ἰσθμός the Crimea, Aesch.; Κιμμέριος, η, ον, Hdt.

div1.head: Κιμμέριοι
div1.sense: the Cimmerians, a people dwelling beyond the Ocean in perpetual darkness, Od.: in later geography, a people about the Palus Maeotis, Hdt.

div1.head: Κιμωλία
div1.sense: sc. γῆ, Cimolian earth, a white clay, from Cimolus in the Cyclades, which was used by way of soap in the baths, Ar.

div1.head: κινάβρα
div1.sense: the rank smell of a he-goat, Luc.

div1.head: κιναβράω
div1.sense: to smell like a goat, Ar.

div1.head: κίναδος
div1.sense: a fox: hence of a cunning rogue, Soph., Ar., etc.:—in Theocr. the voc. κίναδε implies a masc. form κίναδος, ου.

div1.head: κινάθισμα
div1.sense: motion, rustling, as of wings, Aesch.

div1.head: κιναιδία
div1.sense: lust, Aeschin., Luc.

div1.head: κίναιδος
div1.sense: Lat. cinaedus, a lewd fellow, Plat.

div1.head: κινδύνευμα
div1.sense: a risk, hazard, venture, bold enterprise, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: κινδυνευτέος
div1.sense: one must venture, Eur.

div1.head: κινδυνευτής
div1.sense: a daring, venturesome person, Thuc.

div1.head: κινδυνευτικός
div1.sense: adventurous, Arist.

div1.head: κινδυνεύω
div1.sense: to be daring, to make a venture, take the risk, do a daring thing, Hdt., Ar., etc.: to be in danger, Thuc.

that in respect of which danger is incurred in dat., κ. τῶι σώματι, τῆι ψυχῆι Hdt.; κ. πάσηι τῆι Ἑλλάδι to run a risk with all Greece, i. e. endanger it all, Hdt., etc.; so, κ. περὶ τῆς ψυχῆς Ar., etc.
c. acc. cogn. to venture, hazard, κινδύνευμα Plat.; μάχην Aeschin.:—Pass. to be risked or hazarded, μεταβολὴ κινδυνεύεται there is risk of change, Thuc.; τὰ μέγιστα κινδυνεύεται are endangered, Dem.

c. inf. to run the risk of doing or being, Hdt., Thuc., etc.:— then, implying a chance of success, κινδυνεύω (c. inf.) is used to express what may possibly or probably happen, κινδυνεύουσι οἱ ἄνθρωποι γόητες εἶναι they run a risk of being reputed conjurors, Hdt.; κινδυνεύσεις ἐπιδεῖξαι χρηστὸς εἶναι you will have a chance of showing your worth, Xen.; κινδυνεύει ἀγαθὸν γεγονέναι it is very likely to prove good, Plat.:—then impers., κινδυνεύει it may be, possibly, Plat.
Pass. to be endangered or imperilled, Thuc., Dem.

div1.head: κίνδυνος
div1.sense: a danger, risk, hazard, venture, enterprise, Lat. periculum, Pind., Ar., etc.; κίνδυνον ἀναρρίπτειν to run a risk, Hdt., etc.; κίνδυνον or κινδύνους ἀναλαβέσθαι, ὑποδύεσθαι, αἴρεσθαι, ὑπομεῖναι, etc., Attic

div1.head: κινέω
div1.sense: pf to set in motion, to move, Hom., Attic

to move or remove a thing from its place, Hdt.; κ. τὰ ἀκίνητα to meddle with things sacred, Hdt., Soph.; κ. τὰ χρήματα ἐς ἄλλο τι to apply them to an alien purpose, Hdt.;— κ. τὸ στρατόπεδον, Lat. castra movere, Xen.:— to change, innovate, τὰ νόμαια Hdt.
to rouse, disturb, of a waspsʼ nest, Il.: to stir up, arouse, urge on, Trag., etc.
to set agoing, cause, call forth, Soph., etc.:—proverb., κ. πᾶν χρῆμα to turn every stone, try every way, Hdt.
Pass. to be put in motion, to be moved, move, stir, Il., Hdt., Attic
to move forward, of soldiers, Soph., Xen., etc.

div1.head: κινηθμός
div1.sense: motion, Pind.

div1.head: κίνημα
div1.sense: a motion, movement, Plut.

div1.head: κίνησις
div1.sense: movement, motion, Plat., etc.: a dance, Luc.
movement, in a political sense, Thuc.; of the Peloponn. war, Thuc.

div1.head: κινητέος
div1.sense: to be moved, Plat.
κινητέον, one must call into play, Plat.

div1.head: κινητής
div1.sense: one that sets agoing, an author, Ar.

div1.head: κινητικός
div1.sense: of or for putting in motion, Xen.

div1.head: κιννάμωμον
div1.sense: cinnamon, a word borrowed from the Phoenicians, Hdt.

div1.head: κίνυγμα
div1.sense: anything moved about, αἰθέριον κ. a sport for the winds of heaven, Aesch.

div1.head: κίνυμαι
div1.sense: Dep., to go, move, ἐς πόλεμον κίνυντο (Epic imperf.) they were marching to battle, Il.; κινυμένοιο as he moved, Il.

div1.head: κινύρομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to utter a plaintive sound, lament, wail, Ar.:—c. acc. cogn., χαλινοὶ κινύρονται φόνον the bridles ring or clash murderously, Aesch.

div1.head: κινυρός
div1.sense: wailing, plaintive, Il.

div1.head: κινύσσομαι
div1.sense: Pass. = κινέομαι, to sway backwards and forwards, Aesch.

div1.head: κιόκρανον
div1.sense: the capital of a column, Xen.

div1.head: Κίρκη
div1.sense: Circe, an enchantress, dwelling in the island Aea, who changed Ulyssesʼ companions into swine, Od.

div1.head: κίρκος
div1.sense: a kind of hawk or falcon, so called from its wheeling flight, ἵρηξ κίρκος (where ἵρηξ is the generic term, κίρκος the specific, like βοῦς τοῦρος) , Od.
a ring, circle, mostly in form κρίκος.

div1.head: κιρκόω
div1.sense: to hoop round, secure with rings, Aesch.

div1.head: κιρνάω
div1.sense: to mix wine with water, in 3rd sg. imperf. ἐκίρνα and κίρνη, part. κιρνάς, Od.; in Hdt., 3rd sg. pres. κιρνᾶι, 1st pl. κίρναμεν.

div1.head: κίσηρις
div1.sense: the pumice-stone, Lat. pumex, Arist., Luc.

div1.head: κίς
div1.sense: a worm in wood or in corn, the weevil, Lat. curculio, Pind.

div1.head: κίσσα
div1.sense: a chattering, greedy bird, the jay or magpie, Ar.

div1.head: κισσάω
div1.sense: to crave for strange food, of pregnant women: metaph., κ. τῆς εἰρήνης Ar.; c. inf. to long to do a thing, Ar.

div1.head: κισσήρης
div1.sense: ivy-clad, Soph.

div1.head: κίσσινος
div1.sense: of ivy, Eur.

div1.head: Κίσσιος
div1.sense: of or from Cissia in southern Persia, Hdt.; Κισσία ἰηλεμίστρια a Cissian mourner, Aesch.

div1.head: κισσοκόμης
div1.sense: ivy-crowned, Hhymn.

div1.head: κισσοποίητος
div1.sense: made of ivy, Luc.

div1.head: κισσός
div1.sense: ivy, Lat. hedera, Soph., Eur., etc.

div1.head: κισσοστέφανος
div1.sense: ivy-crowned, Anth.

div1.head: κισσοφορέω
div1.sense: to be decked with ivy, Anth.

div1.head: κισσοφόρος
div1.sense: ivy-wreathed, Pind.: luxuriant with ivy, Eur.

div1.head: κισσόω
div1.sense: to wreathe with ivy, Eur.

div1.head: κισσύβιον
div1.sense: a rustic drinking-cup, prob. with an ivy-wreath carved on it, Od.

div1.head: κισσωτός
div1.sense: decked with ivy, Anth.

div1.head: κίστη
div1.sense: a box, chest, Lat. cista, Od., Ar.
a writing-case, desk, Ar.

div1.head: κιστοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying a chest in mystic processions, Dem.

div1.head: κιχάνω
div1.sense: to reach, hit, or light upon, meet with, find, Hom.:— to overtake, Il.: to reach, arrive at, Il.; σε δουρὶ κιχήσομαι shall reach thee, Il.; τέλος θανάτοιο κιχήμενον death that is sure to reach one, inevitable, Il.
rarely c. gen., like τυγχάνω, Soph.

div1.head: κίχλη
div1.sense: a thrush, Lat. turdus, Od., Ar.

div1.head: κιχλίζω
div1.sense: to chirp like a thrush: hence, to titter, giggle, or to eat κίχλαι, to live luxuriously, Ar.

div1.head: κίχρημι
div1.sense: to lend.

div1.head: κίων
div1.sense: a pillar, Lat. columna, Od.: a flogging-post, Soph., Aeschin.; proverb., ἔσθιε τοὺς Μεγακλέους κίονας eat the pillars of his hall, for being a spendthrift, he had nothing else left to give, Ar.
in pl. the pillars guarded by Atlas, which keep heaven and earth asunder, Od.; whereas in Hdt. Mount Atlas is ὁ κίων τοῦ οὐρανοῦ.
a columnar grave-stone, Anth.

div1.head: κίω
div1.sense: to go, Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: κλαγγαίνω
div1.sense: of hounds, to give tongue, only in pres., Aesch., Xen.

div1.head: κλαγγηδόν
div1.sense: with a clang, noise, din, Il.

div1.head: κλαγγή
div1.sense: any sharp sound, such as the twang of a bow, Il.; the scream of cranes, Hom.; the grunting of swine, Od.; the hissing of serpents, Aesch.; the barking of dogs, Xen.:—also of song, Soph.; κλ. δύσφατος, of Cassandra-prophecies, Aesch.

div1.head: κλαγερός
div1.sense: screaming, of cranes, Anth.

div1.head: κλάδος
div1.sense: a young slip or shoot broken off: esp. an olive-branch wound round with wool and presented by suppliants, Hdt., Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: κλάζω
div1.sense: to make a sharp piercing sound, of birds, to scream, screech, Il., Soph., etc.; of dogs, to bark, bay, Od., Ar.; of things, as of arrows in the quiver, to clash, rattle, Il.; of the wind, to whistle, Od.; of wheels, to creak, Aesch.; c. acc. cogn., κλάζουσι φόβον ring forth terror, Aesch.

of men, to shout, scream, Il.:—the nearest approach to articulate sound is in Aesch., μάντις ἔκλαγξεν ἄλλο μῆχαρ shrieked forth another remedy; Ζῆνα ἐπινίκια κλάζων sounding loudly the victory-song of Zeus, Aesch.

div1.head: κλαίω
div1.sense: to weep, lament, wail, Hom., etc.; αὐτὸν κλαίοντα ἀφήσω I shall send him home weeping, i. e. well beaten, Il.; hence κλαύσεται he shall weep, i. e. he shall repent it, Ar.; κλαύσει μακρά Ar.; κλάων to your sorrow, at your peril, Soph., Eur.; κλάειν σε λέγω or κελεύω, Lat. plorare te jubeo, Ar.
trans. to weep for, lament, Hom.:—in Pass. to be lamented, Aesch.: impers., μάτην ἐμοὶ κεκλαύσεται I shall mourn in vain, Ar.
Mid. to bewail oneself, weep aloud, Aesch.; so perf. part. pass., κεκλαυμένος bathed in tears, all tears, Aesch., Soph.
trans. to bewail to oneself, Soph.

div1.head: κλαμβός
div1.sense: mutilated, Hippiatr.

div1.head: κλασιβῶλαξ
div1.sense: breaking clods, Anth.

div1.head: κλάσις
div1.sense: a breaking, NTest.

div1.head: κλάσμα
div1.sense: that which is broken off, a fragment, morsel, NTest., Plut.

div1.head: κλαστάζω
div1.sense: to dress vines: metaph. κλ. τινά to give him a dressing, Ar.

div1.head: κλαστός
div1.sense: broken in pieces, Anth.

div1.head: κλαυθμός
div1.sense: a weeping, Hom., Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: κλαυθμυρίζω
div1.sense: to make to weep:—Pass. to weep, Plat.

div1.head: κλαυθμυρισμός
div1.sense: a crying like a child, Plut.

div1.head: κλαῦμα
div1.sense: a weeping, wailing, Aesch.
a trouble, misfortune, Soph., Ar.

div1.head: κλαυσιάω
div1.sense: Desiderat. of κλαίω, to wish to weep, τὸ θύριον φθεγγόμενον ἄλλως κλαυσιᾷ the door is like to weep (i. e. shall suffer) for creaking without cause, Ar.

div1.head: κλαυσίγελως
div1.sense: smiles mixed with tears, Xen.

div1.head: κλαυσίμαχος
div1.sense: rue-the-fight, a parody on the name of La-machus (ready-for-fight), Ar.

div1.head: κλαυστός
div1.sense: wept, bewailed: to be bewailed, mournful, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: κλάω
div1.sense: to break, break off, Hom., etc.

div1.head: κλειδίον
div1.sense: a little key, Ar.

div1.head: κλειδουχέω
div1.sense: to have charge of the keys, κλ. θεᾶς to be her priestess, Eur.
Pass. to be closely watched kept in check, Eur.

div1.head: κλειδοῦχος
div1.sense: holding the keys, having charge of a place, Eur.; of Aeacus, as judge of the dead, Anth.

div1.head: κλειθρία
div1.sense: a keyhole; or, generally, a cleft, chink, Luc.

div1.head: κλεῖθρον
div1.sense: a bar for closing a door, Hhymn.:—mostly in pl., like Lat. claustra, Trag., etc.

div1.head: κλεινός
div1.sense: famous, renowned, illustrious, Solon., Pind., Trag.; καὶ τοῦτο κλεινὸν αὐτοῦ is well known of him, Luc.

div1.head: κλείς
div1.sense: that which serves for closing:
a bar or bolt, drawn or undrawn by a latch or thong (ἱμάς) , Hom.
a key, or rather a kind of catch or hook, by which the bar (ὀχεύς) was shot or unshot from the outside, Hom.
a key (unknown to Hom.), Aesch., Eur.
metaph., Ἁσυχία βουλᾶν τε καὶ πολέμων κλαῖδας ἔχοισα Pind.; κλῇς ἐπὶ γλώσσῃ βέβηκε, of enforced silence, Soph.; so, καθαρὰν ἀνοῖξαι κλῇδα φρενῶν Eur.
the hook or tongue of a clasp, Od.
the collar-bone, so called because it locks the neck and breast together Il., Soph., etc.
a rowing bench, which locked the sides of the ship together, Od.
a narrow pass, "the key" of a country, Hdt.; a strait, Eur.

div1.head: κλειστός
div1.sense: that can be shut or closed, Od., Thuc.

div1.head: κλεῖστρον
div1.sense: = κλεῖθρον, Lat. claustrum, Luc.

div1.head: κλείω
div1.sense: to shut, close, bar, κλήισεν δὲ θύρας barred the doors, Od.; ἐκλήισεν ὀχῆας shot the bars, so as to close the door, Od.; κλῄειν στόμα Eur.
to shut up, close, block, Βόσπορον κλήισαι Aesch.; κληίσειν τοὺς ἔσπλους ναυσί Thuc.:—Pass. to be shut up, Hdt.
to confine, Eur.

div1.head: κλείω
div1.sense: to celebrate.

div1.head: Κλειώ
div1.sense: Clio, one of the Muses, Hes. etc.; esp. the Muse of Epic Poetry and History.

div1.head: κλέμμα
div1.sense: a theft, Eur., Ar.
a stratagem in war, Thuc.: a fraud, Dem., Aeschin.

div1.head: κλέος
div1.sense: a rumour, report, news, Lat. fama, Hom.; σὸν κλέος news of thee, Od.; c. gen., κλέος Ἀχαιῶν the report of their coming, Il.:— a mere report, opp. to certainty, κλέος οἶον ἀκούομεν, οὐδέ τι ἴδμεν we hear a rumour only, but know naught, Il.

good report, fame, glory, Hom.; κλέος οὐρανὸν ἵκει Od.; κλ. ἑλέσθαι, εὑρέσθαι Pind.; λαβεῖν Soph.; κλ. καταθέσθαι to lay up store of glory, Hdt., etc.: —in pl., ἄειδε κλέα ἀνδρῶν (shortd. from κλέεα) , was singing the lays of their achievements, Il.

in bad sense, δύσφημον κλέος ill repute, Pind.; αἰσχρὸν κλ. Eur.;—both senses combined in Thuc., ἧς ἂν ἐπʼ ἐλάχιστον ἀρετῆς πέρι ἢ ψόγου κλέος ᾖ of whom there is least talk either for praise or blame.

div1.head: κλεπτέος
div1.sense: one must conceal, Soph.

div1.head: κλέπτης
div1.sense: a thief, Il., Aesch., etc.: generally, a cheat, knave, Soph.

div1.head: κλεπτικός
div1.sense: thieving, Plat.

div1.head: κλεπτίστατος
div1.sense: the most arrant thief, Ar.

div1.head: κλέπτω
div1.sense: to steal, filch, purloin, Hom., etc.; τῆς γενεῆς ἔκλεψε from that breed Anchises stole, i. e. stole foals of that breed, Il.; σῶμα κλ. to let it down secretly, Eur.
in part. act. thievish, κλέπτον βλέπει he has a thiefʼs look, Ar.
to cozen, cheat, deceive, beguile, Il., Hes., etc.:—Pass., προβαίνει κλεπτόμενος he goes on blindfold, Hdt.
like κρύπτω, to conceal, keep secret, disguise, Pind., Soph., Eur., etc.
to do secretly or treacherously, κλ. σφαγάς to perpetrate slaughter secretly, Soph.; κλ. μύθους to whisper malicious rumours, Soph.; κλέπτων ἢ βιαζόμενος by fraud or force, Plat.
to seize or occupy secretly, Xen.

div1.head: κλεψίφρων
div1.sense: deceiving, dissembling, Hhymn.

div1.head: κλεψύδρα
div1.sense: a water-clock, like our sand-glasses, used to time speeches in the lawcourts, Ar.
name of an ebbing well in the Acropolis at Athens, Ar.

div1.head: κλέω
div1.etym: Pass., Epic 2nd sg. imperf. ἔκλεο (for ἐκλέεο)
div1.sense: to tell of, celebrate, Od., Hes., Eur.:—Pass. to be famous, Od., Pind.; ἔνθʼ ἀγοραὶ κλέονται where are held the famous meetings, Soph.

div1.head: κλήδην
div1.sense: by name, Il.

div1.head: κληδών
div1.sense: an omen or presage contained in a word or sound, Od., Hdt., Aesch.
a rumour, tidings, report, Hdt., Trag.; κληηδὼν πατρός news of my father, Od.
glory, repute, Trag.
a calling on, appeal, πατρῷαι κληδόνες Aesch.
a name, appellation, Aesch.

div1.head: κλῄζω
div1.sense: to make famous, to celebrate in song, laud, Hhymn., Pind., Eur.:—Pass. to be spoken of, talked of, Aesch., Eur.
to name, call, Soph.:— Pass., ἔνθα κληίζεται οὑμός Κιθαιρών where is Cithaeron called mine, Soph.; cf. κικλήσκω fin.

div1.head: κλῄζω
div1.sense: in late writers for κλείω, κλῄω, to shut.

div1.head: κλήθρα
div1.sense: the alder, prob. alnus, still called κλέθρα in Greece, Od.

div1.head: κλῆμα
div1.sense: a vine-twig, vine-branch, Lat. palmes, Ar., Plat.: generally, a cutting, slip, Xen.: —metaph., ἀνατέμνειν τὰ κλ. τὰ τοῦ δήμου Dem.:— the vine-switch of the Roman centurions, Lat. vitis, Plut.

div1.head: κλημάτινος
div1.sense: of vine-twigs, Theogn.

div1.head: κληματίς
div1.sense: Dim. of κλῆμα:—in pl. brush-wood, fagot-wood, Thuc.

div1.head: κληρονομέω
div1.sense: to receive a share of an inheritance, to inherit a portion of property, c. gen., Dem.:—also c. acc. rei, to inherit, Luc.
to be an inheritor or heir, τινός of a person, Luc.: also c. acc. to succeed one, Plut., Anth.

div1.head: κληρονόμημα
div1.sense: an inheritance, Luc.

div1.head: κληρονομία
div1.sense: an inheritance, Dem.:—generally, κλ. λαμβάνειν τινός to take possession of . . , Arist.

div1.head: κληρονόμος
div1.sense: one who receives a portion of an inheritance, an inheritor, heir, Dem., etc.

div1.head: κληροπαλής
div1.sense: distributed by shaking the lots, Hhymn.

div1.head: κλῆρος
div1.sense: a lot; in Hom., each man marks his own lot, and they are thrown into a helmet, and the first which came out was the winning lot.
a casting lots, drawing lots, Eur.; many officers at Athens obtained their offices by lot, as opp. to election (χειροτονία, αἵρεσις) , Xen., Arist.; cf. κύαμος II.
an allotment of land assigned to citizens (cf. κληρουχία) , Hdt., Thuc., etc.
any piece of land, a portion, farm, Hom., etc.
in Eccl. the clergy, as opp. to the laity.

div1.head: κληρουχέω
div1.sense: to obtain by allotment, to have allotted to one, esp. of lands divided among conquerors, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: κληρουχία
div1.sense: the allotment of land to citizens in a foreign country, Arist.

collectively, = οἱ κληροῦχοι, the body of citizens who receive such allotments, Thuc., Plut.—An Athenian κληρουχία differed from a colony (ἀποικία) , in that the κληροῦχοι were still citizens of the mother country, instead of forming an independent state.

div1.head: κληρουχικός
div1.sense: of or for a κληρουχία, γῆ κλ. land for allotment, Ar.; τὰ κληρουχικά (sc. χρήματα) Dem.

div1.head: κληροῦχος
div1.sense: one who held an allotment of land, esp. to citizens in a foreign country (v. κληρουχία, an allottee, Hdt., Thuc., etc.:—metaph., μητέρα πολλῶν ἐτῶν κληροῦχον having old age for her lot, Soph.

div1.head: κληρόω
div1.sense: to appoint to an office by lot, opp. to αἱρεῖσθαι or χειροτονεῖν, Hdt., Attic:—of the lot, to fall on, Lat. designare, Eur.:— Pass. to be appointed by lot, Dem., etc.
to cast lots, draw lots, Plat.;—so in Mid., Aesch., Dem.
in Mid. also, κληροῦσθαί τι to have allotted one, obtain by lot, Eur., Aeschin.; also c. gen., Dem.
to allot, assign, Pind., Thuc.
κλ. ὀμφάν to deliver an oracle, Eur.

div1.head: κληρωτός
div1.sense: appointed by lot, opp. to αἱρετός and κεχειροτονημένος (elected), Plat., etc.

div1.head: κλῆσις
div1.sense: a calling, call, Xen., etc.
a calling into court, legal summons, prosecution, Ar., Xen., etc.
an invitation to a feast, Xen., Dem.
a name, appellation, Plat.

div1.head: κλῇσις
div1.sense: a shutting up, closing, Thuc.

div1.head: κλητέος
div1.sense: to be called, named, Plat.
κλητέον, one must call, Plat.

div1.head: κλητεύω
div1.sense: to summon into court or give evidence that a summons has been served (v. κλητήρ, Ar.

div1.head: κλητήρ
div1.sense: one who calls, a summoner, or rather a witness who gave evidence that the legal summons had been served (cf. Horaceʼs licet antestari), Ar., Dem.
generally, = κῆρυξ, Aesch.

div1.head: κλητός
div1.sense: called, invited, welcome, Od.
called out, chosen, Il.

div1.head: κλιμακτήρ
div1.sense: the round of a ladder, Eur.

div1.head: κλῖμαξ
div1.sense: a ladder or staircase (because of its leaning aslant), Od., etc.:— a scaling-ladder, Thuc., Xen.; κλίμακος προσαμβάσεις Aesch.:— a shipʼs ladder, Eur., Theocr.
a frame with cross-bars, on which persons to be tortured were tied, Ar.
in Soph., κλίμακες ἀμφίπλεκτοι intertwining ladders, to express the entanglement of the limbs of wrestlers.
a climax, i. e. a gradual ascent from weaker expressions to stronger, Lat. gradatio, as Ciceroʼs abiit, evasit, erupit.

div1.head: κλίμα
div1.sense: an inclination, slope:—esp. the supposed slope of the earth towards the pole: hence a region or zone of the earth, clime, Plut., Anth.

div1.head: κλίνειος
div1.sense: of or for beds, Dem.

div1.head: κλίνη
div1.sense: that on which one lies, a couch or bed, Hdt., Ar., etc.:—also, a bier, Thuc.

div1.head: κλινήρης
div1.sense: bed-ridden, Lat. lecto affixus, Plut.

div1.head: κλινικός
div1.sense: Lat. clinicus, a physician that visits his patients in their beds, Anth.

div1.head: κλινοπετής
div1.sense: bed-ridden, Xen.

div1.head: κλινοποιός
div1.sense: making beds or bedsteads, an upholsterer, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: κλιντήρ
div1.sense: a couch, sofa, Od., Theocr.

div1.head: κλίνω
div1.sense: to make to bend, slope, or slant, Lat. inclinare, κλίνειν τάλαντα to incline or turn the scale, Il.; Τρῶας ἔκλιναν made them give way, Il.; ἔκλινε μάχην turned the tide of war, Il.
to make one thing lean against another, i. e. σάκεʼ ὤμοισι κλίναντες, i. e. raising their shields so that the upper rim rested on their shoulders, Il.
to turn aside, ὄσσε πάλιν κλίνασα having turned back her eyes, Il.
to make to recline, ἐν κλίνηι κλ. τινά to make him lie down at table, Hdt.:—metaph., ἡμέρα κλίνει ἅπαντα puts to rest, lays low all things, Soph.
Pass. to be bent, bend, ἐκλίνθη he bent aside, swerved, Il.; of a pan, ἂψ ἑτέρωσʼ ἐκλίθη it was tipped over to the other side, Od.
to lean or stay oneself upon or against a thing, c. dat., Hom.; so in Mid., κλινάμενος Od.:—also, κεκλιμένος ἐπάλξεσιν seeking safety in them, Il.
to lie down, lie, Hom., etc.; to lie on a couch at meals, Hdt., etc.
of Places (in perf.), to lie sloping towards the sea, ἁλὶ κεκλιμένη Od.; νῆσοι, αἵθʼ ἁλὶ κεκλίαται (Epic for κέκλινται), Od.
to wander from the right course, Theogn.
Mid. to decline, of the day, Hdt.; so, intr. in Act., ἡ ἡμέρα ἤρξατο κλίνειν NTest.:—metaph., κλ. ἐπὶ τὸ χεῖρον to fall off, degenerate, Xen.

div1.head: κλισιάδες
div1.sense: folding doors or gates, Plut.: —metaph. a means of entrance, access, Hdt.

div1.head: κλισία
div1.sense: a place for lying down, hence

a hut, cot, cabin, such as besiegers lived in during long sieges, Il.:—that they were not tents, but wooden huts, appears from Il. 24.448 sq.; and when an army broke up, it burnt them on the spot, Od. 8.501
a couch or easy chair, Od., Pind.
a bed, nuptial bed, Eur.
a company of people sitting at meals, NTest.
a reclining or lying, Plut.

div1.head: κλισίηθεν
div1.sense: out of or from a hut, Il.

div1.head: κλισίηνδε
div1.sense: into or to the hut, Il.

div1.head: κλίσιον
div1.sense: the outbuildings round a herdmanʼs cot, Od.

div1.head: κλίσις
div1.sense: a bending, inclination, τοῦ τραχήλου Plut.
a lying down, lying, Eur.

div1.head: κλισμός
div1.sense: a couch, Hom.

div1.head: κλίτος
div1.sense: a clime, Anth.

div1.head: κλειτύς
div1.sense: a slope, hill-side, Lat. clivus, Hom., Soph.

div1.head: κλοιός
div1.sense: a dog-collar, esp. a large wooden collar, put on mischievous dogs, Ar., Xen.
a sort of pillory, Eur.
χρύσεος κλ. a collar of gold, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: κλονέω
div1.sense: to drive in confusion, drive before one, Il., Hes.
generally, to ruffle, Soph., Ar.
Pass. to be driven in confusion, rush wildly, Il., Pind.
to be beaten by the waves, Soph.

div1.head: κλόνος
div1.sense: any confused motion, the press of battle, battle-rout, turmoil, Il.; κλόνοι ἱππιόχαρμαι throngs of fighting horsemen, Aesch.

div1.head: κλοπαῖος
div1.sense: stolen, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: κλοπεύς
div1.sense: a thief, stealer, Soph.
generally, a secret doer, perpetrator, Soph.

div1.head: κλοπή
div1.sense: theft, Lat. furtum, Aesch., Eur.
a secret act, fraud, Eur., Aeschin.; κλοπῇ by stealth or fraud, Soph.; ποδοῖν κλοπὰν ἀρέσθαι, i. e. to steal away, Soph.
the surprise of a military post, Xen.

div1.head: κλόπιος
div1.sense: thievish, artful, μῦθοι Od.

div1.head: κλοπός
div1.sense: a thief, Hhymn.

div1.head: κλοτοπεύω
div1.sense: to deal subtly, to spin out time by false pretences, Il.;—it seems to be a lengthd. form of κλέπτω, κλωπεύω.

div1.head: κλυδωνίζω
div1.sense: Pass. to be tossed like waves, NTest.

div1.head: κλυδώνιον
div1.sense: a little wave, ripple, Eur.; generally, a wave, Aesch.:—as collective noun, the surf, Thuc.
metaph., κλ. χολῆς Aesch.

div1.head: κλύδων
div1.sense: a wave, billow, and collectively surf Od., Trag.
metaph., κλ. κακῶν a sea of troubles, Aesch.; κλ. ξυμφορᾶς Soph.; κλ. ἔφιππος a flood of horsemen, Soph., etc.

div1.head: κλύζω
div1.sense: to dash over, of a wave, Hhymn.: to dash like a wave, Aesch.:—Pass. to be dashed up, of the sea, Hom.; to rise in waves, Hes.
to wash off or away, Eur.
to wash or rinse out, Xen.
εἰς ὦτα κλ. to put water into the ears and so cleanse them, Eur.
κεκλυσμένος καρῶι washed over or coated with wax, Theocr.

div1.head: κλύμενος
div1.sense: famous, Theocr.

div1.head: κλύσμα
div1.sense: a liquid used for washing out: esp. a clyster, drench, Hdt.
a place washed by the waves, the sea-beach, Plut., Luc.

div1.head: κλυστήρ
div1.sense: a clyster-pipe, syringe, Hdt.

div1.head: Κλυταιμνήστρα
div1.sense: the queen of Agamemnon, Il.

div1.head: κλυτόδενδρος
div1.sense: famous for trees, Anth.

div1.head: κλυτοεργός
div1.sense: famous for work, Od., Anth.

div1.head: κλυτόκαρπος
div1.sense: glorious with fruit, Pind.

div1.head: κλυτόμητις
div1.sense: famous for skill, Hhymn.

div1.head: κλυτόμοχθος
div1.sense: famous for toils, Anth.

div1.head: κλυτόνοος
div1.sense: famous for wisdom, Anth.

div1.head: κλυτόπαις
div1.sense: with famous children, Anth.

div1.head: κλυτόπωλος
div1.sense: with noble steeds, Il.

div1.head: κλυτός
div1.sense: heard of, i. e. famous, renowned, glorious, of persons, Hom.
of things, noble, splendid, beauteous, Hom., etc.

div1.head: κλυτοτέχνης
div1.sense: famous for his art, renowned artist, Hom.

div1.head: κλυτότοξος
div1.sense: famous for the bow, renowned archer, Hom.

div1.head: κλύω
div1.sense: to hear, Hom., etc.; κλύειν τί τινος to hear a thing from a person, Il., etc.; then, κλύειν τινος to hear him, Il.; κλ. τι to hear it, Od., etc.:—c. gen. objecti, to hear of a person or thing, Soph.
to perceive generally, know, Od., Hes.

to give ear to, attend to, τινός Hom., etc.; the imperat. is esp. used in prayers, give ear to me, hear me, κλῦθί μευ, Ἀργυρότοξε Il.; κέκλυτέ μευ, θεοί Il.:—also c. dat. to listen to, obey, Hes., etc.
in Trag. like ἀκούω V. to be called or spoken of so and so, with an adv., εὖ or κακῶς κλύειν.

div1.head: κλωβός
div1.sense: a bird-cage, Anth.

div1.head: κλωγμός
div1.sense: the clucking of hens: the clucking sound by which we urge on a horse, Xen.

div1.head: κλώζω
div1.sense: to croak, of jackdaws:—then, in sign of disapprobation, to hoot, Dem.

div1.head: Κλῶθες
div1.sense: the spinners, a name of the Parcae or goddesses of fate, Od.

div1.head: Κλωθώ
div1.sense: spinster, one of the three Μοῖραι or Parcae, who spins the thread of life, Hes.; Lachesis had charge of the past, Clotho of the present, Atropos of the future, Plat., Luc.

div1.head: κλώθω
div1.sense: to twist by spinning, spin, Hdt., Luc.:—Pass., τὰ κλωσθέντα oneʼs destiny, Plat.

div1.head: κλωμακόεις
div1.sense: stony, rocky, Il.

div1.head: κλῶμαξ
div1.sense: a heap of stones,

div1.head: κλών
div1.sense: a twig, spray, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: κλωπεύω
div1.sense: to steal, Xen.

div1.head: κλωπικός
div1.sense: thievish, clandestine, Eur.

div1.head: κλώσσω
div1.sense: to cluck like a hen.

div1.head: κλωστήρ
div1.sense: a spindle, Theocr.
a thread, yarn, line, Ar.; λίνου κλ. the flaxen thread, i. e. the net, Aesch.

div1.head: κλωστής
div1.sense: a web, Eur.

div1.head: κλώψ
div1.sense: a thief, Hdt., Eur., Xen.

div1.head: κνάπτω
div1.sense: to card or dress cloth, (which was done either with a prickly plant, the teasel, or with a comb):—of torture, to card, lacerate, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: κναφεῖον
div1.sense: a fullerʼs shop, Hdt.

div1.head: κναφεύς
div1.sense: a fuller, i. e. a cloth-dresser, clothes-cleaner, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: κναφεύω
div1.sense: to clean cloth, Ar.

div1.head: κνάφος
div1.sense: the prickly teasel, a plant used by fullers to dress cloth.
a carding-comb, also used as an instrument of torture, Hdt.

div1.head: κνάω
div1.sense: to scrape or grate, Lat. radere, Il.; τὸν κηρὸν κνᾶν to scrape it off, Hdt.
to scratch:— Mid. to scratch oneself, Plat.
to tickle, Plat.; Mid., κνᾶσθαι τὰ ὦτα to tickle oneʼs ears, Luc.

div1.head: κνεφάζω
div1.sense: to cloud over, obscure, Aesch.

div1.head: κνεφαῖος
div1.sense: dark, dusky, Aesch., Eur.
in the dark, early in the morning, Ar.

div1.head: κνέφας
div1.sense: darkness, evening dusk, twilight, Il., Aesch.; also, τὸ κατὰ γῆς κν. Eur.
later, the morning twilight or dawn, Lat. diluculum, κνέφᾳ at dawn, Xen.

div1.head: κνήθω
div1.sense: to scratch, tickle:—Pass. to itch, NTest.

div1.head: κνηκός
div1.sense: pale yellow, tawny, Theocr., Anth.: hence the goat is called κνάκων, ὁ, Theocr.; and the wolf κνηκίας, Babr.

div1.head: κνήμαργος
div1.sense: white-legged, Theocr.

div1.head: κνήμη
div1.sense: the part between the knee and ankle, the leg, Lat. tibia, Hom., Hdt., Eur., etc.

div1.head: κνημιδοφόρος
div1.sense: wearing greaves, Hdt.

div1.head: κνημίς
div1.sense: a greave or piece of armour from knee to ankle, Lat. ocrea, περὶ κνήμῃσιν ἔθηκεν Il.; the κνημῖδες were fastened at the ankle with clasps (ἐπισφύρια) : βόειαι κνημῖδες are ox-hide leggings, used by labourers, Od.

div1.head: κνημός
div1.sense: the projecting limb or (as we say) shoulder of a mountain, Hom.

div1.head: κνησιάω
div1.sense: Desiderat. of κνάω, to wish to scratch, to feel an itching, to itch, Plat.

div1.head: κνησίχρυσος
div1.sense: scraping or gnawing gold, Anth.

div1.head: κνῆσμα
div1.sense: a sting, bite, Xen.

div1.head: κνησμός
div1.sense: an itching, irritation, Plut.

div1.head: κνῆστις
div1.sense: a knife for scraping cheese, Il.

div1.head: κνίδη
div1.sense: a nettle, Lat. urtica, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: Κνίδιος
div1.sense: of or from Cnidos; οἱ Κνίδιοι the Cnidians, Hdt.

div1.head: κνίζω
div1.sense: to scrape or grate: to tickle: metaph., of love, to nettle, chafe, irritate, Hdt., Eur.; of satiety, Pind.; of anxiety, Hdt., etc.; οὐ κνίσω τὸ ῥῆμʼ ἕκαστον will not attack every word, Ar.:—Pass., κνίζεσθαί τινος to be stung (with love) for one, Theocr.
κν. ὀργάν to provoke anger, Pind.

div1.head: κνιπός
div1.sense: niggardly, Anth.

div1.head: κνῖσα
div1.sense: Lat. nidor, the steam and odour which exhales from roasting meat, the savour and steam of burnt sacrifice, which ascends up to heaven as a gift to the gods, Hom.
that which caused this smell and steam, i. e. the fat, in which the flesh of the victim was wrapped and burnt, μηρούς τʼ ἐξέταμον κατά τε κνίσῃ ἐκάλυψαν Il.

div1.head: κνισάω
div1.sense: to fill with the steam or savour of burnt sacrifice, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: κνισήεις
div1.sense: full of the steam of burnt sacrifice, steamy, Od.

div1.head: κνίσμα
div1.sense: in pl. scrapings, Plat.
scratches, Anth.: quarrels, Anth.

div1.head: κνισμός
div1.sense: an itching of the skin, tickling, Ar.

div1.head: κνισόω
div1.sense: to reduce to vapour, Luc.

div1.head: κνισωτός
div1.sense: steaming, of a sacrifice, Aesch.

div1.head: κνίψ
div1.sense: like σκνίψ, a small insect which gnaws figs, Ar.

div1.head: κνυζέομαι
div1.sense: Dep. properly of a dog, to whine, whimper, Soph., Ar.

div1.head: κνυζηθμός
div1.sense: a whining, whimpering, Od.

div1.head: κνύζημα
div1.sense: = κνυζηθμός of infants, Lat. vagitus, Hdt.

div1.head: κνυζόω
div1.sense: to disfigure the eyes, make dim and dark Od.

div1.head: κνώδαλον
div1.sense: any dangerous animal, from a lion to a serpent or worm, a monster, beast, Od., Hes., Trag.: —of persons, as a term of reproach, ὦ παντομισῆ κνώδαλα Aesch.

div1.head: κνώδων
div1.sense: in pl. κνώδοντες, two projecting teeth on the blade of a hunting spear, Xen.; ξίφους διπλοῖ κνώδοντες, i. e. a two-edged sword, Soph.: also κνώδων alone for a sword, Soph.

div1.head: κνώσσω
div1.sense: to slumber, sleep, Od., Pind.

div1.head: κοάλεμος
div1.sense: a stupid fellow, booby, Ar.

div1.head: κοάξ
div1.sense: Comic word, to express the croaking of frogs, βρεκεκεκὲξ κοὰξ κοάξ Ar.

div1.head: κοβαλίκευμα
div1.sense: a knavish trick, Ar.

div1.head: κόβαλος
div1.sense: an impudent rogue, arrant knave, Ar.: —Κόβαλοι were mischievous goblins, invoked by rogues, Ar. II. as adj. κόβαλα, knavish tricks, rogues, Ar.
as adj. κόβαλα, knavish tricks,

div1.head: κόγχη
div1.sense: a mussel or cockle, Lat. concha, Xen.
the case round a seal attached to diplomas or documents, Ar.

div1.head: κογχυλιάτης
div1.sense: full of shells, λίθος κογχ. shelly marble, Xen.

div1.head: κογχύλιον
div1.sense: a small kind of mussel or cockle, Arist.
its shell, any bivalve-shell, Hdt.

div1.head: κοδράντης
div1.sense: the Lat. quadrans, = 1/4 of an as, NTest.

div1.head: κοέω
div1.sense: to mark, perceive, hear, Anacr.

div1.head: κόθορνος
div1.sense: Lat. cothurnus, a buskin or high boot, reaching to the middle of the leg, Hdt., etc. The κόθορνος was worn by tragic actors, its heels serving to add height to the figure: thus it became the emblem of Tragedy, as the soccus of Comedy.
since the buskins might be worn on either foot, ὁ Κόθορνος was a nickname for a trimmer or timeserver, such as Theramenes, Xen.

div1.head: κόθουρος
div1.sense: of drones, dock-tailed, i. e. without a sting, Hes.
div1.etym: Prob. from κοθώ an old word for βλάβη, and οὐρά tail.

div1.head: κοΐζω
div1.sense: to cry κοΐ, squeak like a young pig, Ar.

div1.head: κοίῃ
div1.etym: Ionic for ποίᾳ, dat. sg. of ποῖος, Ionic κοῖος
div1.sense: used as adv. how? in what way? in what respect? Hdt.

div1.head: κοιλαίνω
div1.sense: to make hollow, scoop out, Hdt.; κ. χῶμα, i. e. to dig a grave, Theocr.

div1.head: κοιλάς
div1.sense: a hollow, deep valley, Anth.

div1.head: Κοίλη
div1.etym: fem. of κοῖλος, name of a δῆμος in Attica, Hdt.

div1.head: κοιλία
div1.sense: the large cavity of the body, the belly, Lat. venter, Hdt., Ar., etc.
the intestines, bowels, Hdt.; κ. ὑεία pigʼs tripe, Ar.; in pl. tripe and puddings, Ar.

div1.head: κοιλιοπώλης
div1.sense: a tripe-seller, Ar.

div1.head: κοιλογάστωρ
div1.sense: hollow-bellied, hungry, Aesch.: metaph. a hollow shield, Aesch.

div1.head: κοιλόπεδος
div1.sense: lying in a hollow, Pind.

div1.head: κοῖλος
div1.sense: hollow, hollowed, epith. of ships, which in early times were hollowed out of trees, Hom.; later, κοίλη ναῦς was the hold of the ship, Hdt., Xen.; so, ἡ κοίλη alone, Theocr.:—of the Trojan horse, κ. λόχος, κ. δόρυ Od.; κ. κάπετος, of a grave, Il.; κ. δέμνια, of the bed when no one is in it, Soph.

of Places, lying in a hollow or forming a hollow, κοίλη Λακεδαίμων the vale of L., Od.; κ. Θεσσαλία Hdt.; κ. Ἄργος Soph.; τὰ Κοῖλα τῆς Εὐβοίας Hdt.; ἡ Κοιλή the valley of the Ilissus, Hdt.:— κ. λιμήν of a harbour lying between high cliffs, Od.; κ. αἰγιαλός an embayed beach, Od.:— κ. ὁδός a hollow way, Il.:— κ. ποταμός a river nearly empty of water, Thuc. (so Virgil, cava flumina): metaph. of the voice, hollow, μυκάσατο κοῖλον Theocr.; φθέγγεσθαι κοῖλον Luc.
as Subst. κοῖλον, ου, τό, a hollow, cavity, ravine, Plat.; like κοιλία, of the cavities in the body, τὰ κ. γαστρός Eur.; also, ἐν τῷ κοίλῳ καὶ μυχῷ τοῦ λιμένος Thuc.

div1.head: κοιλόφθαλμος
div1.sense: hollow-eyed, Xen.

div1.head: κοιλοχείλης
div1.sense: hollow-rimmed, Anth.

div1.head: κοιλώδης
div1.sense: hollow-like, cavernous, φάραγξ Babr.

div1.head: κοίλωμα
div1.sense: a hollow, cavity, Babr., etc.

div1.head: κοιλώπης
div1.sense: hollow-eyed: fem. κοιλῶπις, ιδος, Anth.

div1.head: κοιλωπός
div1.sense: hollow to look at: hollow, Eur.

div1.head: κοιμάω
div1.sense: to lull or hush to sleep, put to sleep, Hom.
metaph. to lull to rest, still, calm, ἀνέμους, κύματα Hom.; ὀδύνας Il.; κοίμησον εὔφημον στόμα lay thy tongue asleep in silence, Aesch.
Mid. and Pass. to fall asleep, go or lie abed, Hom., Hdt., etc.
of the sleep of death, κοιμήσατο χάλκεον ὕπνον he slept an iron sleep, Il.: absol. to fall asleep, die, Soph., NTest.
to keep watch at night, Lat. excubare, Aesch., Xen.

div1.head: κοίμημα
div1.sense: sleep, κοιμήματα αὐτογέννητα intercourse of the mother with her own child, Soph.

div1.head: κοίμησις
div1.sense: a lying down to sleep, Plat., NTest.

div1.head: κοιμίζω
div1.sense: to put to sleep, Eur.; ἄημα ἐκοίμισε πόντον, i. e. the winds suffer the sea to rest— by ceasing (cf. Virg. straverunt aequora venti), Soph.: metaph., μεγαληγορίαν κ. to lay pride asleep, Eur.; so, κ. τὰς λύπας Xen.:—Pass., παῖς κοιμίζεται Eur.
of the sleep of death, Soph., Eur.; also in Mid., Eur.

div1.head: κοιμιστής
div1.sense: one who puts to bed, Anth.

div1.head: κοινῇ
div1.etym: dat. fem. of κοινός, used as adv., v. κοινός B. II.

div1.head: κοινοβουλέω
div1.sense: to deliberate in common, Xen.

div1.head: κοινόλεκτρος
div1.sense: having a common bed, a bedfellow, consort, Aesch.

div1.head: κοινολεχής
div1.sense: a paramour, Soph.

div1.head: κοινολογέομαι
div1.sense: to commune or take counsel with, τινι Hdt., Attic; πρός τινα Thuc.

div1.head: κοινόπλοος
div1.sense: sailing in common, Soph.

div1.head: κοινόπους
div1.sense: of common foot, κ. παρουσία, i. e. the arrival of persons all together, Soph.

div1.head: κοινός
div1.sense: common, shared in common, opp. to ἴδιος, Hes., Attic; proverb., κοινὸν τύχη Aesch.; κοινὰ τὰ τῶν φίλων Eur.
c. dat., κ. τινι common to or with another, Aesch.; also c. gen., πάντων κ. φάος Aesch.
common to all the people, common, public, general, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
τὸ κοινόν the state, Lat. respublica, Hdt., Attic
the government, public authorities, Thuc., Xen.; ἀπὸ τοῦ κοινοῦ by public authority, Hdt.; ἄνευ τοῦ τῶν πάντων κοινοῦ without consent of the league, Thuc.
the public treasury, Hdt., Thuc.
τὰ κοινά public affairs, Oratt.; πρὸς τὰ κοινὰ προσελθεῖν, προσιέναι to enter public life, Dem., etc.; also the public money, Ar.
common, ordinary, usual, Plat., etc.
of Persons, of common origin or kindred, esp. of brothers and sisters, Pind., Soph.
like κοινωνός, a partner, Soph., Ar.
lending a ready ear to all, impartial, Thuc., Plat.:— courteous, affable, Xen.
of events, κοινότεραι τύχαι more impartial (i. e. more equal) chances, Thuc.
of meats, common, profane, NTest.
adv. κοινῶς, in common, jointly, opp. to ἰδίᾳ, Eur., etc.
publicly, Thuc., etc.
sociably, like other citizens, Arist., Plut.
in common language or fashion, Plut.
so fem. dat. κοινῇ, in common, by common consent, in concert, Hdt., Soph., Eur.
publicly, Xen.
so with Preps., ἐς κοινόν in common, Aesch.; εἰς τὸ κ. for common use, Plat.

div1.head: κοινότης
div1.sense: a sharing in common, community, partnership, Plat., etc.
affability, Xen.

div1.head: κοινότοκος
div1.sense: of or from common parents, ἐλπίδες κ. hopes in one born of the same parents, i. e. a brother, Soph.

div1.head: κοινοφιλής
div1.sense: loving in common, Aesch.

div1.head: κοινόφρων
div1.sense: like-minded with, τινί Eur.

div1.head: κοινόω
div1.sense: to make common, communicate, impart a thing to another, κ. τί τινι Aesch., Eur., etc.; τι ἔς τινα Eur.
to make common, to defile, profane, NTest.: —Mid. to deem or pronounce profane, NTest.
Mid. to communicate one to another, Aesch., Soph.
to cause to be communicated, τί τινι Plat.
to take counsel with, τινι Xen.
to be partner or partaker, τινος of a thing, Eur.
c. acc. rei, to take part or share in, Eur., Thuc.
Pass. to have intercourse with, Eur.

div1.head: κοινωνέω
div1.sense: to have or do in common with, have a share of or take part in a thing with another, τινός τινι Xen.
κ. τινός to have a share of or take part in a thing, Trag., Xen.
κ. τινι to have dealings with or intercourse, Ar., Plat.
rarely c. acc. rei, κ. φόνον τινι to commit murder in common with him, Eur.
absol. to share in an opinion, to agree, Plat.:— to form a community, Arist.

div1.head: κοινώνημα
div1.sense: in pl. acts of communion, communications, dealings between man and man, Plat.

div1.head: κοινωνητέος
div1.sense: one must give a share, Plat.

div1.head: κοινωνία
div1.sense: communion, association, partnership, fellowship, Pind., Thuc., etc.
c. gen. objecti, communion with, partnership in, Eur., etc.; τίς θαλάσσης βουκόλοις κ.; what communion have herdsmen with the sea? Eur.
a common gift, contribution, alms, NTest.

div1.head: κοινωνικός
div1.sense: held in common, social, Arist.
giving a share, τινος of a thing, Luc.

div1.head: κοινωνός
div1.sense: a companion, partner, τινος in a thing, Aesch., etc.; ὁ τοῦ κακοῦ κ. accomplice in the evil, Soph.; also, τινι in a thing, Eur.
absol. a partner, fellow, Plat., Dem.
as adj. = κοινός, Eur.

div1.head: κοΐ
div1.sense: Comic word, to express the squeaking of young pigs, Ar.

div1.head: κοιρανέω
div1.sense: to be lord or master, to rule, command, Hom.
c. gen. to be lord of, Hes., Aesch.; also, c. dat., Aesch.

div1.head: κοιρανία
div1.sense: sovereignty, Anth.

div1.head: κοίρανος
div1.sense: a ruler, commander, Hom., Trag.

div1.head: κοιτάζω
div1.sense: to put to bed:—Mid., Doric aor1 ἐκοιταξάμην, to go to bed, sleep, Pind.

div1.head: κοιταῖος
div1.sense: in bed, ap. Dem.
as Subst., κοιταῖον, ου, τό, the lair of a wild beast, Plut.

div1.head: κοίτη
div1.sense: the marriage-bed, Soph., Eur.
the lair of a beast, nest of a bird, Eur.
the act of going to bed, τῆς κοίτης ὥρη bed- time, Hdt.; τραπέζῃ καὶ κοίτῃ δέκεσθαι to entertain "at bed and board, " Hdt.
ἔχειν κοίτην ἔκ τινος to be pregnant by a man, NTest.:—in bad sense, chambering, lasciviousness, NTest.

div1.head: κοῖτος
div1.sense: a place to lie on, bed, Od.
sleep, Od., Hes.

div1.head: κοιτών
div1.sense: a bed-chamber, ὁ ἐπὶ τοῦ κοιτῶνος a chamberlain, praefectus cubiculi, NTest.

div1.head: κόκκινος
div1.sense: scarlet, Lat. coccineus, Plut., NTest.

div1.head: κόκκος
div1.sense: a grain, seed, Hhymn., Hdt.
the kermesberry, used to dye scarlet, Theophr.

div1.head: κοκκύζω
div1.sense: to cry cuckoo, Hes.; of the cock, to crow, Theocr.
to cry like a cuckoo, give a signal by such cry, Ar.

div1.head: κόκκυξ
div1.sense: a cuckoo, so called from its cry κόκκυ, Lat. cuculus, Hes., Ar., etc.; ἐχειροτόνησάν με κόκκυγές γε τρεῖς I was elected by three cuckoo-voices, i. e. by three who gave their votes over and over again, Ar.

div1.head: κόκκυ
div1.sense: properly cuckoo! the birdʼs cry, used as an exclamation, now! quick! κόκκυ, πεδίονδε Ar.; κόκκυ, μεθεῖτε quick— let go, Ar.

div1.head: κόκκων
div1.sense: a pomegranate-seed, Solon.

div1.head: κοκύαι
div1.sense: ancestors, Anth.

div1.head: κολάζω
div1.etym: Prob. from κόλος, akin to κολούω
div1.sense: Properly, to curtail, dock, prune: then, like Lat. castigare, to keep within bounds, check, correct, Plat.:—perf. pass. part. chastened, Arist.
to chastise, punish, Soph., Eur., etc.:—Mid. to get a person punished, Ar., Plat.:—Pass. to be punished, Xen.

div1.head: κολακεία
div1.sense: flattery, fawning, Plat., Aeschin.

div1.head: κολάκευμα
div1.sense: a piece of flattery, Xen.

div1.head: κολακευτέος
div1.sense: to be flattered, Luc.

div1.head: κολακευτικός
div1.sense: disposed to flatter, flattering, fawning, Luc.: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) = κολακεία, Plat.

div1.head: κολακεύω
div1.sense: to flatter, Ar., Xen., etc.:— Pass. to be flattered, be open to flattery, Dem.

div1.head: Κολακώνυμος
div1.sense: parasite-named, Comic distortion of the name Κλε-ώνυμος, Ar.

div1.head: κόλαξ
div1.sense: a flatterer, fawner, Ar., Plat., etc.

div1.head: κολαπτήρ
div1.sense: a chisel, Luc.

div1.head: κολάπτω
div1.sense: of birds, to peck at, Luc., Anth.:—of Pegasus, to strike the ground with his hoof, Anth.
to carve or chisel, Anth.

div1.head: κόλασις
div1.sense: chastisement, correction, punishment, Plat., etc.

div1.head: κόλασμα
div1.sense: chastisement, Xen.

div1.head: κολαστέος
div1.sense: to be chastised, Plat.
κολαστέον, one must chastised, Plat.

div1.head: κολαστήριον
div1.sense: a house of correction, Luc.
= κόλασμα, κόλασις, Xen.

div1.head: κολαστής
div1.sense: a chastiser, punisher, Trag.

div1.head: κολαστικός
div1.sense: corrective, Plat.

div1.head: κολαφίζω
div1.sense: to buffet, NTest.

div1.head: κολεόν
div1.sense: a sheath, scabbard of a sword, Lat. culeus, Hom., Attic

div1.head: κολετράω
div1.sense: to trample on, τινα Ar.

div1.head: κόλλαβος
div1.sense: = κόλλοψ, Luc.
a kind of cake or roll, Ar.

div1.head: κόλλα
div1.sense: glue, Lat. gluten, Hdt.

div1.head: κολλάω
div1.sense: to glue, cement, Ar., Plat.
to join one metal to another, κ. χρυσὸν ἐλέφαντά τε, i. e. to make [a crown] inlaid with gold and ivory, Pind.

generally, to join fast together:— Pass. to cleave to, κεκόλληται πρὸς ἄτᾳ is indissolubly bound to woe, Aesch.; so, of persons, κ. τινι to cleave to another, NTest.; and of things, ὁ κονιορτὸς ὁ κολληθείς τινι NTest.
to put together, build, Pind.

div1.head: κόλλησις
div1.sense: a glueing or welding, κ. σιδήρου a welding of iron, Lat. ferruminatio, or perhaps the art of inlaying or damasking iron, Hdt., Theophr.

div1.head: κολλητός
div1.sense: glued together, closely joined, well-framed, Hom., Eur., etc.
ὑποκρητηρίδιον κολλητόν a stand welded to the κρητήρ, Hdt.

div1.head: κολλικοφάγος
div1.sense: roll-eating, Ar.

sense.trans: a roll or loaf of coarse bread.

div1.head: κόλλοψ
div1.sense: the peg or screw by which the strings of the lyre were tightened, Od., Plat.:—metaph., τῆς ὀργῆς τὸν κόλλοπʼ ἀνιέναι to let down the strings of your passion, Ar.

div1.head: κολλυβιστής
div1.sense: a small money-changer, NTest.

div1.head: κόλλυβος
div1.sense: a small coin, κολλύβου for a doit, Ar.
in pl. κόλλυβα, τά, small round cakes, Ar.

div1.head: κολλύριον
div1.sense: eye-salve, Lat. collyrium.
a fine clay, in which a seal can be impressed, Luc.

div1.head: κολοβός
div1.sense: docked, curtailed, c. gen., κολοβὸς κεράτων, Lat. truncus pedum, Plat.; κ. χειρῶν Anth.
absol. maimed, mutilated, Xen.

div1.head: κολοβόω
div1.sense: to dock, curtail, shorten, NTest.

div1.head: κολοίαρχος
div1.sense: a chief of jackdaws, jackdaw-general, Ar.

div1.head: κολοιός
div1.sense: a jackdaw, daw, Lat. graculus, Il., Pind., Ar.: proverbs: κολοιὸς ποτὶ κολοιόν "birds of a feather flock together, " Arist.; κολοιὸς ἀλλοτρίοις πτεροῖς ἀγάλλεται a jackdaw "in borrowed plumes, " Luc.

div1.head: κολόκυμα
div1.sense: a large heavy wave before it breaks (κόλον κῦμα) , the swell that foreruns a storm, Ar.

div1.head: κολοκύνθη
div1.sense: a pumpkin, Lat. cucurbita.

div1.head: κολοκυνθιάς
div1.sense: made from pumpkins, Anth.

div1.head: κολοκύνθινος
div1.sense: made from pumpkins, πλοῖα Luc.

div1.head: κόλον
div1.sense: the colon or lower intestine, Ar.

div1.head: κόλος
div1.sense: docked, curtal, Lat. curtus, Il.;of oxen, stump-horned or hornless, Hdt.; so, ὦ κόλε, addressed to a he-goat, Theocr.

div1.head: κολοσσός
div1.sense: a colossus, of the huge statues in the Egypt. temples, Hdt.: generally a statue, Aesch., Theocr. The most famous Colossus was that of Apollo at Rhodes, 70 cubits high, made in the time of Demetrius Poliorcetes, Luc.

div1.head: κολοσυρτός
div1.sense: poet. word, a noisy rabble, Il., Ar.

div1.head: κόλουρος
div1.sense: dock-tailed, Plut.

div1.head: κόλουσις
div1.sense: a docking, cutting short, Arist.

div1.head: κολούω
div1.sense: to cut short, dock, curtail, Hdt.

metaph. to cut off, disappoint, τὸ μὲν τελέει, τὸ δὲ κολούει part he brings to pass, part he cuts off, of the threats of Achilles, Il.; μηδὲ τὰ δῶρα κολούετε curtail them not, Od.:—of persons, τὰ ὑπερέχοντα κ. to cut down, degrade, those who are exalted above others, Hdt.:—Pass. to be cut short or abridged, Aesch.; ἐπειδὰν κολουθῶσι when they suffer abatement, Thuc.

div1.head: κολοφών
div1.sense: a summit, top, finishing, κολοφῶνα ἐπιτιθέναι, to put the finishing stroke to a thing, Plat.

div1.head: κολπίας
div1.sense: swelling in folds, Aesch.

div1.head: κόλπος
div1.sense: Lat. sinus:
the bosom, Il.
the womb, Eur.

the fold formed by a loose garment, as it fell over the girdle, Il.:—this fold sometimes served for a pocket, Od., Hdt.; κόλπον ἀνιεμένη letting down her robe so as to form a fold, i. e. baring her breast, Il.; κόλπῳ πεπλώματος under the deep-folded robe, Aesch.; ἐπὶ σφυρὰ κόλπον ἀνεῖσαι having let their folded robes fall down to their ankles, Theocr.
any hollow, as
of the sea, first, in a half-literal sense, Θέτις ὑπεδέξατο κόλπῳ received him in her bosom, Il.; then, of the deep hollow between waves, Hom.
a bay or gulf of the sea, Il., Aesch.
a vale, κ. Ἀργεῖος Pind.; Ἐλευσινίας Δηοῦς ἐν κόλποις Soph.

div1.head: κολπόω
div1.sense: to form into a swelling fold; esp. to make a sail belly or swell, Lat. sinuare, ἄνεμος κ. τὴν ὀθόνην Luc.; χιτῶνας κολπώσαντες τῷ ἀνέμῳ, καθάπερ ἱστία Luc.:—Pass. to bosom or swell out, of a sail, Mosch.; κολποῦται Ζέφυρος εἰς ὀθόνας Anth.; of a bay, to curve, Polyb.

div1.head: κολπώδης
div1.sense: embosomed, embayed, Eur.

div1.head: κόλπωμα
div1.sense: a folded garment, Plut.

div1.head: κολυμβάω
div1.sense: to plunge into the sea, NTest.

div1.head: κολυμβήθρα
div1.sense: a swimming-bath, Plat.

div1.head: κολυμβητής
div1.sense: a diver, Thuc., Plat., etc.

div1.head: κολυμβίς
div1.sense: a sea-bird, a diver, Ar.

div1.head: κόλυμβος
div1.sense: a diver, Ar.

div1.head: Κόλχος
div1.sense: a Colchian, Hdt., etc.:—adj. Κολχικός, ή, όν, Colchian, Hdt.:—fem. Κολχίς, ίδος, and as Subst. Κολχίς ( sub. γῆ) , Eur.

div1.head: κολῳάω
div1.sense: to brawl, scold, Il.

div1.head: Κολωνῆθεν
div1.sense: from the deme Κολωνός (q. v.), Dem.

div1.head: κολώνη
div1.sense: a hill, mound, Il.: esp. a sepulchral mound, barrow, Lat. tumulus, Soph.

div1.head: κολωνία
div1.sense: the Lat. colonia, NTest.

div1.head: κολωνός
div1.sense: a hill, Hhymn., Hdt.; κ. λίθων a heap of stones, Hdt.
Colonus, a deme of Attica lying on a hill, about a mile NW. of Athens, immortalised by Sophocles, who was a native of it, in his Oed. Col.

div1.head: κολῳός
div1.sense: a brawling, wrangling, Il.

div1.head: κόμαρος
div1.sense: the strawberry-tree, arbutus, Ar.

div1.head: κομαροφάγος
div1.sense: eating the fruit of the arbutus, Ar.

div1.head: κομάω
div1.sense: to let the hair grow long, wear long hair, Il.; κομέειν τὴν κεφαλήν Hdt. In early times the Greeks wore their hair long, whence κάρη κομόωντες Ἀχαιοί in Hom. At Sparta the fashion continued. At Athens it was so worn by youths up to the 18th year, when they offered their long locks to some deity; and to wear long hair was considered as a sign of aristocratic habits: hence

κομᾶν meant to plume oneself, give oneself airs, be proud or haughty, like Lat. cristam tollere, Ar.; οὗτος ἐκόμησε ἐπὶ τυραννίδι he aimed at the monarchy, Hdt.; ἐπὶ τῷ κομᾷς; on what do you plume yourself? Ar.
of horses, χρυσέῃσιν ἐθείρῃσιν κομόωντε decked with golden manes, Il.
metaph. of trees, plants, foliage, Hhymn., etc.

div1.head: κομέω
div1.sense: to take care of, attend to, tend, Hom.

div1.head: κόμη
div1.sense: the hair, hair of the head, Lat. coma, Hom., etc.; also in pl., Hom.: —κόμην τρέφειν to let the hair grow long, Hdt.; κόμην κείρεσθαι to shave off the hair, in mourning, Od., etc.; κόμαι πρόσθετοι false hair, a wig, Xen.
metaph. the foliage, leaves of trees, Od.

div1.head: Κομηταμυνίας
div1.sense: Comic adaptation of the name ὁ Αμυνίας, coxcomb-Amynias (cf. κομάω) , Ar.

div1.head: κομήτης
div1.sense: wearing long hair, long-haired, ap. Hdt., Ar.
metaph., ἰὸς κ. a feathered arrow, Soph.; λειμὼν κ. a grassy meadow, Eur.
as Subst. a comet, Arist.

div1.head: κομιδή
div1.sense: attendance, care, in Il., always of care bestowed on horses; in Od., of care bestowed on men, by means of baths, etc.; also, care bestowed on a garden, Od.
provision, supplies, Od.
carriage, conveyance, importation, Thuc.: a gathering in of harvest, Xen.
(from Mid. also) a carrying away for oneself, a recovery, Hdt.:— the recovery of a debt, payment, Dem.
(from Pass.) a going or coming, Hdt.: an escape, safe return, Hdt.

div1.head: κομιδῇ
div1.sense: exactly, just, Plat., Dem.
like πάνυ, absolutely, altogether, quite, Plat.; οὐ κομιδῇ not at all, Plut.
in answers, κομιδῇ μὲν οὖν just so, yes certainly, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: κομίζω
div1.sense: to take care of, provide for, Hom.:— to receive hospitably, to entertain, Thuc.; more commonly in Mid., Hom.
of things, to mind, attend to, give heed to, Hom., etc.; ἔξω κομίζειν πηλοῦ πόδα to keep oneʼs foot out of the mud, Aesch.
to carry away so as to preserve, carry home, carry safe away, Il., etc.; simply, to save, rescue, τινὰ ἐκ θανάτου Pind.; but, νεκρὸν κ. to carry out to burial, Soph., Eur.
to carry off as a prize or as booty, Il., Pind.:—Mid. to get for oneself, receive in full, acquire, gain, Soph., etc.
to carry, convey, bear, Hom., etc.:—Pass. to be conveyed, to journey, travel, Hdt.; εἴσω κομίζου get thee in, Aesch.; so in fut. and aor1 mid., κομιεύμεθα ἐς Σίριν Hdt., etc.
to bring to a place, bring hither, bring in, καρπὸν κ. to gather in corn, Hdt., etc.:—so in Mid., Hdt., Soph.; and perf. pass. in mid. sense, τοὺς καρποὺς κεκόμισθε you have reaped the fruits, Dem.
to conduct, escort, Soph., Plat., etc.; κ. ναῦς Thuc.
to get back, recover, Pind., Eur., Plat., etc.:—Mid. to get back for oneself, recover, Eur., Thuc.; κομίζεσθαι χρήματα to recover a debt, Dem.:—Pass. to come or go back, return, Hdt., Attic
like Lat. affero, to bring, give, Aesch.

div1.head: κομιστέος
div1.sense: to be taken care of, to be gathered in, Aesch.
κομιστέον, one must bring, Plat.

div1.head: κομιστής
div1.sense: one who takes care of, Eur.
a bringer, conductor, Eur.

div1.head: κόμιστρον
div1.sense: in pl., like σῶστρα, reward for saving, Aesch.
reward for bringing, Eur.

div1.head: κόμμα
div1.sense: the stamp or impression of a coin, Ar.: proverb., πονηροῦ κόμματος of bad stamp, Ar.
= νόμισμα, coin, coinage, Ar.
a short clause of a sentence, Lat. comma, Cic.

div1.head: κομματικός
div1.sense: consisting of short clauses, μικρὰ καὶ κ. ἐρωτήματα Luc.

div1.head: κόμμι
div1.sense: gum, Lat. gummi, Hdt.

div1.head: κομμός
div1.sense: a striking: esp. like Lat. planctus (from plango), a beating of the breast in lamentation, ἔκοψα κομμὸν Ἄριον I lamented with Median lamentation, Aesch.
in Attic Drama, a wild lament, sung alternately by an actor and the chorus, such as Aesch. Ag. 1072-1185.

div1.head: κομμόω
div1.sense: to beautify, Arist.

div1.head: κομμωτής
div1.sense: a beautifier, embellisher, Luc.

div1.head: κομμωτικός
div1.sense: of or for embellishment:— ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , the art of embellishment, Plat.

div1.head: κομμώτρια
div1.sense: a dresser, tirewoman, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: κομπάζω
div1.sense: to vaunt, boast, brag, Trag.; c. acc. cogn., κ. λόγον to speak big words, Aesch.

to boast of, κ. γέρας to boast oneʼs office, Aesch.:—Pass. to be renowned, Eur.; φόβος κομπάζεται fear is loudly spoken, Aesch.; τινὸς δὲ παῖς πατρὸς κομπάζεται; of what father is he said to be the son? Eur.

div1.head: Κομπασεύς
div1.sense: Com. word, one of the Κόμποσ- deme, a bragsman, Ar.

div1.head: κόμπασμα
div1.sense: in pl. boasts, braggart words, Aesch., Ar.

div1.head: κομπαστής
div1.sense: a braggart, Plut.

div1.head: κομπέω
div1.sense: to ring, clash, κόμπει χαλκός Il.
metaph., like κομπάζω, to speak big, boast, brag, vaunt, Hdt., Eur.; c. acc. cogn., κ. μῦθον to speak a boastful speech, Soph.
c. acc. to boast of, Aesch.:—Pass., to be boasted of, Thuc.

div1.head: κομπολακέω
div1.sense: to talk big, be an empty braggart, Ar.

div1.head: κόμπος
div1.sense: a noise, din, clash, as of a boarʼs tusks when he whets them, Il.; the stamping of dancersʼ feet, Od.
metaph. a boast, vaunt, Hdt., Aesch., etc.
rarely in good sense, praise, Pind.

div1.head: κομποφακελορρήμων
div1.sense: pomp-bundle-worded, derisive epith. of Aeschylus in Ar.

div1.head: κομπώδης
div1.sense: boastful, vainglorious, Thuc.; τὸ κομπῶδες boastfulness, Thuc.

div1.head: κομψεία
div1.sense: refinement, esp. of language, Plat.

div1.head: κομψευριπικῶς
div1.sense: with Euripides-prettinesses (shortened from κομψευριπιδικῶς) , Ar.

div1.head: κομψεύω
div1.sense: to refine upon, quibble upon, κόμψευε νῦν τὴν δόξαν aye, quibble on the word δόξα (referring to the previous line), Soph.:—Mid. to deal in refinements or subtleties, Plat.

div1.head: κομψοπρεπής
div1.sense: dainty-seeming, Ar.

div1.head: κομψός
div1.sense: well-dressed, Lat. comptus; hence, a pretty fellow, Lat. bellus homo, Ar.

accomplished, elegant, exquisite, refined, dainty, clever, witty, of persons or their words and acts, Ar.; κ. περί τι clever about a thing, Plat.; of a dogʼs instinct, exquisite, acute, Plat.; in a sneering sense, of Sophists who refine overmuch, studied, affected, Eur., etc.
adv. κομψῶς, elegantly, prettily, daintily, Ar., Plat., etc.
κομψότερον ἔχειν to be better in health, NTest.

div1.head: κοναβέω
div1.sense: to resound, clash, ring, reecho, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: κοναβηδόν
div1.sense: with a noise, clash, din, Anth.

div1.head: κόναβος
div1.sense: a ringing, clashing, din, Od., Hes.

div1.head: κόνδυλος
div1.sense: a knuckle, κονδύλοις πατάξαι, opp. to ἐπὶ κόρρης (a slap in the face), Dem.: proverb., κολλύραν καὶ κόνδυλον ὄψον ἐπʼ αὐτῇ a roll and knuckle- sauce to it, i. e. a good thrashing, Ar.

div1.head: κονέω
div1.sense: to raise dust: to hasten, Anth.

div1.head: κονία
div1.sense: dust, a cloud of dust, stirred up by menʼs feet, Il.; also in pl., like Lat. arenae, Hom., etc.
sand or soil (v. ὑπερέπτω) Il.
ashes, in pl. like Lat. cineres, Od.
a fine powder, sprinkled over wrestlersʼ bodies after being oiled, to make them more easily grasped by the opponent:—this powder was also used in the bath, Ar.
div1.etym: ῑ in κονίῃσιν, in other cases ῑ usually.

div1.head: κονιατός
div1.sense: plastered or pitched, Xen.

div1.head: κονιάω
div1.sense: to plaster or whiten over, Lat. dealbare, Dem.:—Pass. to be whitened, NTest.

div1.head: κονιορτός
div1.sense: dust stirred up, a cloud of dust, such as is made by troops, Hdt., Ar., etc.; κ. τῆς ὕλης νεωστὶ κεκαυμένης, i. e. a cloud of woodashes, Thuc.
metaph. a dirty fellow, Dem.

div1.head: κονίσαλος
div1.sense: a cloud of dust, Il.

div1.head: κόνις
div1.sense: Lat. cinis, dust, Il., etc.;—of the grave, Pind., Soph.
ashes, Hom.
= κονία II, Luc.: metaph. of toil, Luc.

div1.head: κονίω
div1.sense: to make dusty, cover with clouds of dust, Il.:—Pass., φεῦγον κεκονιμένοι all dusty fled they, Virgilʼs pulverulenta fuga dant terga, Il.; hence, to be in great haste, Ar., etc.
Pass. to be sprinkled as with dust, Theocr.
intr., κονίοντες πεδίοιο galloping oʼer the dusty plain, Hom.

div1.head: Κοννᾶς
div1.sense: a drunken flute-player; Κόννου ὁ ψῆφος, proverb. of a worthless opinion, Ar.

div1.head: κοντός
div1.sense: a pole, punting-pole, boat-hook, Lat. contus, Od., Hdt., Attic: the shaft of a pike, Luc.

div1.head: κοντοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying a pole or pike, Luc.

div1.head: κόνυζα
div1.sense: a strong-smelling plant, fleabane, pulicaria, poet. κνύζα, Theocr.

div1.head: κοπάζω
div1.sense: to grow weary: of the wind, to abate, Hdt., NTest.

div1.head: κοπεύς
div1.sense: a chisel, Luc.

div1.head: κοπή
div1.sense: a cutting in pieces, slaughter, NTest.

div1.head: κοπιάω
div1.sense: to be tired, grow weary, Ar., NTest.
to work hard, toil, NTest.

div1.head: κόπις
div1.sense: a prater, liar, wrangler, Eur.

div1.head: κοπίς
div1.sense: a chopper, cleaver, a broad curved knife, somewhat like our bill, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: κόπος
div1.sense: a striking, beating, Aesch., Eur.
toil, trouble, suffering, Aesch., Soph.
weariness, fatigue, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: κόππα
div1.sense: a letter of the ancient Greek alphabet (#4), retained as a numeral = 90, between π ( 80 ) and this shews that it was the same as the Hebr. (koph) and Lat. Q; cf. σταῦ, σάμπι.

div1.head: κοππατίας
div1.sense: branded with the letter koppa, as a mark, ἵππος κ. Ar.; cf. σαμφόρας.

div1.head: κόπρειος
div1.sense: full of dung, filthy, Ar.

div1.head: κοπρία
div1.sense: a dunghill: also = κόπρος, NTest.

div1.head: κοπρίζω
div1.sense: to dung, manure, Od.

div1.head: κοπρολόγος
div1.sense: a dung-gatherer, a dirty fellow, Ar.

div1.head: κόπρος
div1.sense: dung, ordure, manure, Hom., Hdt., etc.
a farm-yard, home-stead, Hom.

div1.head: κοπροφορέω
div1.sense: to cover with dung or dirt, Ar.

div1.head: κοπροφόρος
div1.sense: carrying dung; κόφινος κ. a dung- basket, Xen.

div1.head: κοπρών
div1.sense: a place for dung, privy, Dem.

div1.head: κοπτός
div1.sense: chopped small: κοπτή, ἡ, a cake of pounded sesame, Anth.

div1.head: κόπτω
div1.sense: to strike, smite, knock down, Od.; κόψε μιν παρήιον smote him on the cheek Il.

to cut off, chop off, Hom., etc.; κ. δένδρα to fell trees, Thuc., etc.; κ. τὴν χώραν to cut down the trees in it, to lay it waste, Xen.:—Pass., of ships, to be shattered or disabled by the enemy, Thuc.:—metaph., φρενῶν κεκομμένος stricken in mind, Aesch.
to hammer, forge, Hom.: to stamp metal, coin money, Hdt.:— Mid. to coin oneself money, order to be coined, Hdt.: Pass., of the money, to be stamped or coined, Ar.
to knock at the door, Lat. pulsare, Ar., etc.
to cut small, chop up or pound in a mortar, Hdt.
of a horse, to jolt or shake his rider, Xen.
metaph. to tire out, weary, Dem.
Mid. κόπτομαι, to beat oneʼs breast through grief, Lat. plangere, Il., Hdt., Plat.
κόπτεσθαί τινα to mourn for any one, Lat. plangere aliquem, Eur., etc.

div1.head: κορακῖνος
div1.sense: a young raven, Ar.

div1.head: κόραξ
div1.sense: Lat. corvus, a raven or carrion-crow, Aesch., etc.; in imprecations, ἐς κόρακας "pasce corvos," "go to the dogs," "go and be hanged," Ar.; βάλλʼ ἐς κόρακας Ar.; οὐκ ἐς κόρακας ἀποφθερεῖ; Ar.; ἐς κόρακας οἰχήσεται Ar.
anything like a ravenʼs beak, an engine for grappling ships, Polyb.
a hooked handle of a door, Anth.
and instrument of torture, Luc.

div1.head: κοράσιον
div1.sense: a girl, maiden, Anth., NTest.

div1.head: κόραυνα
div1.sense: a barbarism for κόρη, Ar.

div1.head: κορβᾶν
div1.sense: a gift or votive offering for the service of God, NTest.:—hence κορβανᾶς, ὁ, the treasury of the temple at Jerusalem, NTest.

div1.head: κορδακικός
div1.sense: like the dance κόρδαξ· hence, tripping, running, ῥυθμὸς κ., of trochaic metres, Arist.

div1.head: κορδακισμός
div1.sense: the dancing of the κόρδαξ, Dem.

div1.head: κόρδαξ
div1.sense: the cordax, a dance of the old Comedy, κόρδακα ἑλκύσαι to dance the κόρδαξ, prob. from its slow, trailing movement, Ar.

div1.head: κορέννυμι
div1.etym: κεκορηώς, Epic part. perf. act. with pass. sense
div1.sense: to sate, satiate, satisfy, τινα Theogn., Aesch.: to fill one with a thing, c. dat., Il.; also c. gen. rei, to fill full of, Soph.:—Mid. to satisfy oneself, have oneʼs fill, c. gen., ἐκορέσσατο φορβῆς Il., etc.; c. part., κλαίουσα κορέσσατο she had her fill of weeping, Od.: —Pass. to be satiated, Hes.; rarely c. dat. rei, πλούτωι κεκορημένος Theogn.; ὕβρι Hdt.

div1.head: κόρευμα
div1.sense: = κορεία, maidenhood, Eur., in pl.

div1.head: κορεύομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be a maid, grow up to maidenhood, Eur.

div1.head: κορέω
div1.sense: to sweep, sweep out, Od.; κ. τὴν Ἑλλάδα to sweep Greece clean, depopulate her, Ar.

div1.head: κόρημα
div1.sense: a besom, broom, Ar.

div1.head: κόρη
div1.sense: fem. of κόρος, κοῦρος
a maiden, maid, damsel, Lat. puella, Il., Soph., etc.
a bride, young wife, Hom., Eur.
a daughter, κοῦραι Διός Il.; κ. Διός, of Athene, Aesch.:—in voc., κούρα my daughter, Aesch., Soph.
the pupil of the eye, Lat. pupula, because a little image appears therein, Eur., Ar.
a long sleeve reaching over the hand, Xen.
Κόρη, Doric Κόρα, Ionic Κούρη, ἡ, Cora, the Daughter (of Demeter), name under which Persephone (Proserpine) was worshipped in Attica, τῇ Μητρὶ καὶ τῇ Κούρῃ Hdt., etc.; Δημήτηρ καὶ Κόρη Xen., etc.

div1.head: κορθύνω
div1.sense: to lift up, raise, Ζεὺς κόρθυνεν ἑὸν μένος raised high his wrath, Hes.:—Pass., κῦμα κορθύεται waxes high, rears its crest, Il.

div1.head: κόρθυς
div1.sense: in Theocr., κόρθυος ἁ τομά the swathe of mown corn.

div1.head: κορίαννον
div1.sense: coriander, Ar.

div1.head: κορίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to fondle, caress, coax, Ar.

div1.head: Κορίνθιος
div1.sense: Corinthian, Hdt., etc.:—also Κορινθιακός, ή, όν, Xen.; Κορινθικός, Anth.

div1.head: Κόρινθος
div1.sense: Corinth, the city and country, Il., Hdt., Attic; famed for its luxury, whence the proverb οὐ παντὸς ἀνδρὸς εἰς Κόρινθον ἐσθ’ ὁ πλοῦς;— with a masc. adj., ὀφρυόεντα K. Orac. ap. Hdt.:—proverb., Διὸς Κόρινθος, used of persons who are always repeating the same old story, Ar., etc.
adv. Κορινθόθι, at Corinth, Il.

div1.head: κόρις
div1.sense: a bug, Lat. cimex, Ar.

div1.head: κορκορυγή
div1.sense: the rumbling of the empty bowels: generally, any hollow noise, a din, tumult, Aesch., Ar.

div1.head: κορμός
div1.sense: the trunk of a tree (with the boughs lopped off), Od., Eur.; κορμοὶ ξύλων logs of timber, Hdt.; κ. ναυτικοί, i. e. oars, Eur.

div1.head: κόρος
div1.sense: oneʼs fill, satiety, surfeit, Hom., etc.; πάντων μὲν κόρος ἔστι, καὶ ὕπνου one may have oneʼs fill of all things, even of sleep, etc., Il.; κ. ἔχειν τινός to have oneʼs fill of a thing, Eur.
the consequence of satiety, insolence, Pind.; πρὸς κόρον insolently, Aesch.

div1.head: κόρος2
div1.sense: a boy, lad, stripling, Hom., etc.: κοῦροι young men, warriors, Il.; also servants, like Lat. pueri, Hom.
with gen. of prop. names, a son, Od.; Θησέως κ. Soph., etc.
div1.etym: Prob. from κείρω, one who has cut his hair short on emerging from boyhood.

div1.head: κόρος3
div1.sense: the Hebrew cor, a dry measure containing 10 Attic medimni, about 120 gallons, NTest.

div1.head: κόρση
div1.sense: one of the temples, the side of the forehead, Il.;—so in Attic, ἐπὶ κόρρης πατάσσειν to box on the ear, Dem.; cf. κόνδυλος.
the hair on the temples, which is the first to turn gray, Aesch.

div1.head: Κορυβάντειος
div1.sense: Corybantian, Anth.

div1.head: Κορυβαντιάω
div1.sense: to be filled with Corybantic frenzy, Plat.:—in Ar., comically, of a drowsy person suddenly starting up.

div1.head: Κορυβαντίζω
div1.sense: to purify or consecrate by Corybantic rites, Ar.

div1.head: Κορύβας
div1.sense: a Corybant, priest of Cybele in Phrygia; in pl. Κορύβαντες, Eur., etc.
enthusiasm, Luc.

div1.head: κορυδός
div1.sense: the crested lark, Ar.

div1.head: κόρυζα
div1.sense: a running at the nose, Lat. pituita, Luc.: —metaph. drivelling, stupidity, Luc.

div1.head: κορυζάω
div1.sense: to run at the nose, Plat.

div1.head: κορυθάϊξ
div1.sense: helmet-shaking, i. e. with waving plume, Il.

div1.head: κορυθαίολος
div1.sense: with glancing helm, Il.

div1.head: κόρυμβος
div1.sense: the uppermost point, head, end, νηῶν ἄκρα κόρυμβα high-pointed sterns of ships, Il.; in pl. of a single ship, Aesch.
the top of a hill, Hdt., Aesch.
= κρωβύλος, Anth.
a cluster of fruit or flowers, Mosch., Anth.

div1.head: κορύνη
div1.sense: a club, mace, Il., Hdt.:— a shepherdʼs staff, Theocr.
div1.etym: υ in Hom.; ῡ in Eur.

div1.head: κορυνήτης
div1.sense: a club-bearer, mace-bearer, Il.

div1.head: κορυνηφόρος
div1.sense: club-bearing: κορυνοφόροι, οἱ, club-bearers, the body-guard of Peisistratus, Hdt.

div1.head: κορυπτίλος
div1.sense: one that butts with the head, Theocr.

div1.head: κορύπτω
div1.sense: to butt with the head, Theocr.

div1.head: κόρυς
div1.sense: a helmet, helm, casque, Hom.
the head, Eur.

div1.head: κορύσσω
div1.sense: to furnish with a helmet, and, generally, to fit out, equip, marshal, Il., Hes.:—Pass. and Mid. to equip or arm oneself, Il.
to make crested, κόρυσσε κῦμα he reared his crested wave, Il.:—Pass. to rear its head, of a wave, Il.; of Rumour, Il.; of clouds, Theocr.

div1.head: κορυστής
div1.sense: a helmed man, an armed warrior, Il.

div1.head: κορυφαία
div1.sense: the head-stall of a bridle, Xen.

div1.head: κορυφαῖον
div1.sense: the upper rim of a hunting-net, Xen.

div1.head: κορυφαῖος
div1.sense: the head man, chief man, leader, Hdt., etc.:—in the Attic Drama, the leader of the chorus, Dem.; κ. ἑστηκώς standing at the head of the row, Ar.
as adj. at the top, ὁ κ. πῖλος the apex, of the Roman flamen, Plut.

div1.head: κορυφή
div1.sense: the head, top, highest point; hence,
the crown or top of the head, Il., Hdt., Attic
the top or peak of a mountain, Il., Hdt., Aesch.
metaph. the highest point, Lat. summa, παντὸς ἔχει κορυφάν is the best of all, Pind.; κορυφὰ λόγων προτέρων the sum and substance of ancient legends, Pind.
the height or excellence of a thing, i. e. the choicest, noblest, best, Pind.

div1.head: κορυφόω
div1.sense: to bring to a head:— Pass., [κῦμα κορυφοῦται rises with arching crest, Il.; τὸ ἔσχατον κορυφοῦται βασιλεῦσι kings are on the highest pinnacle, Pind.
to bring to an end, finish, Plut.:—Pass., κορυφούμενος being summed up, Anth.

div1.head: κορωνεκάβη
div1.sense: old as a crow or Hecuba, Anth.

div1.head: κορώνεως
div1.sense: κορώνεως συκῆ, ἡ, a fig of raven-gray colour, Ar.

div1.head: κορώνη
div1.sense: Lat. cornix, the chough or sea-crow, a small kind with red legs and bill, Od.
= κόραξ, the carrion-crow, Hes., Ar.
anything hooked or curved, like a crowʼs bill,
the handle on a door, Od.
the tip of a bow, on which the bowstring was hooked, Hom.:—metaph., βιῷ κορώνην ἐπιθεῖναι to put a finish to life, Luc.

div1.head: κορωνιάω
div1.sense: to arch the neck, Anth.

div1.head: κορωνίς
div1.sense: crook-beaked, curved, of ships, from the outline of the prow and stern, Hom.
of kine, with crumpled horns, Theocr.
as Subst. a curved line, a flourish with the pen at the end of a book, Anth.:—metaph. an end, finish, ἐπιθεῖναι κορωνίδα τινί Luc.

div1.head: κορωνοβόλος
div1.sense: shooting crows: κορωνοβόλον, τό, a sling or bow for crow-shooting, Etc.; Anth.

div1.head: κορωνός
div1.sense: curved, crooked: with crumpled horns, Archil.

div1.head: κοσκινηδόν
div1.sense: like, as in a sieve, Luc.

div1.head: κοσκινόμαντις
div1.sense: a diviner by a sieve, Theocr.

div1.head: κόσκινον
div1.sense: a sieve, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: κοσκυλμάτια
div1.sense: shreds of leather; in Ar., of the scraps of flattery offered by the tanner Cleon to his patron Δῆμος.

div1.head: κοσμέω
div1.sense: to order, arrange, Hom., etc.: esp. to set an army in array, marshal it, Il.:— Mid., κοσμησάμενος πολιήτας having arranged his men, Il.
generally, to arrange, prepare, δόρπον Od.; ἔργα Hes., etc.
to dispose, order, rule, govern, Hdt., Soph., etc.; τὰ κοσμούμενα orderly institutions, set order, Soph.
in Crete, to be Cosmos (κόσμος ΙΙΙ), rule as such, Arist.
to deck, adorn, equip, furnish, dress, esp. of women, Hhymn., Hes., etc.: Mid., κοσμέεσθαι τὰς κεφαλάς to adorn their heads, Hdt., etc.
metaph. to adorn, embellish, Eur., Thuc., etc.
to honour, pay honour to, Soph., Eur., etc.
in Pass. to be assigned or ascribed to, ἐς τὸν Αἰγύπτιον νόμον αὗται αἱ πόλεις ἐκεκοσμέατο Hdt.

div1.head: κόσμημα
div1.sense: an ornament, decoration, Xen.

div1.head: κόσμησις
div1.sense: an ordering, disposition, arrangement, adornment, Plat.

div1.head: κοσμητής
div1.sense: an orderer, director, Epigr. ap. Aeschin.
an adorner, Xen.

div1.head: κοσμητικός
div1.sense: skilled in arranging: ἡ -κή (sc, τέχνη) , the art of dress and ornament, Plat.

div1.head: κοσμητός
div1.sense: well-ordered, trim, Od.

div1.head: κοσμήτωρ
div1.sense: one who marshals an army, a commander, Hom.

div1.head: κοσμικός
div1.sense: of the world or universe, Luc.
of this world, earthly, NTest.

div1.head: κόσμιος
div1.sense: well-ordered, regular, moderate, δαπάνη Plat.:— κόσμιόν ἐστι, c. inf., ʼtis a regular practice, Ar.
of persons, orderly, well-behaved, regular, discreet, quiet, Ar., Plat., etc.: —τὸ κ. decorum, decency, order, Soph.:—adv. κοσμίως, regularly, decently, Ar., etc.; κοσμίως ἔχειν to be orderly, Plat.

div1.head: κοσμιότης
div1.sense: propriety, decorum, orderly behaviour, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: κοσμοκόμης
div1.sense: dressing the hair, Anth.

div1.head: κοσμοκράτωρ
div1.sense: lord of the world, NTest.

div1.head: κοσμοπλόκος
div1.sense: holding the world together, Anth.

div1.head: κόσμος
div1.sense: order, κόσμῳ and κατὰ κόσμον in order, duly, Il., etc.; μὰψ ἀτὰρ οὐ κατὰ κόσμον Il.; οὐδενὶ κόσμῳ in no sort of order, Hdt., Attic
good order, good behaviour, decency, Aesch., Dem.
the form, fashion of a thing, Od., Hdt.
of states, order, government, Hdt., Thuc.
an ornament, decoration, embellishment, dress, Il., etc.; esp. of women, Lat. mundus muliebris, Il., Hes., etc.:—in pl. ornaments, Aesch., etc.
metaph. honour, credit, Hdt., Soph., etc.
a regulator, title of the chief magistrate in Crete, Arist.
the world or universe, from its perfect order, Lat. mundus, Plat., etc.
mankind, as we use "the world," NTest.

div1.head: κοσμοφθόρος
div1.sense: destroying the world, Anth.

div1.head: κοτέω
div1.sense: to bear a grudge against, c. gen., ἀπάτης κοτέων angry at the trick, Il.: absol. to be angry, Hom.

div1.head: κοτήεις
div1.sense: wrathful, jealous, Il.

div1.head: κοτινηφόρος
div1.sense: producing wild olive-trees, Mosch.

div1.head: κότινος
div1.sense: the wild olive-tree, Lat. oleaster, Ar.

div1.head: κοτινοτράγος
div1.sense: eating wild olive-berries, Ar.

div1.head: κότος
div1.sense: a grudge, rancour, wrath, Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: κοτταβίζω
div1.sense: to play at the cottabus, Ar.

div1.head: κοττάβιον
div1.sense: the prize of the game κότταβος, Arist.

div1.head: κότταβος
div1.sense: the cottabus, a Sicilian game, much in vogue at Athens. Each person threw the wine left in his cup, so as to fall in a metal basin; if the whole fell with a clear sound, it was a good sign. But the game was played in various ways.

div1.head: κοτυληδών
div1.sense: any cup-shaped hollow:
in pl. the suckers on the arms (πλεκτάναι) of the polypus, Od., in Epic dat. pl. κοτυληδονόφιν.
= κοτύλη 2, the socket of the hip-joint, Ar.

div1.head: κοτύλη
div1.sense: a cup, Hom.
the cup or socket of a joint, esp. of the hip-joint, Il.
a liquid measure, containing 6 κύαθοι, i. e. nearly half a pint, Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: κοτυλήρυτος
div1.sense: that can be drawn in cups, i. e. flowing copiously, streaming, Il.

div1.head: κοτύλων
div1.sense: nickname of a toper, Plut.

div1.head: κουρά
div1.sense: a shearing or cropping of the hair, tonsure, Hdt., Eur.
a lock cut off, Aesch.

div1.head: κουρεῖον
div1.sense: a barberʼs shop, Ar.

div1.head: κουρεύς
div1.sense: a barber, hair-cutter, Lat. tonsor, Plat., Anth., etc.

div1.head: κουρήϊος
div1.sense: youthful, Hhymn.

div1.head: κούρητες
div1.sense: young men, esp. young warriors, Il.
Κουρῆτες, οἱ, the Curetes oldest inhabitants of Pleuron in Aetolia, Il.

div1.head: κουρίας
div1.sense: one with short hair, Luc.

div1.head: κουριάω
div1.sense: of hair, to need clipping, Luc.

div1.head: κουρίδιος
div1.sense: wedded, of the husband (κουρίδιος πόσις) or the wife (κουριδίη ἄλοχος) , Hom.: esp. a lawful, wedded wife, as opp. to a concubine, Hom., Hdt.:—hence, λέχος κουρίδιον our lawful marriage, bed, Il.; κ. δῶμα a husbandʼs house.
later, nuptial, bridal, Ar., Anth.

div1.head: κουρίζω
div1.sense: intr. to be a youth, Od.
trans. to bring up from boyhood, Hes.

div1.head: κούριμος
div1.sense: of, for cutting hair, Eur.
pass. shorn off, Aesch., Eur.
shorn, κρᾶτα Eur.

div1.head: κουρίξ
div1.sense: by the hair, Od.

div1.head: κουροβόρος
div1.sense: devouring children, Aesch.

div1.head: κουροσύνη
div1.sense: youth, youthful prime, Anth.: mirthfulness, Theocr.

div1.head: κουρόσυνος
div1.sense: youthful, Anth.

div1.head: κουρότερος
div1.sense: younger, more youthful, Hom.; used much like a positive.

div1.head: κουροτόκος
div1.sense: bearing boy-children, Eur.

div1.head: κουροτρόφος
div1.sense: rearing boys; ἀγαθὴ κ. good nursing-mother, of Ithaca, Od.; so, κ. Ἑλλάς Eur.

div1.head: κουστωδία
div1.sense: the Lat. custodia, NTest.

div1.head: κουφίζω
div1.sense: intr. to be light, Hes., Eur.: of pain, to be alleviated, assuaged, Soph.
trans. to make light: hence to lift up, raise, Soph.; ἅλμα κουφιεῖν to make a light leap, Soph.; κ. πήδημα Eur.:—Pass. to be lifted up, soar, Plat.
